title: Depends on What You Need it to Do
text: This extender works well if it is located relatively close to the router and is positioned between the router and whatever you are trying to connect to (a wireless TV box, for example) without anything blocking it.  I found that it worked well when placed closer to the router than the wireless TV box and when there was a direct open pathway between the two.  It did not work well when there was a wall or piece of large furniture in front of the extender.  It did, however, significantly improve the wifi signal (connection and speed)  for laptops and tablets regardless of location.  So, depending upon where it is placed and what you need it to do, this can be a great remedy.

Easy setup. It worked fine for a week or so.

Then all of a sudden, it wouldn't connect to the router anymore, even a location where my phone gets full bar wifi signal (merely 15 ft away). However, the extender would connect if it's within a few feet from the router. But what's the point to get an extender if it would only connect when it's few feet away?
We checked the firmware. Updated. Tried to connect to the 5ghz signal. Didn't work. We reset the extender to factory settings. Didn't work. We did everything we could find from support site, nothing worked.
Eventually, we have to request a refund and send it back to Amazon.

title: Ease of set-up for anyone
text:
Clear and simple set-up instructions make the EX 6120 a breeze to mate with your router. Note: be patient when watching for the "green indication lights" on the unit as it connects to your router. In my case, I worried that the green positive connection lights did not come on quickly - thought my router was not communicating with it. It may take a couple of minutes for both router and extender to link up, but it will. No tech support required.
The EX6120 extender is installed at the other end of our home and wifi signal strength is great.

title: Can you hear me now?
text: Yes, it was easy to set up. However, when you hit the modem (access point) WPS button to initiate it, remember that you better know the password to your modem because that will be needed. My system is modem (password), Netgear wireless router (password), then extender (password). I did not initially realize that the modem has the WPS button, not the Netgear router. That effectively means it set up the extender from the modem and without the router involved. I now have 4 networks to log on to. But it certainly does work.

title: NETGEAR Not producing "Up to 1200MPbps"... LOL
text: Clearly, as some NETGEAR 'lower cost' products go, this is no exception to its name. It is a very substandard product for the price in that it just doesn't have the oomph nor the output as claimed. In fact, it's incredibly dismal and under-powered in signal as little at 20 feet away. It was purchased for the purpose of extending my RING doorbell and it does that; but its 'bandwidth' signal for using 'Ookla' or any other service transmits dismal numbers never exceeding beyond 40-49Mbps. I simply can not understand where NETGEAR get's these number from..? In truth, I'd say this is a fraudulent claim in the least. I certainly don't recommend this for high speeds, but also true of most NETGEAR products are that they are easy to install and up and running in no time. It did do that, but the throughput speeds are 10X or more less functional than advertised. Buyer beware.

title: Works OK but not what I thought.
text: I bought this to be able to extend my Verizon DSL's router WIFI signal throughout the house . Unfortunately Verizon has decided to disable the WPS connection on their routers. In order to install this device without using that you must establish a new dedicated network name for the extender that is separate from the routers network. For example if your network name is family123 the suggestion in the setup would be family123_ext. For your devices to use the extender you must go into WIFI settings of your device and select the new network name in order to connect. That does work but if you move to an area of the house that is better served by the router you must then go into the device again and select the routers network name.  I thought this would be a simple WIFI extender that would use the same network all over the house but it is not working out that way.

title: Good product but be sure to download the app.
text: I purchased this so I could extend WIFI to my garage which is 100 feet from my house.  First I put it in my house but couldn't get to the garage no matter what I tried.  Then I put it in the garage and it couldn't find the WIFI in the house.  Setup was really simple using the supplied directions.  The supplied instructions mentions a Netgear phone app called Netgear WIFI Analytics.  This reads the signal strength of your WIFI signal.  This was the answer!!  With this I found an outlet in my garage that had a strong enough signal to work.  Without this signal meter you are trying to chase a ghost.  WIFI is a strange animal but the app allows you to tame it.  The extender works very well now.  The placement can be very specific to say the least.

title: Easy to install, great connection, quality product
text:
The setup took only a few moments before it was ready to go. The relatively compact design helps with not taking up too much wall space and leaves the other outlet slot open, which is great. There was not a single thing I found to be wrong or broken on my product. Just remember: wifi extenders do not help with increasing your internet speeds. This helps with your computer or device not being able to detect your home wifi or for when it barely connects. The download speeds will remain the same. If you are looking for increased download speed, check your system’s hardware and consider a wifi adapter or mesh system if you have the money.

On a different note, when I did need tech support help, the operator was extremely well educated in the subject matter and helped me understand how internet speeds work and their relation to a wifi extender.

4 out of 5 stars, I did not end up needing the product after a while, but when I did, all aspects of it were great! I recommend this product if you’re in a dead zone for your wifi!

title: Overheats and fails after a few months
text:
Makes a decent connection, though the speed is somewhat less than expected, and the ethernet port is extremely limited in speed. Still, it's good enough for connecting a desktop PC or a work laptop with disabled wireless to your Wi-Fi network.

That would all be fine, except that after a few months of use, the unit began overheating and frequently dropping its connection. It comes back within a few seconds in most cases, but such an unstable connection is unacceptable if you lose connection during an online game or become disconnected from your work VPN and have to wait for that to reconnect each time.

Netgear's technical support was responsive, but they jumped me through a bunch of hoops before approving my RMA, and I suspect my threat to contact consumer protection organizations short-circuited whatever other hoops they had planned for me. The RMA process, however, requires that you ship the device back first, paying for the shipping yourself (at least $10), or pay them $15-20 to ship you a new one and a prepaid return shipping label up front. Considering you can frequently buy an open box unit from Amazon Warehouse for $15-25, that doesn't seem like much of a deal.

I guess I'll be replacing this with one of the highly-recommended TP-Link models instead, and buy it from a certain membership warehouse store with a famously generous return policy just in case. I've been using Netgear products for years, but between their poor support for Linux and this, I highly doubt I'll buy any more that aren't branded with their "Nighthawk" designations or need to connect to a computer through anything but an ethernet cable.

title: Needed a simple Access Point without Router/Firewall
text:
I simply needed another access point without a router/firewall functions/features, as I already have two or more firewalls deployed.

Although not immediately apparent from the product description, scanning through the user manual dictates this device can either be used as a wireless bridge connecting to the Internet via another wireless access point or router, or used as an access point, connecting to the Internet via an Ethernet cable.

Setup was quite easy. Plug the device in, wait for a minute or so, connect to the device with your wireless device and or other hard-wired computer to 192.168.*.123.

CONS:
1) Too many passwords and passphrase related questions, and should be optional.

2) Filter via MAC allows all devices to connect, requiring activating deny in order to deny. Rather than the preferred, deny all and allow selected MAC device numbers. Although the current allow all plan works well for most, advanced users would likely prefer to deny all by default, once the device is configured correctly.

title: Awful performance for the money
text:
I bought this extender to enhance range in my backyard/garage and figured I would upgrade to the higher end 1200 model with the hope that it would maintain some semblance of my gigabit fiber connection…not even close. The thing was no more than 15 feet away and couldn’t hit more than ~40 mbps down, 0.1 mbps up. Complete joke of a product.

To add, this was with the extender configured in access point mode, with a cat 6 Ethernet cable from the modem. I intended to use it in extender mode for ease of installation but it just made my entire network slow and didn’t even work.

Returning and purchasing another used router on eBay to setup in AP mode since I went through the trouble of routing plenum Ethernet through my hvac to the addition on my home. This is by far the more cost effective solution if you are planning to wire the device in anyways. $25 shipped for a used netgear nighthawk r7000.

title: Old model, no longer supported, lots of bugs
text:
There are a lot of positive reviews, but they are from several years ago. This is now old, unsupported tech and is a pain to use.

I did get this working after some tears, but then I had to reset my router and I could never get it to work again. I tried things like a factory reset, but I always got an error when trying to connect to the range extender: ERR_SSL_VERSION_OR_CIPHER_MISMATCH. It turns out that the default firmware is incompatible with all new browsers and so you have to download old versions of IE or Firefox to run the setup after a factory reset.

I recommend buying a newer extender that supports current browsers.

title: Don't do it...  unless you want LESS signal.
text: Where to begin... well, first off, I never could get the WPS to connect, even sitting right next to my router.  I'm pretty tech savvy, so this was highly annoying.  Finally, I got it connected regularly and you can see the results in my photos.  The first is on my phone, connected directly to my wireless router, sitting about 6' away from it (no walls or anything between us).  The 2nd is with my phone, connected to this piece of crap, sitting in the same spot and only about 2' from the extender.  I wasn't expecting it to be the same Mbps as my router, but a drop of nearly 80% seems outrageous.  When I checked my son's computer - upstairs and through several walls and why I bought the extender - the speed through our wireless and the extender were about the same.  Even when I moved the extender to a plug in front of the doorway going upstairs so there would be no walls between the router + extender OR the extender + his laptop.  The only difference is that the extender drops its connection every 15-20 minutes, making for a very frustrating user experience.  Sending this back because it literally made things worse.

title: Product Description Inaccurate
text: I bought this device primarily based on Amazon’s product description that up to 20 devices can connect to the underlying WIfi Router network, however, this Netfear network extender only connects 12 devices at one time. The WiFi router I connected this device to can support up to 15 devices.  Additionally, this WiFi extender hijacks the underlying WiFi network and interferes with devices connecting to the router, although Netgear’s recommendation is to connect devices directly to the original network if there is a strong signal. Furthermore, the WiFi extender persistently does not recognize devices that are connected to it and prevents access to the extender’s administration/settings website/portal.

title: Auto WEP does not provide proper security
text:
I purchased this last week and tried and tried to set it up. I have a Netgear router/modem and thought the auto connect capability was enough to add the extender. NO!!! The auto connect option will not handle WEP/WPA-2 security automatically. The extender must be reset to factory setting then manually set up.
I tried for three days to go through the manual setup but kept getting errors using mywifiext.net. THAT DOES NOT WORK!!!
You have to put NETGEAR_EXT as the WiFi carrier. Then and only then can the extender be set up.
Why, oh Why, can’t the auto WPA setup handle the security???
I will keep the extender for now.

title: Think of this as a relay. It does work but don't expect miraculous speeds
text:
I have an older model of this unit but I highly recommend this product. You must be strategic about how you use it in order to really be satisfied with it! Don't expect to be able to download anything as quickly as your primary wifi. This device is basically a relay that slingshots your signal from your primary wifi back to connected devices. It is unavoidable that there will be some delay in signal(unless you opt for the mesh setup but that is not what I have gone for).

I put all my smart devices on the connections from this relay instead of my primary wifi as they are far away the originating router, do not require higher speeds, and they free up bandwidth slots on the main router. Even my tablets rarely have streaming issues on the 5GHz band from the relay! But for downloading, you absolutely are going to need to be connected to your primary router if you do not want to pull your teeth out.

I am very happy with this product, but I also went in knowing what to expect. I knocked off one star because I think there should be more honest marketing to average consumers regarding these units, but the setup, and use, of these extenders really are phenomenal! Go in with realistic expectations and you'll be satisfied with this product.

title: This unit doesn't like an Ethernet Wired Network
text: I have a Cat 5e wired network throughout my large house. The Ethernet plug on the device (LG Smart TV) furthest from my router has failed and the TV only works with WiFi. The distance makes it hard to get a good signal. I bought this unit to "Extend" the WiFi signal to provide better signal strength. First during setup, the MAC address that showed at setup on the computer screen was different than the one on the sticker on the unit. That seemed strange. Second, once setup, the distance from the router to this unit was limited to about 20 feet to maintain a "Green" light on the unit. The signal was not increased at the TV when the unit was functioning. During setup, I noticed that I had 7 wired units in my "Connected" list in the router. As the day went on, evidently this unit removed the wired units from that router connected list. That meant that any other device that was not connected by WiFi in addition to being wire connected, failed. I also noticed that the icon on the computer task bar went from a computer icon to a WiFi icon which was again, strange. The reason I noticed the wired device falling off the list was that I was watching a different TV when it failed, due to lost signal. The troubleshooting found the devices removed from the wire connected list in the router. I removed this device and "Reconnected" all the other wired devices and with several "reboots" thing came back to normal. The furthest TV still has a very weak signal, so I will have to find another way to fix the problem. This is the second extender device I have tried. The other one would not allow a network name with spaces. My network name has 3 words separated by spaces. Not going thru the trouble of renaming everything...

My main complaint with this product however was the setup. Not only was it VERY confusing, but it's impossible to set up with discretion. I didnt want the home owner knowing about it because I didn't want to offend him with my need for an extender. Only to find out I not only needed to set it up in the same room as the router, but it shows up on the list of Wi-Fi as a new one, immediately blowing my cover. And there is no option to change the name that I saw. Overall, would buy again for the price I paid on prime day but not full price.

title: Netgear Extenders are bad

To no solution, I am accumulating a grave yard of these.  The first two that failed went to e-recycling, now these three will be joining.  The definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over and expecting a different result.  Going with these from Net Gear is insanity.  Look for something different folks.  I am trying another brand available on amazon and will see how it works.

title: you don't want one of these: Case 46570147
text:
I have to unplug this device almost daily because it loses sync. The main router is less than 20' away and I have a solid signal to the laptop in the same area. The only reason I have this is to provide a wired connection. There appears to be no 'management' for the device except to set up an account with the manufacturer - another source of spam emails no doubt.
UPDATE: Spent another five hours working on this and made a discovery: I get 5 Mbps speed when connected to the device (on those rare occasions when it works) and when unplug it and use the poor quality Wi-Fi, I get 100 Mbps. The 5G network never connects to the Internet. This thing actually works better from the trash can! Save yourself the money, time and frustration and get something that actually works.
I will update this again when, or if, I get the email reply from 'tech support'
Update 2: Spent another three hours fighting with this thing. I was able to get it connected and found the following: 2.4g 25mbs/19, 5g 148/103, Ethernet to the device 94/81. Connecting wireless to the router I get 296mbs with an Ethernet connection of over 400. The provider at2 is unable to deliver consistent speeds, even over fiber.
I unplugged and re-plugged the ‘extender’ and had the following results: 2.4g 12/20, 5g no internet. When attempting to use the web link, I get the following error message: “this site can’t provide a secure connection”.
Basically, this is an unreliable device and should be an embarrassment to anyone associated with the company. Delivery to landfill in two weeks.
As for my network consulting business, I have eliminated at least one manufacturer to recommend.

I stated that I would not contact them and wanted the support that accompanies the purchased extender, I was told someone would get back on 2 days. After hanging up, I received an email stating “Sorry we got disconnected…please call back…” So the tech support is not skilled enough to assist with basic WPA2 or other protocols and lies and defers in order to prevent escalation. I also have a Netgear cable WiFi as my main router.
I will be changing them all out to a vendor that can provide basic tech support with out playing games and wasting my time.

title: Very affordable bargain to extend your WiFi...at least
text:
NETGEAR WiFi Range Extender EX6120 with AC1200 Dual Band Wireless Signal Booster & Repeater

Pros

Affordable and handy alternative a $40 total
Easy to setup
Works as advertised with WiFi

Cons

Do not exceed wireless devices connected to it
Same data speeds as the router that transmits to it
The Ethernet port failed in my sample

The NETGEAR EX6120 WiFi Extender is a nice and compact piece of communications hardware that can be beneficial in homes or large apartments where the main Router / Gateway has difficulty to reach the farthest corner of your place or you insist to keep your main Router hidden, weakening its signals.
Having used an earlier technology NETGEAR router in the past I was counting on an easy and smooth installation experience: I was well pleased about this one. For the newbie, it is as easy as plugging the extender to an AC outlet, pressing the WPS button in your main router and another WPS button on the extender. But, yes: there are some tech heads among us that demand to get “under the hood” of any gadget. Guess what? You can login to the extender via your web browser of choice to tweak things – or just presume that you know how they work. At any rate, both ways of setting it up are user friendly for each kind of audience. And its 2 antennas can be rotated 180 degrees each, just in case you are as obsessive with catching your main router's WiFi signal as I am with Digital TV antennas to get the strongest signal with the most channels.
Do you have in a far corner of your home a computer, game console or video disk player that won't connect to your network unless it can connect with an Ethernet cable? No problem! The EX6120bWiFi Extender has one Ethernet port. So, you can have WiFi AND Ethernet in a place 'far, far away' from your main router within your house. I tried it with a desktop PC connected by Ethernet, several WiFi devices and it ran a windows update download, rebooted and then... the Ethernet port stopped working! Tryouts with other PC and cable didn't work: the Ethernet port failed.
Now, don't try playing wise guy or wise girl by trying to connect via WiFi more devices that it is recommended to support, specially if you use one of those devices for teleconferencing (“ZOOM, TEAMS, anyone, anyone?”). This device won't make your WiFi network run faster or better if your main router and / or internet provider's service level subscription has limitations (remember the last time your favorite interstate highway suddenly got all lanes jammed and you though that the next exit will take you to your place faster?). So, if you see a “internet connection is unstable” message during teleconferencing with an application like ZOOM, you may need to compromise between dining out weekly each month or paying for an upgrade to your internet service that allows at least 20 MBPS. A WiFi extender won't make the cut.
Sometimes, you may convince your significant other to relocate your main router in a better location to broadcast your WiFi or may get a Router upgrade that can actually extend the signal reach out. But, for those of us who can't, the NETGEAR EX6120 is a good alternative with an extensive WiFi reach.
All photos (c) 2021 by reviewer.

title: Overheats Constantly
text:
Yes this is by the oven but I never use the stove or oven. In fact the kitchens been very chilly lately. But this extender overheats constantly.

You can see it's plugged into a rebooter, but even that doesn't help without a large fan right next to the extender, on high, all day and night.

I need it in this spot to get signal out to security cams out back, and it DOES give them a strong signal, but... not without life support.

title: Get something else
text:
These extenders would not connect to the mywifiext.net wizard, so I had to use the wps button. That's all good, but no way to change the name of the extender like you can do with the wizard. So if you've got multiple extenders you want to set up, they will all have the same name.
Even after setting up extenders, to use for security cameras around perimeter of house, with them having good signal from router, connecting to them to watch cameras was impossible once they go to sleep. You have to sign into each extender separately, which defeats the purpose if you are away from your home.
Tech support was questionable at best.. gave this foreign sounding man remote access to my computer system to troubleshoot my setup, he's trying to tell me I've got numerous "things"accessing my system and started to try and sell me Netgear firewall protection, even tho I've got the firewall with my router. Couldn't trust him after that, cancelled the troubleshooting session.
Returning these and trying something else..
Beware

title: works great
text: This is the second Netgear Extender I have installed (EX3700 and EX6120).  The 3700 is used exclusively with my home camera system to connect to the router, this one is used for all the other WiFi devices in the house.  The 6120 has greater Xmit power and therefore greater coverage and can handle more devices.  It even cleaned up an apparent dead spot at the far end of the house.  Great product and easy to install and configure.

title: BUYER BEWARE!!
text:
Bought the new on 01/13/2023. It didn’t work both for extender as well as access point.
Contacted Netgear customer service. Their response:
//——
My name is —-, I am the network specialist handling your case with regard to your AC1200 Dual Band WiFi Range Extender(EX6120). To start with, the warranty details are as follows:

•Purchase date: 1/13/2023
*Manufacturing date: 10/1/2021
•Basic technical support (from the purchase date): 90 days
•Hardware warranty (from the purchase date): 1 year

It seems that the purchase date specified for this registration is beyond a reasonable "presumed shelf life" (difference between the manufacture date and purchase date)
—////

So I returned the item to Amazon.
It seems that Netgear will not support the product bought as on even within 10 days of purchase, because it’s shelf life.

Very disappointed with Netgear

title: 5G band does not work in dual band mode
text:
As many people already pointed out, the 5G band cannot work in "basic" or dual band mode, as it has DHCP issue for IP address assigning. That means your client cannot get IP address assigned by your router correctly. It only affects the 5G band, while 2.4G band works. The only way to bypass this issue is to switch to "fast lane" mode, that means your router will use only one band to connect the router and the other one band to connect to clients. It is not the full dual band at all.
I have to return this one and switch to another big brand AC1200 extender. The other brand externder works like a charm and it is $10 cheaper. I am not sure what happened to Netgear, but it seems no longer a trustable brand anymore.

I plugged the device in the same room as my modem - hit the WPS button and it synced - moved it to my kitchen, plugged the IP camera in to the ethernet port and scanned for it on my PC - boom - came right up.

As for speeds - it takes my 300mbs wifi and turns it into 20mbs - so on that aspect, its trash. Maybe not for some people who will say "its better than nothing" and yes, they are correct... it is. either way - it did what I wanted so I am happy - 5 stars.

title: This little extender works great!!
text:
1ST I cannot give enough praise to my AMAZON PRIME membership for price and speed of delivery.
This extender by Netgear is fantastic! Setup was a breeze even for a tech illeriate like me. All you have to do is plug it in an outlet in the same room with your modem. Wait for the flashing light to turn green.
Push the WPS button, clearly labeled. When it's ready push the WPS button on your modem. Wait a minute or two then go to your WIFI settings, I used my smart phone which has 2 security apps running, and when prompted click the NETGEAR_EXT then put in your password.
I needed it for my mancave/shop outback. Works fantastic!!
Dropped service one time while I was on vacation but all I had to do was push factory reset and it reset in a matter of seconds.
Be sure to register your device with NERGEAR and get 90 days tech support. They emailed me right away when it had lost signal.
BTW;
If you install yourself there is a scam you'll get if you get an error code. Mine showed as Ohio n the guy walked me thru setup n said he'd have to transfer me tech support but it would cost 89.90. I said forget it I'll return it. Then he said could I pay 60.00? I said," I'll just return it cause I didn't pay that much for it." Watch it cause the one that kept calling me was smooth but I started wondering why he kept calling then realized he was working me. My netgear extender works great boosting my wifi signal so I can have my shop about 75' to 100' from my modem connected to wifi.

text: Installed this, went through many variations to get it to work, kept getting notification that device not configured (it was, and I connected to it with multiple devices) then it kept dropping the signal. Then more messages that this device needs attention PLUS my Apple devices kept indicating it was an unsecure connection. Might be the WPA2 encryption but never found out how to even identify the type of encryption the device was using (there are weak and strong encryption protocols within WPA2). I have worked with Wi-Fi since it was a brand-new technology and the way this item was designed baffles me. So back to Amazon it went...if I have to troubleshoot a new device beyond the instructions, well, I just don't do that for very long. New Linksys deice installed and none of the NetGear issues. BUT Linksys installation manager takes you to an unsecure web site to set up passwords. Guess both of these companies take short cuts on security!

title: Once set up EX6120 seems to work great, replacing a 5 year old EX2700
text:
First I want to say this AC1200 extender (EX6120) has been working flawlessly and definitely provides a more solid, stable signal throughout the main floor and basement, much better than the N300 (EX2700) than we'd had for 5 years. We recently switched our internet to use a Verizon Jetpack hotspot, and this extender provides a nice boost to that signal.

I did encounter some issues in setting it up, however. In following Netgear's procedure, Typing in the URL to access the firmware, it initially appeared to work. I signed into my hotspot router to obtain the IP address of the extender and then was able to access it directly through that address to learn about a firmware update which I successfully downloaded and installed. However, upon subsequently trying to use Netgear's procedure, I obtained a warning from my Chrome browser that I was trying to access an unsafe site..

To make a long story short, after some Google searches, I learned from a Netgear site that this occurs because they have programmed their firmware to be accessed from the browser AS IF it is a website, and recent changes to Chrome and some other browsers are not able to validate a security certificate for that URL so they are interdicting the access to prevent a security breach, which, of course, isn't actually a concern because you're not really accessing an external website at all. On their site, Netgear provided instructions on how to proceed to get around this false warning issue, and then I was able to access the device to make changes etc.

Unfortunately, I didn't see any information on this in the box or in the online users manual I downloaded, so it took some time to sort out. It was a bit frustrating at the time, but now looking back, I see it as a minor inconvenience given how wonderfully this extender has been working for us. So I just wanted to update my initial review to hopefully assist someone else who may encounter this issue.

Worthless for use as I'm away from home for stretches of time and have security cameras on it. I wouldn't buy again.

title: 5-min setup and works through brick walls
text:
I have this router set up as an extender in a detached house on the property. The signal is strong, picks up the original SSID in the attic and through one bedroom. And then runs the relay through drywall and a brick wall in the new area. The signal in the new area is all bars at 5G w/ a 2G alternative. Download and streaming speeds are excellent, also. I can wirelessly setup a new office area there, w/ network printing.

I positioned this router in a room w/ a window to pick up the original router signal. Works flawlessly so far.

I've seen a lot of complaints on setup, so here is how I got mine running in under 5 min:

1. Plug the router into the wall.
2. Wait for the router lights to turn green.
3. Once green, connect to the router via your laptop or desktop. In your wifi drop down, look for NETGEAR_EXT and connect to that.
4. Once connected to the extender, open a browser window and type this as the address: 192.168.1.250
5. This should bring you to the setup page and you can go ahead and setup your router from here.
6. Follow all the prompts to connect to your original wifi router.
7. Be sure to connect to the extender router again with another device after setup to test that it works.
8. if successful, complete the setup and close the browser window.
9. Enjoy your new wifi router!

title: This may be my last Netgear purchase
text:
Netgear used to be good about 5 to 10 years ago. The current experience is nowhere near the same.

The UI is unresponsive, full of glitches and errors.

First off, it forces you to create an account if you want to configure it with the web ui. You must enter your email, password, and choose "security questions" such as "what was your first Netgear purchase".

Gone are the days when you have a locally served easy to use and functional page without revealing your email ID to the company. (It does offer a WPS install, but it seems that's just to tick off the "easy to install" category. I want to be able to configure this manually.)

On this page you'll see irrelevant advertisement, e.g. Netgear Web Analytics that I have nothing to do with.

The configuration for 5G can't select the channel automatically. You have to choose something from the drop-down. Can't tell if this is a problem with the hardware or the UI.

Then Netgear pops up a message warning you to not set the SSID (name of network) same as your router - without clearly explaining why. (Perhaps it's because they know the quality of the extender is poor, and it will drag down the whole network with it if we do that?)
This essentially means they recommend you to add the new network to every device your have in your house. And if some of them only support one network, good luck.

Finally the range itself is horrible. The router I wanted to extend actually allows more stable connection than the extender, irrespective of where I place the extender.

----

Update -

My original review was primarily about the user interface. After testing it out for some more time, I believe the hardware is either as bad, or is handicapped with bad software.

The advertised "upto 1200Mbps" is a total lie or a gross misrepresentation of facts. The best I could get was upto 20Mbps, or 1/60 of the advertised speed.
But that's not even the normal use bandwidth. Where I needed it, this device managed hardly 2Mbps. The original signal was crossing 50 or 100Mbps despite low bars.
And it has difficulty keeping connected to the router when placed very close to it.

So this turned out to be a total junk, and I feel bad but I had to return it.

A lifelong Netgear user... but now I'm gonna switch over to something else. I hear good things about Asus, may be that's gonna be my next networking equipment provider.

title: Setup does not follow manual instruction; connection sketchy at 10 feet; speedtest.net hangs
text:
I have a Netgear Nighthawk 1750 router, but WiFI signal at my stairway goes down a bunch to 1 bar of signal oince inside my bedroom. I placed this range extender closer to the signal in the next room, but it's still not any better and signal strength is 4 of 5 bars.

Setup is absolutely garbage . The booklet instructions do not match what you need to do.
Booklet said go to mywifiext.net once connected to the range extender SSID.
This does NOT work in current versions of android and Chrome.
My phone is a 2021 MotoG and was just pushed an update last week.
Google Chrome blocks the page as "insecure" and probits you from going to it.
And of course the connection to the extender has no internet at this point.

You must go to the mywifiext.net page from an active internet connection which goes to netgear's help page. Then use the link from there while reconnected to the extender. IDK what the difference is but only then does the page not bug out as insecure and it was what I eventually happned onto. But it took well over an hour of fooling around and goofing with it. I know my way around tech stuff. It should not be this hard.

Once done with all of that I still cannot get a stable internet connection. Speedtest.net either hangs 'connecting' or the speed is far lower than if I connected to the 1bar signal from the router alone.
I don't know how to monitor signal between the range extender and the router.

In any case. I'm not seeing any benefit from this range extender at this point and I will probably return it.

title: Garbage wifi extender
text:
Bought this extender to reach less than 100ft away in my house and VERY disappointed with it's performance. So much so after doing some in-depth testing of it's performance I decided to purchase a different one that performed WAY better! https://www.amazon.com/dp/B09X171PW3?ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_details&th=1

Testing Results:
Router = Connecting directly to the router
CurrentExtender = Connecting to the current extender I'm writing a review about
NewExtender = Connecting to the new extender I mentioned above (https://www.amazon.com/dp/B09X171PW3?ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_details&th=1)

Both Extenders Right Beside the Router And Testing Right Beside Both Extenders:
Router-2G = 38.6Mbps
CurrentExtender-2G = 11.1 Mbps
NewExtender-2G = 30.4 Mpbs
Router-5G = 58.7 Mpbs
CurrentExtender-2G = 16.2 Mpbs
NewExtender-2G = 57 Mpbs

Both Extenders 75ft from the Router With Wall Obstructions And Testing Right Beside Both Extenders:
Router-2G = 46.1 Mbps
CurrentExtender-2G = 14.4 Mbps
NewExtender-2G = 36.5 Mpbs
Router-5G = 58.7 Mpbs
CurrentExtender-2G = 26.7 Mpbs
NewExtender-2G = 56.3 Mpbs

The numbers speak for themselves!

title: This range extender has some major problems
text: The worst problem is that any device on the 5GHZ Wi-Fi network has no network access. The device will connect fine, but never gets an IP address and therefore cannot access any other devices on the LAN or Internet. The 2.4 GHZ Wi-Fi works fine. Reading reviews and forums, this seems to be a known problem that has never been fixed.  Another irritant is Netgear’s insistence that you register with them and use an email address as the extender login username before you can continue to configure the range extender. After about 6 hours of trying to get the extender to work properly, which included updating the firmware, I gave up and returned it. This leaves me wondering what has happened at Netgear.  Netgear once was a quality company, but after this experience I won’t be buying any more Netgear products.

title: Simple setup. Works well for my purpose.
text: Setup on this device was very simple and I found the instructions in the user manual to be very clear. I'm not  sure why some reviews report otherwise. The device takes a bit longer to boot up than I expected so be sure to wait for the green light before you attempt to initiate setup.  I bought the Netgear AC1200 (EX6120) because I have a few wifi connected flood lights in my back yard that frequently drop connection. I assume that they are not getting a strong enough signal because they work fine when I bring them indoors. Since I've installed this device I have not had a single drop and I can finally use my flood lights as intended. One thing to be aware of is that the device creates a separate wifi segment with its own unique SSID. If you do not pair your equipment with that new SSID you are not taking advantage of the extended range. Re-pairing all of my flood lights to the new wifi segment was the most time consuming part of the installation. It's only been a few days now but so far I am very pleased with this purchase. Some other reviews report the unit failing after a short time so I'll keep an eye on it and report back if I experience the same.

title: Fixed the dead spots within five minutes of arriving
text:
So I keep the gateway in my room for direct Ethernet connect for my consoles for optimal gaming. However, this leaves the other level in my home with spotty Wi-Fi. After all the complaints I finally decided to try an extender. This thing was everything I wanted and more. I took it out of the box and had it setup within 5 minutes. SUPER easy setup and it works so great.

As long as you make sure to have it close enough to your gateway it will extend the signal to where you need it. It's also important that you first set it up IN THE SAME room as your gateway and then once it's setup you move it to where it's needed. As long as you do that, you'll be happy and so will all your devices!

title: Does Exactly What It Says It Does

title: Frustrating. And I'm a techie.
text: Rather than extend an existing network, this "extender" creates one or two additional networks (2G and/or 5G). The result is that devices can switch between networks randomly, causing breaks in coverage. It seemed that the device was not able to hold its connection for long periods, resulting in these switches. This is particularly frustrating when streaming (music or video) and even more so on video calls. I would have returned the device, but missed the window as I foolishly persisted with it, trying difference configurations. I've now disconnected it and found a different solution. $43 down the drain, plus many hours.

title: Can't Hold a Signal

Which sucks since people rely on the extension in the house and a few of our cameras rely on it as well. Overall, easy to set up, however, it doesn't work 100%. It's more evident to us since our camera system notifies us when 1 of our cameras loses signal. It happens regularly now. Initially it never dropped signal however, now it's a daily issue. And I know it's not my modem since I'm connected to it 8+ hours a day without signal drops. So I know it's the device that's the issue. Will likely switch to more popular brands like ASUS.

title: Little device; Big coverage!
text: Read Instructions carefully; after pairing, or creating an extended sub-network on your Wi-Fi, placing the NETGEAR Wi-Fi Range Extender EX6120 is critical, to get a maximum extension of the signal. Use the help of "Wi-Fi signal detector App." on your cell phone for this purpose. For printers and devices to sync on the same Wi-Fi network, you have to make sure all such devices, such as printers, video doorbells, video cameras, and such, are on the same sub-network to eliminate the delay in sync'ing, and to bypass the Internet as a route for such devices. title: This product just doesn't work! Try a different brand!
text:
I purchased this in hopes of extending the range of my router and I had done a lot of research and this one was on quite a few top lists of extenders. I went through the setup steps in the manual both using WPS and via a web browser. 2 different purchases! Save yourself the trouble, especially if you are not computer savvy.

1st attempt with extender #1: This is through the WPS route. I got it connected but I kept getting a "Connected without Internet" warning every so often. After going to the Netgear website, I found that the solution was to update the firmware. I attempted to do so, but somehow during the update it got stuck or corrupted and the power light just blinked red not stop. I sat on the phone for over an hour with support (and that was after half an hour on hold), which I could barely understand the technician, and being told to do a factory reset over and over again. (I tried this prior to calling them.)

They then wanted me to change my computer settings to give myself a static IP and other setting changes. I was not about to do that because I am not super knowledgeable in those settings and didn't want to mess with my personal computer. I had also read in the help section that sometimes they want to remote into my computer. Absolutely not! I just told them that I was on a work computer and did not have access to change those settings. After an hour, they told me that they would send me an email for instructions on how to send it back to Netgear and they would send me a replacement. A week later, I still did not get the email and I called them back. Another half-hour on the phone just to be told that I have to return it to Amazon since that is where I purchased it.

2nd attempt with extender #2: I got the replacement and went to set this up. Did it via web browser this time only to have it not work part way through the set-up procedures. I was following the directions, but when I got to the part where you connect to the new extender wifi, it stopped working. I could not navigate on the setup website any farther from here and just got a "You are not connected to your extender's WiFi network" even though my computer said I was. Stuck. I then did a factory reset and started the setup through WPS. Again, I got it connected, but "Connected without internet." I called support again as I was not about to try to do a firmware update and have it freeze again on me. After 34 min on hold, someone finally came on the line to help. Again, it was very hard for me to understand him. He went through the setup with me again and it seems to be working for now. If I have any further issues, I will update this review.

Please note that you have to register your device before you can get help. I accidentally typed in 2020 for the year on my replacement device and cannot change the date so I will not be able to get further help on that one. I had to submit a ticket for the 1st device to get help. The guy on the phone had no idea what I was talking about when I asked to have the purchase date updated.

If this product stops working like the first one, I will return it again and buy a different brand.

title: Excellent!
text: Great extender and very simple to setup. As others have stated I use this in my man cave which is my two car detached garage. My house is brick and my garage is brick so trying to get a strong signal to the garage was not possible without an extender. The setup was very simple, I used the option to setup through the Netgear site. The instructions were simple to follow and the setup took approximately 5 minutes. Initially, I set the extender in a bathroom closest to my garage, but a speed test showed not much gain. I then moved the extender to the garage and the difference was verified again through a speed test. Once the device is setup you have the option to connect to the extender through either a 2g or 5g connection. Obviously the 5g connection point yields better results. I am now streaming live TV in the garage so now on to the parties!

title: Connects to Wifi Network - No Internet Connection
text:
In September 2021 I purchased the Netgear AC1200 (EX 6120) through Amazon. Great delivery service as usual!
When configuring the AC1200 I ran into two problems.
1) The WPS light on the extender did not stay on and there was no clear answer of whether it should leading me to doubt whether that level of security was deployed.
2) Once connected to my existing WiFi network and setting up the two extender networks (2.4 and 5) the extension networks would not connect to the internet. I researched this issue for 2 hours and could not find a solution that worked. Also I did not want to perform brain surgery on my router to guess at a fix.
This device is supposed to be easy to install, but, more people than I have the same issues at set up. There must be a problem/trick with the AC1200 that greater minds than mine could figure out. For me, I just returned the item and will move onto a different product line.

title: Very good extender
text: Have tried others in the past and always ended up frustrated while trying to connect them. Read the directions and follow them, be patient while waiting and it is extremely easy to install. Plug in, make sure led is on, push second button, push button on router and wait. I was a little impatient and had to push twice before it connected.

title: Allows much better connection for Ring stick-up camera
text:
My outside driveway Ring camera was getting an RSSI value of -70, which is marginal and was causing degraded video. I installed this WI-FI extender in my garage, and the RSSI value for the camera went down to -40, which gave me perfect 1080P video. Connecting this device into my current WI-FI was challenging, but once I slowed down and followed the directions exactly, it gave me a second, extended, Wi-Fi signal, and my camera was able to connect to it perfectly. Some Wi-Fi routers have a WPA button that you can push which makes the installation super easy, but my router didn’t have that, so I had to follow a more involved setup procedure, but it all worked out fine once I followed the directions.

Edit after a few days use: Using it in the garage did not work. The Wi-Fi extender would overheat and lose the connection to the camera. This is during 95 degree heat outside. Moved the extender into the house and the problem was fixed, although the RSSI went to -60, but I was still producing perfect video.

I also found that there is no further setup required when moving the extender from outlet to outlet looking for the best signal. It just needs a few minutes to boot up and the camera automatically connects to it again.

I tried to contact the customer service through Netgear's website, guess what? It doesn't give a phone number or chat line or a way to email them.

Netgear always has problems and this is no exception. I tried both methods of set up, I even plugged an ethernet cord into the Wi-Fi extender and it still would not connect my Wi-Fi. I contacted customer support and they were extremely unhelpful they literally said and I quote "I don't know why it's not working". For the price here, I'd go for something else considering the fact that it's not cheap and if you need it for something like I needed it for, you need something reliable. title: WARNING - DON'T BUY
text: I have purchased 2 extenders in the last few weeks and had to return both because they were not able to connect to my router. I contacted Netgear and a talked with a 2 different techs. They told me that he could connect the unit for me so I gave him access to my computer over the internet. I was told that the extender would not connect because I had a security issue on my firewall. He told me if I would install Netgear software on my computer that the extender would then connect. I agreed to and paid $95.84 prior to having this issue corrected. They did not install Netgear software as stated... but, installed Webroot Antivirus Software which I could have purchased for a lot less online. The first tech that I talked with gave up and turned me over to another individual. After spending about 2 hours with 2 different Netgear techs, it was determined that the extender was not working properly and I was told to return it to the seller. I then told him that I wanted a refund of $95.84 which I paid earlier that evening through PayPal. The next day I received an email from PayPay that they refunded me $37.41. I contacted Netgear and they claimed that I would receive the full amount in a 3-4 days. Time will tell what will happen. If they don't refund the full amount, I will have file a formal complaint with my credit card company and have the charges reversed. I would not recommend anyone to do business with this company. Save yourself the time and trouble!

title: Great Product.  Solved years of struggling with streaming.
text: I had been trying for years to get my smart TV to stream movies via my router which was about 45 feet away. Any movies I tried to stream would take a very long time to load (if they loaded at all) and then would keep stopping or rebooting every few minutes. I had asked several technicians from major computer or network companies to help, but they were not able to improve the streaming. Then an independent technician doing some other work at my house suggested the Netgear AC 1200 Range Extender (EX6120). I ordered one, and after hooking it up and placing it between my router and TV, the movies all stream beautifully. No rebooting, no delays, no freezing up. It solved my problem immediately. (I had a bit of trouble figuring out how to connect the Netgear Range Extender the first time, but after a brief on-line chat with a Netgear technician, he walked me through the process easily). The Netgear Extender is small, unobtrusive and requires no wires or cables. It's great and I am extremely satisfied with it. I would certainly recommend it to others,

I thought maybe it needed to re-enter the password, so I went to the mywifiex.net site like I did before. This time a chat window opened and someone decided to have tech call me. title: Works Great and Easy Setup
text:
This is a great little Wi-Fi extender. The size of the device is very small and when plugged in is almost unnoticeable.

The performance of both the device itself and repeated connection is very good, and I personally liked the FastLane feature the best. I purchased this extender as I have a lot of 2.4GHz band interference at my house and my cameras only support the 2.4GHz band, using the FastLane feature I was able to connect to my router using 5GHz (which is way faster and has much less interference), and then use this device to repeat the signal as 2.4GHz, completely solving my issue and giving much better coverage without just causing more interference like a normal 2.4GHz to 2.4GHz repeater would.

If your Wi-Fi router is old and you are looking to extend it's coverage, I would probably just purchase a 2-pack Mesh router instead, but if you have a newer router and just need to extend coverage and don't need an upgrade, this device is perfect.

title: No way is it 5G bandwith

This proved that my original router was giving much better signal than this device will ever put out. Massive fail for an extender with supposed 5G bandwith capabilities!!! If there was something I was missing, I am certainly not dumpster diving through Netgear technical hoops to get there. Back it goes and will land in the hands of another extender newbie who writes a similar one star review. NEXT!!!

text: The installation was easy and worked.  When I located the new location for the extender I had 3 green lights (for power, contact to the router and contact to the devices).  After approximately 4 hours I had 2 green and one amber (power green, device green and router amber).  After another 4 hours I had 1 green, 1 red and one amber (power green, router red and device amber).  After another 4 hours I had 1 green, 1 blinking red and off and 1 red (power green, router red/off, device red).  I immediately pulled the unit out of the electrical socket, waited 10 seconds and plugged it back in and after it rebooted, I had 3 green.  The extender was placed approximately 20 feet from the router with no obstickles and the TV was approximately 10 feet from the extender separated by a glass patio door.  While the unit was showing 3 green, the TV signal was intermittent occasionally having picture freeze with a warning there was no internet connection.  To isolate the problem I bypassed the extender and connected directly to the router having no problems.  Again I pulled the extender out of the socket, plugged it back in and after rebooting it still showed 3 green.  That was four days ago and the unit has functioned as expected.  It took 2 days for the unit to work out it's squirieliness, but I'm still waiting for the other shoe to fall.  Not sure how long my luck will last.

title: Absolute Dogwater
text:
I used this device to extend the range of my wifi to the room with my PC. The router is in the living room, meaning there is exactly one (1) wall between the router and extender. My PC does not have a wifi card, so I purchased this extender to be able to use my ethernet cable. What a horrible decision that was!

Out of the box, the router never asked for a setup - it wanted a username and password, implying the product had been previously used (I tried using generic passwords such as "admin" and "password" to no avail). This would be okay, but I paid full price for a new unit, not a used one. I did multiple factory resets in an attempt to setup the device per the instructions, but the device never broadcast a setup SSID like the manual claimed it would. I then tried the WPS functionality, which did successfully connect to my router, but with god-awful speeds.

By placing my phone immediately next to the extender and connecting the wifi to my main router (NOT the extender) I received ~250Mbps download. My PC, which is connected to the extender by ethernet, receives anywhere between 10-15Mbps, roughly 5% of the same speed. Absolutely ridiculous.

title: DO NOT BUY ANYTHING FROM NETGEAR
text: I've bought 2 Netgear network extenders.  First, they are impossible to set up.  Once they are set up, they stop working after a few months.  If you go on their website, someone cheerfully offers to have someone from "tech support" call you, and they immediately do.  HERE'S WHERE THE SCAM BEGINS.  I had a Nighthawk 7000 extender.  I changed ISPs and needed Netgear's help setting it up.  A guy logged into my computer and said that I didn't have a good firewall, etc., and for the low price of $300 he could fix that and get the extender to work.  Stupidly, I paid it, and he did get it to work.  3 months later, I called with my "lifetime service guarantee" to get my extender working again, and I got the same B.S. story--$299 lifetime service.  Just to fix the extender would cost $99 which they'd guarantee for 90 days.  Now, neither of them work.  I threw them in the garbage and bought a different kind.  STAY AWAY!! STAY AWAY!!

title: Complete garbage. Don't waste your money.
text:
This thing is terrible. Right as you start, It requires an email and account to set up and get to the settings. It pretty much just has three settings 1. extend existing network (broadcast 2.4 and 5g) 2. Extend network connect via 5g and broadcast 2.4. 3. Extend network connect via 2.4 and broadcast 5g. After playing with all these settings, they are all function poorly and suffer from the same set of issues. The device frequently disconnects. The internet it provides is extremely slow and for some reason DNS resolution (Opening a new site via URL) is extremely slow! I'm talking 20 to 30 seconds slow. You can't turn off WPS which is a security vulnerability. The entire device is a disappointment and a waste of money.
Just buy a 50 foot cat6 cable and run it to whatever computer needs internet. At the end of the day it would be cheaper, easier, more reliable and less of a god awful headache than this device.

text:
This is an awesome device to spread wifi signals provided by a router to more distant areas of an interior space. It works flawlessly. Setup is a bit balky trying to get the configuration panel to open up, but once accessed, set up is just a few clicks and few keystrokes.

The device is very configurable. Its SSID can be turned on or off and the unit can be set up as either an extender or a hot spot. Its literature says it can either extend RJ-45 ethernet wired signals into wifi, or can feed wifi signals to an RJ-45 wired input. I did not test this as I have no such need.

I highly recommend this device.

title: Better than Nuthin
text: This extender is real easy to setup, but you have to be patient when it is installing the necessary files to connect to your wifi router. My biggest gripe is how often I have to reset the extender.

title: Good for the price
text: It worked but the signal in our house was choppy and we had to replace with mesh extender. This might work well for smaller spaces

title: Piece of Junk!
text: Doesn’t connect regardless of the method utilized in the very poorly written manual. You can only get support AFTER you’ve registered the device. Not worth your time!

title: Easy set up
text: It was a quick plug in and set the device up through my phone. Signal for my streaming has improved dramatically!

title: Spotty WiFi
text: I’ve had mine for over a month and the first week was amazing. I use this to extend my WiFi to the ring cameras on the farthest part of my house. After a week though, it will keep losing connection to the router sometimes multiple times throughout the day. Not worth the buy unless you’re home to keep troubleshooting, I’d get something else.

title: Could not hook up.
text:
Hey I bought this and tried over and over again to get it hooked up. But just couldn't So we called and got this guy on the phone and he told us he would help us out. He took over the computer and started out telling us we have a lot of people on our network. He can fi that with a program to stop people from getting into our network. I felt he was very pushy and kept asking us to buy this program.
He really made us fell uncomfortable. I kept asking if he was going to help us with the hook of the unit we have already bought? Sure after you buy this program. We just hung up and I sent the unit back to NET GEAR.
Very disappointed. I have a NET GEAR ROUTER and it works great. But for now NO MORE.

title: I am trying to use the EX6120 for my Samsung TV Internet connection.
text: I have tried to use the EX6120 Range extender. It works for a few hours, then it crashes and says it has no network connection. Sometimes the lights indicate the signal from the router is weak. My Router is about 20 feet from my TV. I located the extender about 15 feet from the router.  I have also relocated the extender next to the TV 20 feet from the router and 8 feet from the TV. Still a weak signal from the router. If I connect the TV internet by WiFi  from the router it works all of the time.  I have about 14 WiFi devices connected.  I have a wood framed house with two walls between the router and the TV. Maybe I got a bad one.

title: Does not support WPA3.  Use WPA/WPA2 on WiFi router.
text: Does not support WiFi mode WPA3 even with newest firmware.  If EX6120 is unable to connect to your router/internet, change the router's WiFi mode to WPA/WPA2.  C'mon Netgear -- it's 2023.  Get with it.

title: Easy to Set-up & Connect
text: After logging into NetGears Setup Page and making a password and 2 security questions I found it fairly simple and quick to get the AC1200 WiFi Range Extender to lock into my router.  I live in a mobile home and the WiFi connection in the living room where the router is located is fine but when you take your laptop or Ipad down to the other end of the trailer, in the bedrooms you lose  quite a bit.  On a lot of sites you would get a lot of buffering.  Once I put AC1200 in the back bedroom it was like having the router in the room.  Plus there are no cord connections, just plug it in the wall socket.  If I want to use an Ethernet Cable with my laptop in the bedroom there is an Ethernet Port on the side of the AC1200 Extender to plug into.  Some Extenders I reviewed before buying this one don't have that feature.  You can't go wrong with this model.  Works great.  And if your a member of Amazon Prime you'll get it in 2 days. Some Extenders I reviewed before buying this one don't have that feature.  You can't go wrong with this model.  Works great.  And if your a member of Amazon Prime you'll get it in 2 days.  I did.After logging into NetGears Setup Page and making a password and 2 security questions I found it fairly simple and quick to get the AC1200 WiFi Range Extender to lock into my router.  I live in a mobile home and the WiFi connection in the living room where the router is located is fine but when you take your laptop or Ipad down to the other end of the trailer, in the bedrooms you lose  quite a bit.  On a lot of sites you would get a lot of buffering.  Once I put AC1200 in the back bedroom it was like having the router in the room.  Plus there are no cord connections, just plug it in the wall socket.  If I want to use an Ethernet Cable with my laptop in the bedroom there is an Ethernet Port on the side of the AC1200 Extender to plug into.  Some Extenders I reviewed before buying this one don't have that feature.  You can't go wrong with this model.  Works great.  And if your a member of Amazon Prime you'll get it in 2 days. title: Easy setup, doesn't support IPv6, not compatible with some phones.
text:
At first everything went as expected. The install was quick and set up two additional WiFi networks as the manual indicated. Unfortunately only one of them would actually bridge to my Xfinity dual band 802.11ac XB3 cable modem. After playing around with different settings it became clear that this was either a limitation of the device or my cable modem and could not be easily worked around. Never the less, I was able to connect my phone to one of the networks and it worked, sort of. The speed was sub par, 4Mbps vs 200Mbps over direct connection, but enough to communicate and stream mobile quality video to a single device. It does not support IPv6 however, so many of my usual speed test sites were unavailable. Even still, when forced to use the same sites, the speed tests were consistently bad over the extender network. To top of off, my wife's phone a newer One Plus 5G phone, doesn't seem to be able to connect at all.

I generally like the quality of Netgear hardware, but this seems to be from the Windows Vista era or something because it doesn't seem to be compatible with relatively newer hardware in inexplicable ways and functions at early 2000s speeds.

title: Easy to set up
text: I tried another brand of wifi extender that I couldn't get to work with my Netgear router so I decided to try with a Netgear extender.  I was surprised to get it set up in short order using the "connect with WPS" method. I have a cement block wall between my primary router and the rest of the house. I could get the signal near the wall but it fell off considerably as I got further away. The EX6120 extender has changed all that. I can now stream video anywhere in the house and the basement, where I had no signal at all. I just read in the instruction book that the extender can be used in "Access Point Mode" by connecting it directly to the LAN with the Ethernet port on the Extender. I'll probably try this method next. I assumed that the Ethernet port on this device was solely for connecting an Ethernet- enabled device, like a TV or Blu-ray player. Connecting directly to the main router should get an even stronger signal throughout the house. So far, I really like the way this helps with extending the wifi where I need it.

title: Not overly impressed
text: 1200 mbps? No. That’s absolutely not true. I’d be surprised if this device could handle more than 125 mbps honestly. Even right next to the router, it was barely pulling 70 mbps (I have 400 mbps internet from spectrum) the same network without the extender gets in the 300/400’s in the same place for perspective. However due to the thickness of my walls and distance, my bedroom Wi-Fi suffers dramatically with only delivering 40/50 mbps. This device boosted the 40/50 I was getting into 70/80. So, does it work? Yes. Does it work anywhere near what they advertise it as? No. If you don’t have a super fast network, this might be ideal for you. I didn’t expect to have the full 300/400 carry but to not even hit 1/4th the speed even when 2 ft away from the router was disappointing. Install was fairly easy but I ran into some issues with it only wanting to split the 2 G network into a 2 and a 5 instead of duplicating the 2 and 5 G networks my router already has. I had to manually go in via device IP and set the network preferences manually but it was very doable. The range extender web address they give you is garbage (at least it was for me) and wasted most of my time I spent setting the thing up. BUT just log into your router and pull the IP and punch that into a browser and you’ll be golden. For the price, I guess it’s acceptable. I just didn’t expect it to be quite this mediocre 🤷🏻‍♂️

title: What a deal!
text: Bought used for $20. What a deal! Didn't come with instructions, but was super easy to set up. Plugged in to the outlet, waited for the amber power light to turn green, pressed WPS on my router then WPS on the range extender. Took a couple of tries but once the router light on the extender lights up for a second, the pairing is finished. Unplugged the extender, took it into the room I wanted to use it in, plugged it back in and the router light lit up and I was good to go. All of these reviews with people saying the tech support was terrible obviously didn't know what they were doing when setting the device up.

title: Great, for desperate connections
text:
Overall Positives: Okay, I'm not going to lie, this is great for something like a basement connection, or third floor where there's NO connection or basically unusable connection. I'm using this in our guest room as we have a media console in there and its network connection to our normal router was painfully slow. Unable to even watch Netflix. This extender honestly works great for that.

Setup: Super easy, but I expected nothing else from a WPS setup. Any device that is WPS should be easy to configure. I haven't been able to get the network configuration page to work, even following the directions. The page says I'm not connected to the extender, but I am, and I have an outward-facing connection, so I'm not sure what that's about.

Reliability: Had some issues reconnecting once when we restarted our primary router. Simply unplugging and restarting this extender resolved the issue, but it's still an issue, it should be able to handle that. Its range is honestly ridiculous. I have a connection to the darn thing from 2 floors above it (with it in the basement during my testing, my desktop picked up its connection with full bars.)

Speed: This is why I'm writing this review... Everything else has been great, but don't fall for the false advertising on the speeds. We have a ridiculously fast network in our house over 500 mb/s down, which is ridiculous for our area. I only get 50 mb/s down on a good day with this extender. Remember, for a desperate, fast connection, this is amazing. Some people don't even have networks that fast, but they claim 1200 mb/s transfer, and it's nowhere near, and yes, my system and network are capable of testing that. I thought perhaps it was a connection or range issue, so I tested this in three different areas of my house, dramatically different areas. This included different floors, at different ranges and connection quality. It's consistent in it's speed, so that's good, maybe?

Overall, this is a decent purchase if you need something small and simple to tuck away in a corner, but if you need something to replace or extend your current network speeds, and want more than 10% of your home network, might want to look elsewhere.

title: OMG FINALLY got this to work!!!
text: Use the WSP button, if you have it on your router. If you have your router from a cable provider, you will probably have to enable it on the router first. Call your internet provider for assistance. Factory reset may be needed before setup. Plug in extender in same room/close to router, wait for green on power and signal. Press and hold WSP button on router for 3 seconds, then press WSP on netgear. If you do not have WSP on your router, will need to select extender from wifi list (your wifi name_ ext), once connected, open browser and go to "192.168.1.250" follow setup instructions. Move extender to final location and power up. Make sure signal light is green (excellent signal), or minimally yellow (fair). Side note: I got new windows that have a coating that limits wifi transmission. If you need signal outside and excellent/good inside but poor/no signal outside, open window/retest. Found this to be the problem. Moved extender to garage/now good signal outside. 😁

title: Not Mac Friendly - Not For Me Anyway
text:
Bought this device upon recommendation of ADT phone support, who stated I needed a second extender in my 1030 sq ft. home! System also covers two outbuildings within feet of the main home. The same CSR tendered more dis-info on other issues as well.

ADT had installed an identical Netgear EX6120 Extender during a recent system upgrade - many glitches due to improper setup I came to find out.

Only a very basic setup was achieved that failed to fully integrate the security system and EX6120 Extender. The Netgear Genie app failed to function properly (constant spinning wheel of death). Netgear's www.mywifiext.net setup page failed to function by stating 'couldn't find server' or 'can't find Netgear device'. Unable to confirm and update firmware as a result.

Netgear Support responded with nothing useful. The EX6120 appears to be an older device relying on older firmware/software - perhaps a newer device will work properly with a newer Mac OS.

ADT Tech came back out yesterday to re-set up the new Command/Control system with only one EX6120 Extender - this guy (has Windows based work laptop) made the original one work and advised to send the other one back to Amazon for a refund.

New ADT Security System now works properly as it should have from day one.

Update 10/29/21: Read through many of the reviews here. Can access Netgear Genie 'device setup' webpage on an iPhone Xr and iPad Air 2 but not on my iMac or Mac Book Pro. Can update Firmware using iPhone but not the iPad Air 2, and then only on one EX6120 (garage) and not the other EX6120 device (ADT connected).

Keeping the updated device primarily for use by my automobiles that update over home wifi - WPS worked correctly with connecting my cars the the Netgear device. ADT coming back out next week to fix another glitch - will ask him about the non updated device that is connected to my home security system.

I even tried moving it to within 10 feet of my wifi router and the red light would still come on. I tried changing wifi channels and it still has trouble. The first few months all seemed well, but after about 9 months I noticed devices connected through this extender would often show as offline. My cell phone now lists the extender as an "Unreliable Source." It's really a shame Netgear can't figure this stuff out by now. The 1500 Sq Ft coverage refers to an empty outdoor field. My ISP provided wifi router / modem in the basement covers more area than this extender that is plugged in upstairs.

text: I live in a rural area and am using a Netgear LAX20 LTE router which covers most of my small house pretty reliably. I bought this extender mainly to use its Ethernet port to connect a smart lighting bridge since I already have one hooked up to my router and outlets in that area are scarce. I set it up via WPS, and at first I thought it wasn’t working but found that I just had to give it a little time for the lights to start flashing and setup was seamless from there. The lighting system I have running through it works flawlessly, and I tested out the connection with my laptop and it was just about as fast as my normal connection with the router. Another huge bonus, this extender gave me an easy way to be sure my phone is connected to the 2.4GHz band and my Nanoleaf light panels, which were once very finicky, have been working perfectly ever since.

title: Follow the instruction sheet
text:
If you have any other range extenders unplug them. Take this new device and put it in the same room as your wi-fi router.
Wait until two light on left front are illuminated. Go to router and push WPS button. Go to extender (with 15 seconds) and push its WPS button. When they do a handshake the LED on the top left of the range extender will light up.

Now move the range extender to the room you need additional coverage. Fire up a wi-fi device (computer, iPad, smart phone, etc.) and watch for the LED on the right front to light up. This means your device is working through the range extender.

Afterwards you can plug in the additional range extenders, but I found this dual band device gave me better coverage than the (3) 2.4Ghz extenders that we had working with our old cable modem/wifi device. All this may sound complicated, but it is not. Go for it.

This extender was easy to install and set up, but it continued to have problems staying locked onto my WiFi network over the course of a work day (I work online from home). It’s only 15 feet from my WAP, which is putting out a strong signal. Call quality via Skype was also occasionally impaired implying to me that it’s dropping packets. I moved the repeater 5-feet away from my home WAP, and still had issues. It also runs very hot. Eventually I logged into the Extender and was promoted to download new firmware. The extender would then not boot up. Apparently this is a common problem that even a hard reset doesn’t fix. I could not get through to customer service after trying for over an hour.

All in all, a very bad experience with this particular extender. I ended up purchasing a NetGear Model EX7500 and initial tests are pretty impressive with regards to coverage, but I haven’t had a chance to spend an 8-hour day working via the extender.

Setup was easy.  It makes a copy of your current wifi settings and broadcasts BLAHBLAHext.  I hooked the computer to the LAN port and that's how I am using it.  In fact, I have another computer I need to hook up alongside this one.  When I do that, I will put a network switch between the pc's and this device.  I know it will slow down the throughput, but I build workstations, test and then deploy.  My side office was not meant for this so they overlooked data connections.  This allows me to test and even download some stuff to configure and deploy.  I was looking for something faster than the Edimax 150 usb that I have, yet keep it low cost.  This seems to fit the bill!  Add that it has the LAN port allowing me to connect multiple computers, bonus.
