title: No joy for Airport Express users
text:
If you're a Mac customer who routs wirelessly via Airport Express, prepare to be disappointed by this product's claims of universal compatibility. I had to return it.

Even though Netgear had a paucity of negative reviews from Mac users, and their video actually featured Apple products, I just couldn't get the Netgear Range Extender to work, regardless of how many times I tried: it never connected to my Airport Express router and always defaulted to being a wi-fi access point instead of a wi-fi extender--useless to me. When I did get it to work, my download speed was under 1.00 Mbps. (That's not a typo.) Maybe that's idiosyncratic, but the on-line setup for Mac users was also not good: about halfway through the setup process, I was taken back to the first page to start again, and I took multiple attempts inputting the same information before I was allowed to complete the setup—which, as it turned out, was completely to no avail anyway. After hours of trying, I gave up and re-boxed it. At least returning it for a refund was trouble-free.

This past year, Apple officially announced it will discontinue development of Airport wi-fi products, so I'll eventually need to buy a third-party router anyway. At that point, I may purchase a compatible range extender as well. For now, I encourage other Airport Express users either to wait till they need a new router, or to bite the bullet and just get a second Airport Express to extend their network. It may work for you, as some Mac reviewers have stated. Or, it may not, which was my experience. May the odds be ever in your favor.

title: Great Low Cost Wifi Extender - UPDATED
text:
UPDATE: Adding these and trying to set up as a mesh did not work so well. Having two set up seemed to cause interference also, they aren't made to create a mesh network. Might have worked better with different network IDs, but then you're just constantly changing networks manually to get a signal. Unfortunately, they don't keep connection with the main router through walls or floors well, so the router drops quite often. I get the feeling these would only work well with line of site, but that kind of defeats the purpose. For a cheap extender, it might work well in an apartment or small house, but not anything larger. I just ordered a Netgear Orbi RBK50 unit, should do what I need.

I picked up two of these for my house (3 stories) and use with a Netgear N600 dual band router. Works pretty good, although in all honesty I only bought it for my video doorbell. My router is on the 3rd floor in a cabinet (obvious problem, I know) and the doorbell is on the 1st floor (duh - most of the time). I hadn't bought one of these before the doorbell, I had thought about it to get better WiFi outside, but that kind of defeats the purpose of being outside.

Setup is a breeze, just plug in to the wall, go to mywifiext.net or use the Netgear app (I just used the web). I set up the first on on my laptop, second on an iPad. Pretty sure it can be done on a cell phone too, maybe I'll try that when I reconfigure the second unit I have.

Once you're logged to to the Netgear site, setup is very straightforward. Most will add as an extender, it will search for available networks, pick your WiFi and move on. I named the extender networks the EXACT same as the main router (basic mesh network) so devices shouldn't be stuck on one extender or router, it should pick up the strongest signal while you move around the house. So far it has worked well, although I bet devices which are advertised as mesh networks would work much better, but are more expensive.

Again, I primarily bought this for my new video doorbell (SimpliSafe) because the doorbell doesn't have a very strong antenna and signal. I had to add the extender for it to work properly. I also recently added smart dimmer switches and sprinkler system controller, so I guess it helps those also.

I did a speed check and it wasn't great, but neither was the receive/transmit signal from the router. Bottom line, this device should give you a great network around the house, but likely won't work well if you have multiple users pulling lots of data at once.

Would definitely purchase again if needed.

title: Returned it about 45 minutes after I opened it
text: Right off the bat, anything that requires you register an email, personal information and your password on the manufacturer's website in order to *access* and *manage* the device you just bought (you own it now) is an immediate show stopper.  Luckily, with most Netgear setups you can simply replace change the setup URL with "/start.htm" and set everything up manually (for the most part.)  The first thing I noticed is this doesn't work in a bridged mode (i.e. simply repeating the signal and same SSID) so you can roam between radios w/o having to reconnect.  Another 'no go' for me.  Instead, in "extender" you will configure another SSID and password so that if you find yourself getting a weak signal from your main Access Point you can switch to the extender.  I have been designing computer networks for 2 decades and it should not take me more than 25 minutes to get a home consumer repeater up and running.  It took almost 2 hours of messing with this device to get it usable only to find out the there is a significant delay when my devices (laptop, home attendant, etc) use the extender.  It may not sound like much but there is a consistent 1-3ms delay reponse time from the extender when doing something as simple as going to a website.  This delay does not occur with the actual access point itself.  1-3ms delay network-wise is significant. I really do not have the patience to go into all the short comings of this device because the list is lengthy in my opinion.

text:
First, the "issues": Setup is not particularly easy. It's not as simple as pressing the WPS buttons on it and the router. As far as I can tell, that completely failed to do anything at all. I ended up Connecting to it via wifi, and going through the setup screens.

After that, I ran into a problem where the 5GHz connection kept showing "no internet". As far as I can tell, this was because my router uses the same SSID for 2.5GHz and 5GHz, and the range extender can't handle that correctly. When I changed the 2.5GHz connection to extend the "guest" SSID, everything was fine.

Also, when I attempted to update the firmware, it completely failed to recognize the file downloaded from Netgear. Never did figure out what the deal was there.

However, once I got past those setup issue, it seems to work just fine. Definitely getting a better signal in all areas of the house.

title: Great Signal Booster
text: Working flawlessly with my FIOS Quantum router. 5 stars for making it seamlessly work without a pain to set it up. Open the box, plug it in, press WPS on Router -- BOOM.

title: Passes
text: Works great. No issues.

title: Great coverage
text: Amazing booster. It has taken my hot spot to a completely different level. I get service across all of my home. Only small problem would be to tell you when you try to connect to the extender and set it up that you should connect on your computer directly to the extender first to set it up and not to your WiFi. But it works now and does great.

title: Setup nightmare
text: I'm somewhat tech savvy and even so, this was way more complicated to setup than expected. The instructions were useless as the links provided weren't even in existence at this point in time. Somehow though, I was able to connect it through trial and error with a little bit of logic (something that the user manual lacks).

title: Just Okay for me
text: Works but not fully what I expected because the throughput seems to be significantly less strong even at close range.  Using my house wiring is easily just as fast and sometimes faster.  I will keep it just in case I need to move it easily.

title: Unobtrusive range extender
text: Works really well.  Setup worked but it was hard to tell it was working which led me to repeat setup once, and when plugged in at new spot it can take a few mins to get established. Overall very satisfied with this unobtrusive range extender.

title: Terrible Unit - Cuts speed to nearly zero
text:
I had a terrible time installing this simple device. My router is a Symantec Core unit and it does not have a WPS button. Therefore I had to access the device on line. I bought it to use as a Access Point but I was never able to set it up as one because the website that is needed to set up the Access Point is not available when the Access Point is being set up which is crazy and very frustrating. So I finally gave up and set it up as an extender. I was able to do this using my phone. I was never able to do so using my computer.

As an extender this device is worthless. First the signal doesn't carry very far. But far worse, the speed is chopped to nearly zero. When I first set it up it seemed extremely slow so I decided to check it. I brought it into my office where I have several computers set up, and in close proximity to the router. I have machines that are Ethernet connected and wireless connected. Using the Ookla speed test, I checked my wired computers, my wireless computer and the wireless computer going through the extender. I got speeds in the range of 110-120 Mbps down and 11-15 Mbps up with the Ethernet connected machine. I got speeds in the 30-35 Mbps down and 8-10 Mbps up with the wireless machine. Going through the extender, I only got a reading of about 1 Mbps down and nothing up. I tried testing several times using different hubs and the results were similar.

I learned several things doing these tests. First, this extender is worthless, both as an access point (which I couldn't make it be) or as an extender as the throughput was terrible. Unfortunately I learned this too late to return the device. I also learned that my Symantec Core Router is definitely not worth the premium price I paid for it. I should be getting much better speeds with wireless than I am seeing. Live and learn I guess.

text:
This product has given less connectivity frustrations and headaches. It's been in use for over a year now and I haven't one bad thing to say about it. The product has extended beyond any expectations initially had. It's sturdy, sleek and small enough to hide behind a piece of furniture and still work flawlessly.The white is still white and I was for sure it would start to yellow as some plastic made products do. Easy to wipe down or dust. In the last year of use, there were satellite upgrades, therefor the range extender needed to be reset and re-set up, there were no issues, simple and quick. Have recommended to family and friends. If I needed to I would buy again and if not for myself for a gift.

Living in a bi-level 5500 square foot home can cause internet coverage inconsistencies. After almost a year's worth of frustration with the quality of service from the provider, decided to purchase 2 Netgear Boosters. The combination of the two boosters give excellent coverage all the way up to a small finish area of a third floor finished attic office. Absolutely impressed with the end result.

title: Started great, ended as fire hazard
text: Received this in December 2017.  Was an easy install for anyone who has had any experience setting up a router.  And it worked great as advertised.  I did not have drops like a lot of people reported.  Unfortunately what I did have in July 2018 after 7ish months of use was a burning smell coming from it.  As you can see from the picture, the unit was starting to burn up and melt down.  I have used the wall outlet it was on for various things, and have never had an issue.  The item was plugged in appropriately and never removed or messed with.  This could have burnt my house down.

title: Good at extending a network - but has some flaws
text:
I got this range extender to work in conjunction with my Nighthawk router to give full coverage throughout the house since there were some dead spots previously.

The good - it does provide the additional range I needed

The bad - constant switching between networks, lots of latency on extended network

I ended up having to "forget" the extended networks so my devices wouldn't automatically connect to them. If I need to use the extended area, I will just tap into directly and not "remember" it since it is so annoying for devices to bounce between that often and I notice the change in quality.

title: Big Disappointment
text: I had real high hopes this would work in extending the wifi to our back deck where the signal is weak. Setting this up was pretty simple using the WPS buttons on the extender and my router, which by the way is also a Netgear product. In the same room as the router the extender showed a strong connection to my router (green router light) so I know it is recognizing my router and connecting to it. I even tested a connection to a device (Roku) and it worked fine. Here's where things went south. When I moved it to the furthest wall in our home from the router which is only about 20 feet away with very few obstructions along the way, the extender starts off with a green router light indicating it has a strong connection. My bubble was bursted quickly as within a few minutes the light went amber then red indicating a poor signal. My cell phone when put in the same exact spot receives a very strong signal when connected to my wifi. So why not the extender?  I tried moving it closer to the router only to get the same results. Ultimately I had to put it within 5 feet of my router to get the router light to stay green. Anything beyond that seemed to result in a poor connection. I tried moving my router to a more open area in hopes that would help. Results were the same. I spent a lot of time troubleshooting in vain ending up with the same results (and a lot of frustration). I really thought this would work great especially given my router is the same brand. But only being able to place it 5 feet from my router to get a good connection renders this pretty useless to me. I am therefore returning it and will do further research for a product that may be better. A big disappointment!

title: Little maintenance is required once it is setup and installed.
text: I have used many access points, range extenders in my career and I will have to say, NetGear makes the better one these days.  I replaced all my TP-link range extenders in the past couple of years with the AC1200, as its a good unit.  I have also installed the AC1200 into several family/friends homes to boost their home networks.  They ask me with device to purchase, I told them to get the AC1200 and I will setup and install.  I like the fact that these units tend to be maintenance free, once I setup, spec and install, the most that the users have to do is unplug and plug back in to reset the device.

Never.

When I was buying this I was offered a lower price one from Amazon which stated that it would be as normal but there would be a dent in the box in the upper left corner. There was, but otherwise everything looked fine. However, when setting up became far more difficult than the instructions and YouTube videos led me to believe I realized that this was a returned product that had already been linked to someone else’s WiFi. Because of that it refused to connect to my WiFi. It took a couple factory resets but I was able to get it to work as it should. However, I think I’m pretty good with technology and I think for someone who maybe isn’t this could be a huge road block. That being said, the actual product itself works great! The only hookup for internet in my house is in my guest room which is on the complete opposite side of my house. I couldn’t lay in bed in my bedroom and connect to WiFi. I now have a super strong signal and can be on my phone and watch Netflix in my bedroom. Definitely worth the money.

title: It solved my problem, works great!
text:
I previously bought a cheaper NetGear wifi extender from Amazon and seemed happy with it for a little while but this summer when I really needed it to work well on my patio/in my yard it was seriously sucking. That device differed from this one in two ways, it was only about $30 and it did not have antennas on it. I just installed this one yesterday and not only was it incredibly easy to install (plug in, push the WPS button, push the WPS button on my Comcast router, open Settings on my iphone, select the extender, enter in my existing wifi password, DONE) and it works GREAT. Where I once had 2 spotty bars on my patio (which is right on the other side of the wall where the extender was plugged in) I now can roam my .14 acre yard with full bars which is perfect for cutting down on my data usage when I'm streaming Sirius or whatever.

I'm giving my old one away to a family member who (I Hope) finds it useful. It did work great in the house but then again, my regular wifi did too so being that it didn't work well outside, it didn't really work for me.

title: It works but there are compromises.
text: I think as far as extenders go maybe this is a "middle of the road" device. I purchased this one after returning the N300 model. I kept his one but I'm still not totally satisfied. This device drastically reduces the WiFi speed....about 50% which is actually MUCH better than the N300 which reduced it by about 80%. The range is weird too. Some areas have a great signal and others not so much. It would seem that simply going upstairs directly above the device would be a good signal but it's spotty at best. You really have to seek out the sweet spots with this. It's definitely not like the diagram represents...full coverage in an arcing pattern. Bottom line is you have to be willing to compromise some speed if you want to use this to extend the range of your WiFi. It does do the job but it leaves me wanting more. Guess I'll need to throw down the BIG $$$$ on the next one!

Save your money and don't buy this if you expect to pass through 5Ghz.

text: The purpose of this range extender was to reach Wi-Fi capable smoker / grill.  This had to be done on the 2'2 G band. ( we also tried the 5 G band). The range extender was plugged in at a location where the primary signal from the router was still reasonably strong (4 out of 5 bars).  The smoker / grill is positioned outside about 20 feet from said range extender.  This did require the signal to go through a frame exterior wall.  We were successful in getting the Wi-Fi signal to communicate with the smoker at a 2 to 3 bar level, which appears to be the minimum requirement for the system to work.  The purpose of this setup is to provide the ability to monitor and control the smoker remotely via a cell phone app.

title: More Than Meets the Eye
text:
I don't use this as a Wi-Fi extender - I use it as a Wi-Fi to Ethernet bridge and it works exceptionally well in that role - especially as it can be locked to 5 GHz and you can disable wireless rebroadcasting.

With this device, instead of multiple devices (e.g. TV, Roku, Xbox, etc.) in the family room all using Wi-Fi, they are connected to a gigabit Ethernet switch which then connects to this device which uses just one Wi-Fi link for all of the devices instead of creating additional congestion on the network.

Is it perfect? No. A physical cable would be much closer to perfect.

Does it get the job done? Yes, absolutely and I wouldn't hesitate to purchase another one in the future to meet this need. I can report that this device has not needed rebooting or any additional support - like the old infomercial says, "set it and forget it".

title: It works pretty well, almost too well
text: It works pretty well, almost too well. In extender mode it took over my parent's network and I had to reset their router. The initial setup was clunky because I couldn't get my family off their phones/tablets. Whichever device the setup screen came up on first is the device I had to use to configure this. Imagine yelling at 5/8/12 year olds "WHOSE IPAD SCREEN JUST CHANGED" and it ended up being my mom's iphone. In the end I decided to use it in access point mode at my brother's shop instead to broadcast a new wifi signal. This product almost seems too complex for simply extending a signal. Older variations of extenders from trendnet I've used were much easier to set up.

title: Great Product, Works as Advertised -- Did have a Problem Setting Up -- UPDATED SETUP INSTRUCTIONS
text:
UPDATED - See New Setup Instructions Below:

Overall this extender works as advertised. I was able to extend our router signal to the opposite side of our house with a strong signal (our Fire TV Stick always responds with a "Very Strong" wireless signal). Our wifi Blink Outside Cameras at the opposite of the side of the house also work great. Note: the Extender is picking up signal thru 3 walls.

I did have an issue with initial setup -- the app to perform setup (mywifiext.net) could not be found when setting up with my desktop (Windows 10, Chrome, Edge or Firefox). I tried clearing cache several times and never got it working with any of these browsers.

So I tried setting up with my iPhone and it worked great. I did a factory reset on the Netgear Extender, turned on Wifi on my iPhone and "Bam" their was the Extender App ready for setup!

Very happy with the product and will purchase another soon for another part of our house.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Purchased an N300 in November 2019 and read the instructions. Much easier setup:

New Setup Instructions:

Much easier setup (took the time to read the instructions). Per the documentation included with the extenders:

Connect with WPS:

Plug the WIFI extender into an outlet as close to your modem (router) as possible.

Wait for the WIFI extender Power Light to turn Solid Green (takes a few seconds).

Press the WPS button on the side panel of the WIFI extender. The WPS LED blinks.

Within two minutes, press the WPS button on your modem (router) or access point. When the WIFI extender connects to your network, the WPS LED on the WIFI extender lights solid green and your router Link LED lights. If it doesn’t work, try it again.

Unplug the WIFI extender and move it to a location that is about halfway between your router and the area with poor WIFI signal.

Plugin the WIFI extender and wait for the Green Power LED and Router LED to light. If the Router LED doesn’t light Amber or Green, plug the WIFI extender into an outlet closer to the router and try again.

On your computer or WIFI device, find and connect to the new extended WIFI network.

It’s that simple!

After a slight bit of frustration with an older model and more research, I chanced on this one. The other crashed our internet and did not have a strong signal; this is because our router was too new for it to run well.
This one works fine. Once you get over the meticulous button pressing for setup and connecting via your browser, you're basically set for good. I've had it for almost half a year with no problems.
I knocked off a star because sometimes the LED indicators will flash red despite not showing any problems with my devices. Additionally, it's not a miracle; the signal will still peter out now and then, usually when traffic is overloaded or the weather is harsh, especially on my phone. However, my PS4 is at peak performance and I use it as my main entertainment center, so that's what matters most.

Really great item if you're having the issues I had. Solving these problems can be incredibly frustrating, and this extender made it a little less so.

title: Works fine as extender but there are a few gotchas . . .
text:
As an extender it does a good enough job. It was very easy to set up using the router's WPS. I estimate it delivers a usable signal for ~100 ft, but of course that is very dependent on its locn vis-a-vis the router, the antenna positioning on both devices, and the locns of your client devices.

But there are several potential issues to be aware of that aren't mentioned in the mktg info or manual. The first one is brought up in the Q&A section above, which IMO you should read before buying: The extender will create a new SSID so any device using the extended network will need to use this SSID. That may be fine if your device(s) is in a fixed locn, but if it's a mobile device you should check whether your device will automatically hand-off from one SSID to another, will at start-up look for the strongest wifi signal (so it may choose the router or the extender signal, depending on where you are), and just whether or not you want your mobile device to use more than one SSID (e.g., my iPhone 6S is strong enough to use the router's signal throughout the house, so I configured it to use that SSID only).

Second, if you are using more advanced techniques with your router, be aware that the router will actually create two clients as the extender, not just one. You'll see in your logs that the extender's mac address is used for the initial hand-shake and authorization, but it is not assigned an IP address. There will be a second virtual (pseudo) mac address too which will then be authorized at the same time and it will be assigned an IP by the router's DHCP server. So 1 extender client using 2 mac's, but only 1 IP. Furthermore, any device connected to the extender will not use its native hardware mac address, but again a pseudo mac address, although it will obtain its IP from the router DHCP server as normal. So if you are e.g. using mac filtering or IP address assignment by mac address, you need to use the pseudo mac addresses for the extender's clients. If your device uses both the router and extender SSID's, you'll need both native and pseudo mac addresses in your router tables and provision in your IP address pool for 2 addresses, 1 for each mac address.

Third, and while this issue is admittedly obscure, it's still a possibility: The extender's signal can interfere with other devices. I have a Roku3 with a remote that I is spec'd to use "WiFi Direct" technology rather than IR or Bluetooth. I wanted the extender to service the Roku, my Samsung smart tv, and my Chromecast. But while I can use it for the Chromecast and tv (caveat, see next issue below), not the Roku. Fortunately, the Roku has a strong wifi transceiver so it can use the router's signal instead (another option might be to use a smartphone app to control the Roku which might permit putting it on the extender, but haven't tested that yet - again, see below).

Finally, note that some smart apps indicate that the mobile device using the app must be on the same network as the device being controlled. So if you have a device you are controlling from your smart phone, it's definitely possible that the phone must be on the same SSID as that device. All three of my devices may work off the extender using a smart phone app rather than the provided remote, but it is highly likely that to do so will require putting the phone on the extender's SSID.

So the bottom line is, this extender works very well as long as your location, devices, network configuration, and router all cooperate with what you want to do. If the configuration and usage characteristics such as described above are not an issue, it will probably serve you well.

title: Just what I was MISSING!!!!
text: Living in Manhattan you get use to things not always working right and as I didn't need wi-fi for work it's speed was never a real issue because as a restaurant manager I never would bring my work home. Then 5 years ago I lost half my right foot, then the following year after that I lost my left leg below the knee...now I'm home all the time and watch more TV than ever and I'm online more than ever, and trying to keep bills inline (cable in Manhattan is OUTRAGEOUS...triple play $170.. and I only have 1 box). I started looking into ways to save money and last year a friend gave me an APPLE TV and hooked it up for me and everything but my biggest problem was buffering....it made me not want to watch the damn thing (I had netflix on my PS3 and didn't use it for the same reason). I didn't want to move my home computer and equipment from my office where I have everything because I didn't want to over crowd and already overcrowded living-room. I had looked at getting a Range Extender for quite sometime but kept putting it off and thought it might be I just needed a new Router so I replaced that first and it helped but not enough, then someone told me I really needed to get a range extender SO I did a lot of research and decided on Netgear (which had been recommended by a few friends) this helped in SO many ways. One thing I didn't realize was that between all the wired and wireless equipment and overlapping signals and neighbor's wi-fi signals and cable company's hot-spot signals it was slowing me down (it's what happens when you live with 8 million other people). SO after following the instructions (I use to be Tech savvy then I got lazy in the early 2000's and having lots of friends in their 20's I just had people do it for me) Now I'm on a I need to learn this stuff and at 51 it's so easy after you get the hang of it.This was SO easy to set up just take your time and read the manual and it only took me about 10 minutes, I took my time and by the end of the night I had hooked everything up and changed all my passwords (make sure you write everything down and put in a safe place the last thing you want to do is forget these passwords) The first thing I noticed was how fast and responsive my tablet had become then I noticed that my APPLE TV and PS3 had become faster and guess what...NO BUFFERING, it has been nice watching shows during prime time and not have to wait for a signal, and as great as this is I do plan on getting another extender for even faster service, I like the fact that I'll be able to plug my Apple TV right into the extender and having that wired connection is always better {to me} and the extender is not in a spot where I want to run a cable (I'm also getting a new cable modem to save more money on my cable bill {$96.00}...I now love my range extender  and wish I had gotten one a couple of years ago I'm sure I would have saved several hundred dollars by now. I now plan on getting rid of my triple play and just going with Super hi speed internet...between Tivo, Range Extenders, Netflix, Hulu, a digital phone service and a HD antenna I could be able to save $800-$900 dollars a year. I love my range extender so much I think I may give a few as gifts this year...great job Netgear!...THANKS!!!

title: Great way to give your business/home emergency backup internet services
text:
I typically recommend these units to people who have equipment with Ethernet jacks but without WiFi. What you can do is use this unit to link your wired equipment into your wireless network. To do this you simply configure this unit to connect to your wireless network then use a network cable (Ethernet cable) to connect your equipment to this unit. Instant network access for whatever you want. Just be aware the bandwidth isn't going to be equal to cable connectivity.

Now a use which isn't widely known is the ability to use this for backup internet connectivity in some cases. NOTE I SAID SOME CASES. What you'll need is a router with a WAN port that normally connects to a modem, or other device, which provides internet access. If you have this - a router with a WAN port - then you can do the following to provide emergency internet backup for your entire network:

1) Configure your cell phone to be a mobile hotspot.
2) Configure this unit to connect to your cell phone's mobile hotspot via WiFi.
3) Plug an Ethernet cable into this unit.
4) Plug the other end of the Ethernet cable into your router's WAN port. No not LAN port - WAN port.
5) If your router's WAN port is configured to obtain IP address for anything other than DHCP you may need to tweak some settings. Normally connected to a hotspot you want the WAN port setup to be 'obtain IP from DHCP'.

Instantly you should have internet access for your entire network. Note however you will also instantly be using whatever data plan you have on your cell phone. Data usage connected this way can be staggering - so if you don't have an unlimited plan you need to be aware it could be expensive. But if all you're doing is validating credit card transactions this may be worth it. Your connections should be changed back when your service has been restored. Note: You could use something like a Linksys LRT224 which would automatically switch back. I use a Linksys LRT214 and can confirm this setup works perfectly - but this requires manually switching cables back and forth.

title: Underwhelmed
text:
My primary wireless router (dual band ASUS RT-A68U) is in a basement utility closet next to the cable modem. There is a lot of metal to dampen signal strength near it, but it is accessible everywhere inside the house. Signal strength is weak in my workshop and out on my deck (occasional drop-outs).

Installation (WPS method) went smoothly. Some patience is required for the device to power up and to establish connections. I found the NETGEAR WiFi Analytics App, which I installed on my tablet, to be helpful for selecting the best outlet and antenna orientation.

I added this extender expecting to see a significant improvement in most upstairs areas. I did get a dramatic signal improvement out on my deck but no gain in my workshop, and the rest of the upstairs area showed little or no signal strength improvement. Having established a robust router connection I was expecting more gain out of this device at 25 feet away in my workshop, especially since I had paid handsomely for the higher data rate and dual band capability.

title: Netgear support is the worst.  Avoid their garbage products at all costs.
text:
I am done with Netgear. This thing just doesn't work unless you have a few specific routers. The configuration is garbage. If you are running a commercial access point or open source firmware, good luck. It will not work. Netgear will refuse to help. You will waste at least two hours of your time with their support who will just go through the guided setup again with you (which will never work). Eventually you can get the wireless portion to work with some obscure dynamic DNS revisions to the router (you will have to google this - Netgear support has no clue), but the ethernet port will never work. Unfortunately the ethernet port is the main reason I wanted this.

When you update to the latest firmware as of today (1/13/18) it will randomly decide if it wants to allow devices to access it or not when it is power cycled. This means that every time your power goes out, you have a pretty good chance that you will be reseting this thing. This didn't happen until I updated to the latest firmware. Considering it takes about five full minutes to restart, you can imagine how much time you will be wasting, wondering if the device is going to allow devices to connect.

I can't express the disgust with Netgear's support. If you go to their website and click that you want to call for support for this device it will take you to an email form. They don't even want to waste their time chatting about the issues. You can google the phone number and after being harassed by the automated responder for about 10 minutes you will be connected to a completely disinterested employee at Netgear. Their main goal is to get you off the phone as soon as possible. Even a customer hang up is considered a successful support call for Netgear. After owning the device for more than 90 days, this wonderful support feature will cost you.... $65 a year!!!! I am not joking. They actually have a business model for "long" term support on their own products. I've owned other brands networking equipment for years and they never charged me to chat with someone when something went wrong down the line.

title: I will not buy from this company again--- update
text:
I will not buy items from this company again. I bought this Wi-Fi extender, after another Netgear Wi-Fi extender was not providing the coverage that I needed for my home. I called several times since installing this extender to get help with placement because I was not getting adequate coverage from my router to my bedroom. We worked with placement, reconfigured it, and reinstalled it. I still only get spotty coverage in my bedroom. The last time I called them was last week and somebody assisted me. I called today and said I was still having problems. I indicated that I did have a second Netgear Wi-Fi extender and asked whether they could both be installed together on my network. After 15 minutes of giving them serial numbers, phone numbers, emails, the representative (Haritha #1713) indicated that she could indeed reconfigure my router so that I could install both Netgear products on my network and indicated that it would take care of the coverage problem. I thanked her and said let's go ahead and do this. I indicated that I wished somebody else would have suggested that earlier on. She then informed me that she would take care of the problem, but at the end of the call, since I was out of warranty that I would be required to purchase an additional technical support package for not only my Netgear products, but all electronics in my home. She indicated that the cheapest they offer is a three month package for $89. I said that in no way do I want them to take care of anything other than the Netgear products. I indicated that I purchased this product and it has never worked correctly. I indicated that I had called several times within the three month warranty. And nobody had indicated that there were other options that we could consider. I indicated that $89 was as much as I paid for both of their products. I indicated that they manufacture the products, have training and expertise in how to install them and get them working correctly, and that I should not have to pay more than the cost of these products to have this done. I spoke with her supervisor Naresh (1484) who indicated that he was not willing to help me set their product up correctly unless I paid an additional $89. I indicated that I should not be asked to pay for their products and then pay double that to have it set up correctly. I said I would go ahead and write a review on Amazon to warn other people that this is how their company treats their customers. I indicated that I would not purchase their products again. I also plan to write the CEO of Netgear to complain about this practice. I would like others to be aware. I do not write negative reviews often at all.
Update--I called corporate-after 20 minutes a representative in charge of technical support indicated that they would give me a one time okay to get this issue addressed. She indicated that she put this in my records and gave me a number to call and a case number. I just spent 30 minutes on the phone with a representative you said he would be happy to do this, indicated that he had my information in front of him, but he had to consult with a senior advisor. He indicated that the problem would get addressed and solved. He came back on the phone and indicated that he could not do this. He indicated that there was nothing in my records from corporate that said I could have a one time technical support call. I indicated I had just spoken with corporate several hours ago. He said there was nothing in the file. He tried to sell me the $89 one time contract. Why are we letting this company get away with this? So many times I have written reviews that highlight an excellent product, excellent customer service, and a delightful experience-this is not an example of that despite my best efforts to offer a different ending to this story. Have others had this experience? Any suggestions?

title: Hookup was easy but you've got to give it a while to ...
text: I was having a hard time getting my wifi to reach out to certain rooms in my home. After reading reviews, I decided to give this netgear a try. I highly recommend this product.  Just remember to be patient when hooking it up to your wifi.  Took me 3 tries and about 20 minutes.  Well worth the price. HERE IS A 3 MONTH FOLLOW-UP. I STILL LOVE THIS UNIT. IT'S STILL GIVING ME EXTREMELY STRONG WIFI IN ALL PARTS OF MY HOME AND PROPERTY.  BUT IT RANDOMLY LOOSES THE CONNECTION FROM MY ROUTER ABOUT ONCE A MONTH AND YOU HAVE TO RESET. SINCE THIS TAKES LESS THAN 5 MINUTES, I DON'T CONSIDER THIS A DRAWBACK. AFTER ALL, LIKE ALL  ELECTRONIC DEVICES, THEY HAVE TO BE REBOOTED EVERY ONCE IN A WHILE. THIS UNIT IS LOOSING CONNECTIONS WITH THE ROUTER EVERY OTHER DAY AND MUST BE RESET.  WHEN IT WORKS ITS FINE.  BUT UNSTABLE. SPEND A LITTLE MORE AND GET A BETTER ONE. I think I'd go for a better one.  Since im having to reconnect with my modem as many as 2-3 times per week.

title: It's okay...
text: My slightly used unit didn't come with instructions. But I figured it out and got it to work. It pulls in the 5 GHz router signal and rebroadcasts it as 2.4 GHz -- a smart move  that minimizes cross signal interference on the same frequency.  It helped "a little bit" to have this over-the-air device.  But it still isn't the same as having your laptop in the same room as the wireless router.  Signal strength is still compromised when going the distance through walls.  I might try and purchase the other type of extender next time that runs the signal feed through the house's power lines as that approach should avoid the loss of signal strength and clarity.

title: *UPDATED* Review from a 'non tech' user
text:
*UPDATE 9-2017*
POS already stopped working!! Will no longer communicate and just get a red light. Computer can't find it to reload. Buy something else!! Good for the 2 months it lasted :(

Our 1940's Cape style home is not plaster walls, they are cement board! Even our trusty Apple devices struggle. I needed to have wifi in my back yard studio. It's approx 100' from our wifi base, which of course has to go thru cement board.... on top of that, the building I converted to my studio is made from 1 1/4" thick solid walnut shiplap, with cedar siding.

This took no time at all for my SO to set up using the computer for our Apple modem. It linked right away, and we plugged the wifi range extender into an outlet about 30 ft from the studio.

I had ZERO wifi in the studio previously. Now I have full power for my devices. I can stream no problem. So for under $60 this was a great solution for me!

With Prime, if it doesn't work for you then return it. This fit the bill perfectly for me, but I am not doing really complicated computer work. I just needed to stream videos and music. Hope this helps :)

title: Junk
text:
This is now out of stock--I wish it was out of stock when I decided to give it a try. What a piece of garbage. I've got 150mb FIOS service but my Ring doorbell has some wifi issues since I moved it off the front door & hard wired into my house doorbell so I thought a wifi extender would beef it up, not to mention give the kids better wifi in their rooms upstairs. Downstairs, I rarely get less than 135mb down or up but upstairs in a couple of rooms the kids are lucky if they get 5-10mb. This extender was supposed to solve all of that.
Installation started smooth enough. But once it rebooted after I entered all the info it was a mess. First, devices could connect to it but not get any Internet. When they finally got Internet it was just 3-5 mb/s. Changing the direction of the antenna & kicking everyone off but 1 device Inwas able to squeeze out a maximum of 62mb on the 5ghz channel. 2.4 ghz was between 2 & 17mb. I can get a better wifi signal than that 4 houses away from my router.
If you're looking for a quality wifi extender, keep looking as this isn't it.

title: First Netgear product I've not liked
text:
I bought this for the typical "weak signal on part of my property" case, no special requirements here.

The *first* install wizard is well done. Not a fan of having to create a Netgear account during this process, but ok, fine. But the guided steps are clear and will get you to a connection point if the device itself doesn't have issues.

After that, its all downhill.

Using SpeedTest, the 5GHz WiFi speed near it is about half the speed of connecting directly to the 5G WiFi network its extending from the same exact spot. I suspect the device isn't powerful enough in processing to relay data fast enough, but I have no proof of that.

I have never been able to get the 2.4GHz part to work. On first attempt, devices failed to connect. Thinking maybe I typo'ed the wifi password, I went into the device's web interface to change at. However, there is no way to reconfigure host WiFi parameters. That left me with the factory reset option, and going through it all again.

This is where the wizard fails, as it provides no way to reuse existing account info. You get to "create" an account again, along with the two required password recovery questions.

This time, devices will connect, but, they can never reach the internet. Looking at the clients in my router's table, the Extender isn't on the 2.4G client table. It only exists on the 5G client table, which tells me its failing to properly connect.

Given it sucks at 5Ghz repeating, and two attempts to get it to work on 2.4GHz failed, back to Amazon it goes.

Instead of trying to save time with an extender, I plan to put up a real AP.

text:
I would say installation wasn't too difficult, just needed to read the instructions and then following through it. I did had to do it 2-3 times connecting it to my Netgear AC 1900 Modem Router. The wait time to pair the extender to my modem router took a little longer time than what was written on the instructions.

Once connected, I had the wifi extender plug close to the "dead end" of my son's room where he needed the strong signal for his home based learning. He was then able to connect his device to the extender immediately and had strong signal.

However, he would lost the wifi signal whenever his device is in a sleep mode, so he had to get the device to connect each time it went "dead", and all these reconnection take time, which is very inconvenient and frustrating.

We tried another extender from another big brand "T", and didn't have any issue like this Netgear extender. His device stayed connected to the extender the whole time even when his laptop was on sleep mode.

This Netgear extender just don't work well for us, will be returning for a refund.

title: Working well so far, but no better than an N300 (if you can't set yours up, connect to it via Ethernet during the setup)
text:
This is my second attempt at getting this extender from Amazon Warehouse Deals and it works pretty well. I set it up today.

The first one arrived yesterday from AWD, but someone had switch the labels....they put a less expensive model (N300/EX2700) back in the box with the labels of an AC1200/EX6120...not cool.

It's back in the box & being returned, but I went ahead and tried again and got the real-deal today.

Anyway, as soon as the correct EX6120 arrived I set it up.
I always have to connect to new (Netgear) range extenders via Ethernet cable for the initial setup, but after that it's usually fine. I just move it to the room I need to be in and we're good to go.

If you're not able to get your extender working by using only WiFi (via WPS) then you have to temporarily disconnect from your modem/router and connect directly to the Netgear extender in the same room as your main PC and then open your browser to www.mywifiext.net in order to set it up.

If you only use one modem/router, disconnect from it and manually connect your PC to the extender in the same room (only during setup... after it's set up, then you can move it to where you need to).

If you connect to a router, that then connects to a modem like I do, disconnect from the modem and connect via Ethernet to the extender to set it up using your browser at mywifiext.net.

Once the setup screen opens up and you're able to name your extender, your regular router will add the extender to its "client list" and assign its own IP address, which you can use in the future to access the router via your internet browser using 192.168.X.X or use www.mywifiext.net

NOTE: be sure to turn off the SSID Broadcasting after the set up is complete...it's better security...and in the extender's IP page, after it's been installed, when you turn off the SSID Broadcast you'll see a message that the extender won't work without SSID Broadcasting...NOT TRUE....it works fine. I don't broadcast our SSID for any routers or extenders...it's better security...your neighbors & passer by's cannot see your router's name.

Any device that needs to connect to your router or extender can easily do so, you just manually setup the connection the first time by extender (or router) name & passkey. Thereafter, it will connect automatically.

This range extender will be replacing an older, slower Netgear extender that is always losing the connection.

So far, this EX6120 is working fine, but, like other reviewers, I had to turn off the 5G to get the 2G signal to work. And, even though this EX6120 has longer antennae (than the N300), the range isn't any better than that of the N300.

Given the above, there's really no reason to spend the extra money on the EX6120. I'm basically using it as an N300.

So, for the money, I recommend sticking with the N300. I got my EX6120 from Amazon Warehouse Deals so I didn't pay the regular retail price. I paid about the same as the N300 Amazon retail price. Had I known the limitations of this EX6120, I would have gotten an N300 (...and not one disguised as an EX6120....LOL).

title: Lagging and dropped signal actually got worse!
text:
This booster had some pretty good reviews but from now on, before I buy I'm going to the product website and finding out how new or old the product I'm considering buying really is because this one is obviously going obsolete as Netgear doesn't even have it listed on its main product page although I was able to download the manual for it from deep within the website itself.
(NOTE: Always download a manual the moment you buy, you're on the website registering so take that extra moment to grab a download of your manual too. Create a file and dump every single one you get in to it, then ignore it until you can't find your hardprint manual and you're desperate for directions. After 5-10yrs or even 1-2 yrs there's hardly a company that still has downloadable manuals.

I bought this wifi boost to increase connectivity to a tablet in the room at the back of the place that was always glitching and losing bar strength.
1st install attempt I did myself and it was simple and smooth according to directions and programmed in the same room as my desktop and router, then installed it in a room between router and a tablet-use room. All well for about 2 days then the tablet in the back room started lagging and dropping off and also my desktop in the router room started losing connectivity, which had never happened before in 5yrs. Got so bad, I uninstalled it.
2nd attempt, I programmed an alternate way in the manual but wasn't comfortable with how it seemed to end the programming before I got to the end of the instructions but it had good bar strength. This time I installed it directly in the room the tablet was being used in but ended up uninstalling it for the same reason as install #1 - lagging and dropped signal.
3rd attempt 3/4/21 and this time I called Netgear. My obsolescence suspicions were pretty much confirmed when they had to track down a tech to help me with this specific booster.
That's a really bad sign, anytime about anything!
Theo the Tech was awesome though. It must have taken at least 30min to install it by web browser setup but by the time he was done I had a separate network connection for my booster in both 2G and 5G and even unique
passwords on both new accounts. It seemed all problems were solved but...within 2hrs both our devices were having the same issues again; I gave up for the day and slept on it, only to remember
that I had not moved the booster back to the in-between room or even the tablet-use room so in to the tablet room it went, from one wall plug to another, hoping to find one that would hook up with the router and after trying 2 plugs and even seeing the router light turn red when only green and amber are ever mentioned in the manual - it finally stayed green on the router light.
I wish I could just get my money back at this point.

title: Junk. Don't buy
text:
Well, I've spent about 4 hours on Christmas day trying to connect this extender to my router. I would like to mention that this is an Amazon "used-returned" product and now I know why. I will return it myself. I would like to mention that installation isn't as simple as they make it sound in the instructions. The extender would not connect to my AT&T Uverse router via WPS button at all. Yes, I was in the same room with the router 5 feet away from it. Finally I completed the connection via the LAN cable. Hook the router to the Netgear extender via LAN cable. I used the Netgear genie and it took about 10-15 min. The repeater is dual band. It has 2.4 and 5Ghz. I added both bands and did the passwords for both. Most modern devices will connect via 5GHz which is way faster. After setting it up with LAN cable ( if you don't have one you're in trouble) I moved the repeater about 20 feet away from router in a different room. Extender still has a good connection to the router. So far so good. The problem is, the device you have, as you move away from the main router, won't automatically connect to the WiFi extender as you get closer to it. You have to do it manually, which of course defeats the purpose. When doing it manually, 3 feet away from extender, sometimes it connects, sometimes it doesn't. When it doesn't, it stays stuck on "obtaing IP". If it does connect, it only works if you're about 5-10 feet away in that room..if you move about 20 feet away, no more connection and unfortunately device won't connect to regular router, I have to do it manually. My advice to anyone wanting an extender? Get the one recommended by your internet provider. If you do, it is made to pair up easily with the provider's router. ATT has one they sell, but I took the cheap way out.( cheap only because my wifi extender was used, otherwise, not cheap). This NETGEAR unit is way too finicky and not powerful enough. Device connected to it has to be in the same room with it and let's hope it isn't a very big room. Save yourself some time and headaches. Get the extender recommend by your internet provider and let them install it and set it up if possible. The reason they recommend a certain extender is because after trial and error, they realized which one works and connects best with their routers.
Today, December 26th I've spent 45 minutes on the phone with Netgear support. Basically we reset and reinstalled. Netgear support came to the conclusion that unit is broken and advised to send back to Amazon. I wonder if Amazon is checking these "used" units or just sending them broken to unsuspecting customers.

text: I bought this Wi-Fi range extender so my smart TV would work in my bedroom. I unboxed and it was really easy to link to my router with the WPS method. However, I could not get any device to connect to the extender. It kept telling me my password was wrong even though it was the right password. I tried the website support, and found nothing useful and ended up calling technical support. When talking to technical support they asked to remotely connect to my computer which I hesitantly did. They ran some command prompts to ping IP addresses using my WiFi. They told me that there were too many things using my Wi-Fi and recommended downloading $150 software from a website to remove these “Wi-Fi Pirates “because my router was overloaded and no new device could be connected. I politely declined. Subsequently, I logged into my router directly and saw they were only the four devices I knew and no other random devices that have ever been connected to They told me that there were too many things using my Wi-Fi and recommended downloading $150 software from a website to remove these “Wi-Fi pirates “because my router was overloaded and no new devices could be connected. I politely declined. Subsequently, I logged into my router directly and saw they were only the four devices I knew and no other random devices that have ever been connected to my internet. The tech-support felt like a huge sham and I regret allowing them access to my computer at all. Fortunately through some ingenuity I was able to move my router 6 feet closer to my bedroom and was able to connect my TV to my router without needing any range extender. I do not recommend this product at all. If you choose to buy this product and it does not work with the instructions given, do not call tech support. They will just try to sell you something. Returned same day.

title: Initial review
text:
2/20/2018 - My main access point is on the far right side of my home on the second floor. This was leaving the other side with spotty access.I was looking for a way to extend my WiFi across my home without having to send a couple hundred dollars in additional equipment or running cat5e drops throughout my home. So far this device has easily resolved my issue for less then $50.

Setup was easy. I followed the instructions and the device was up in about 5 minutes. plug in the device connect to it's SSID. Type in the provided URL, follow the prompts. It couldn't be easier!

So the initial testing seem to be promising. According to the Netgear home test app I am getting 100% Signal / 144 Mbps in the room I am trying to reach on my first floor. Speedtest over WiFi is 28 down/12 up to the interest (Which is average in my home for WiFi). No complaints from the kid about there gaming systems. That's always a good sign.

So far I am happy with this device. It was easy to setup and has been working stable. I will update in about a month or as this change for better or worst.

3/20/2019 - It's been over a month so far so good. Only thing I would have done different name the extenders separate SSID. I recommend naming SSID_ext1,SSID_ext2 so they don't conflict with the main router.

title: Due to complexity of product, "Ease of install" is a relative term
text:
This is the 2nd one I've installed.
When it arrived and I plugged it into the wall, no signal, no nothing. Didn't show up. Reset resolved ... possibly this was used? Hard to tell.

I was not installing via WPS, so I needed to get to the browser. Okay, you're connected to the device, and you setup an account. Given that it doesn't immediately connect to the internet, I was wondering how they check your account. Doh! Once it does connect to the wireless, then of course it can check. I found this a bit confusing, then realized they did it differently than I expected.

I then logged into the account I already created, and the rest was in fact easy. It does a great job and allows my wife's office (3rd bedroom in the house) to receive, when before it was a bit spotty. Even though our Netgear wireless router is in the center of the house.

On other end of the house, good signal. Not as strong as the wireless router, because that is closer. So sometimes it may be necessary to connect to the best signal. No problem, that's easy to do.

title: D-I-Y WiFi Booster (used to extend and improve my wireless 4G (VZW) hotspot)
text:
This device will help amplify and extend and improve your WiFi signal. Amazing signal boost. It also has an ethernet jack on the side so you attach your data cable.
Setting this up is not too difficult if you follow the eternity AND connect (1) this device and (2) your web browser (in desktop mode) device, to (3) the same WiFi signal. On a scale from 1 to 9, with novice as 1 and expert as 9, you need to be at a 4 level. You may suceed as a novice but it could take you much longer. You also fail as an expert if you fail to read and follow the instructions. I am a " 6 " on this scale and it took me 1/2 hour.
Do try this at home.
Your results may vary. Batteries not included....seriously you do not need any.

title: OMG read my updates...  Direct lan to laptop to his device SCREAMS.
text:
Wow I had never read the 1 star reviews. I likely would not have bought one. But I did... works GREAT except I tried direct LAN connection to my laptop and that doesn't work. (maybe user error? might have to configure it in settings)? I'll look into that.

I run a observatory in my yard. 300+ feet from my router. I have 5G and 2.5G on the router. (cable internet). I could BARELY connect to the 2.5 300+ feet away. I got this for 1/2 way... but first time I tried it I just plugged it in next to the laptop 300+ feet out. It picked up good signal and was giving the laptop 5 bars. Works great. MY PROBLEM is my laptop is old and has slow wifi. So I want to try direct LAN connection. I got 50mbs in the house and 10 at the laptop. I may have to get a faster/newer laptop. Many reviews say it died in a couple months. I'll report back if mine does.

UPDATE OMG! I worked on the LAN connection. Seems I had a bad cable. It's now working, My speedtest.net went from 15mbps to 66 mbps!!! Now that LAN is working - I'm going from 4 to 5 stars!

PS - I think the 1 star reviews are user/error.

title: Finally have internet access in the guest house!!!!
text: I am NOT a tech savvy person. I can connect to the internet, and that's basically where it ends. That said, I was concerned about purchasing an extender because I didn't want a headache with setup, and wasn't even sure what I needed. We have a decent size yard with a small guest cottage in the back, which was supposed to double as an office for me. Great setup until I realized I have no internet access out there. Enter this device. I stumbled upon it and thought I'd give it a shot. To my DELIGHT it took less than five minutes to set up, no tech skills necessary other than the ability to press one button on my internet router so it would connect with the extender. I then followed the instructions to move it and plug it in half way between the router and the problem area (my guest cottage). Fortunately, that is basically my bedroom, so I picked an empty outlet, plugged it in, connected to it as I would any other internet connection, and then went out to the back of the yard (the cottage) and YESSSSS, we have INTERNET! It didn't connect to the "5G" option (whatever that is) but it connected to the 2G option with strong signal. I tested Netflix, and had no trouble being able to get a clear video. SO glad that I found this extender, and highly recommend for anyone who is weary of getting into the weeds of tech issues but needs their home signal to reach the yard, etc.

title: This Thing Is AWESOME!
text:
I live in an old NYC Apartment Building with a bunch of other tenants with wi-fi. Needless to say, although my 2G had decent range, the range on my 5G suffered tremendously.

(Basically, if my router was out of site, I had no real access to 5G.)

In my bedroom, not only was 5G inaccessible, but the slower 2G was unacceptable (and unstable).

So... I purchased this, followed the WPS instructions 2x (twice), as per instructions (for those operating a dual band router).

The instructions are simple:

1st, plug in and power on the extender near the router (and give it a minute to 'warm up').

2nd, press the WPS button on the extender (it will blink repeatedly).

3rd, press (and in my case, hold) the WPS button on the router (which blinked as well, on the router).

4th, wait for the WPS LED on the extender to turn solid green (which indicates a connection (1st, to the 2G).

***Repeating steps 2-4 will link a second connection to 5G (if you have a dual-band router).

5th, unplug the extender, and place/plug it midway between the router and the device(s) which will access it (which in my case was near the entrance of my bedroom).

Lastly... Search for the extender's SSID --- ending in '_EXT'.

Since I wanted to extend and obtain access to 5G, I searched for the '...5G_EXT', typed in the same password used to access my roter's wi-fi, and VIOLA! I now have access to 5G in my bedroom, all bars MAXED!

Since my devices aren't accessing the 5G from the router directly, there is some (theoretical) loss in speed (which I do not notice).

One thing for sure, however, is the internet speed in my bedroom is now MUCH faster (and more reliable) since I can now tap into the 5G speeds which I couldn't access before the extender.

Thus, "Mission Accomplished!"

The directions are so simple, I think a lot of people over-complicate it. I almost did.

They said to repeat the steps to link a second connection to 5G; that's what I did.

Maybe someday I'll try to configure it for other security measures I've read other reviewers mentioned...

But for now... No more 2G for me! ...and that has made ALL the difference 😉👍

(Btw... I am using the 1200 model.)

Hope this helps.

title: Stopped working after 1 year! 5ghz never worked.
text:
I've had this Wi-Fi extender for 1 year now and it has given me trouble ever since the day it arrived. First of all, I have 300 mbps internet and even when getting a very strong signal (I even tested it right next to the main router), the best this has managed to pull off was 150 mbps on the 5ghz band. In addition, the 5ghz band never worked right. When you connected to the 5ghz network, it would work fine for about 30 minutes, then, all of a sudden I would get messages from my web browser saying could not locate website ip address or something to that effect. Once this happened, the only way to fix it was to disconnect the from Wi-Fi network and reconnect. This made the 5ghz band completely unusable for online gaming or video calls where it's very important that you have a solid connection. I've never had this problem on my main router. You may be asking why don't I use the 2.4 ghz band. Well, with that I get around 30 to 60 mbps. That's a 10x decrease at worst!!!! I've spent hours playing around with its crappy configuration settings, changing dns settings, changing ip addresses etc. Granted, it was still better than no extender but still not an ideal experience.

Recently, it started to randomly stop working requiring me to unplug it and plug it back in. By "stop working," I mean it just flat out didn't work or would deliver speeds of around 10kbps - 500 kbps!!! That's fine for 1999, but in 2021 it's completely and utterly useless. Finally, 3-4 of days ago, power cycling it no longer worked and now it's pretty much trash.

If everything I've just said went over your head, here's the summary: It never worked correctly, while it did extend the Wi-Fi, it made it extremely slow and now it just doesn't work any more. DO NOT BUY THIS!!!!!!!! Buy anything else if you have to. I don't want anyone else to go through the trouble that I've been through.

title: NetGear WiFi EX6120 Range Extender is an easy fix for an aggravating problem
text:
I purchased and installed the NetGear WiFi EX6120 about six weeks ago. It resolved a spotty reception problem in the master bedroom. I placed it in a hallway receptacle located approximately 40 feet from the original WiFi access point and approximately 20 feet from the the consumption point in the master bedroom. Works great! The only negative is the minor inconvenience of having to tell my iPad to use the other access point when I move into and out of the bedroom. Not a big deal since both access points service “most” of the house adequately anyway. The extender simultaneously supports my regular and 5G signals.

The picture attached shows the device mounted upside down. This allows me to also plug in my carbon monoxide detector (removed for the photo to avoid confusion). Just flip the attennas around no problem.

title: Works Great

title: A very good value.
text:
Cable modem and wifi router in the second floor, smart TV in the basement, signal too weak to be reliable for the TV. Installed the extender on the first floor, problem solved.

Do you need an expensive “system” solution to multiple devices and drywall/masonry/flooring barriers? Not yet, in my opinion. The extender solution works fine until gigabit speeds to the house are more ubiquitous - and not ridiculously aggregated by the providers.

This particular one works well, and I strongly recommend the dual band models. There are good technical reasons for this, but they boil down to better throughput from the Internet to your devices. Installing it and getting the settings right can be an adventure. Read the manual before you start. Always keep the firmware up to date. Netgear products with old firmware are vulnerable to malicious attacks. So is almost everybody else, for that matter.

If I were building a new house, I would do a smart system with wired ethernet between the wireless points, but I’m not, so I won’t.

Maybe it had to do with the router I was using, an ASUS AC1300, but that was not noted anywhere or stated by Netgear tech support.  After over an hour or so on the phone with technical support, and going through the usual (firmware upgrade, factory reset, router channel change, etc.), it was determined my product was "defective". title: Easy to install.  Easy to use when it works.
text:
This is easy to install. Plug it in near wifi router. Push WPS button on extender. Push WPS on router and wait for connection. You're then free to unplug and move the extender to where you wish to plug it in. Since my router is 2ghz and 5ghz enabled, the extender will emit the same signals on the extended wifi. This means that you will now have 3 wifi signals. You will need to log into the wifi you wish to use.

That being said, I've had this installed for about a week and I've had to reset it twice due to dropped connections. After reset it works fine. I've run speed tests on all connections and it does help bolster speed the further away from your main router you get which is nice.

The support number on their website quickly sorted it out using an IP address for the unit I did not have. Due to additional concerns, I still ditched this and ended up using NETGEAR PowerLINE 1000 Mbps WiFi, 802.11ac, 1 Gigabit Port. Amazon carries this, it's more expensive, however I had it installed in under 5 minutes using the included instruction. Dead easy. That's my 2 cents. Good luck.

title: Great for what it is but with limitations!
text:
What this is not is a full-fledged AP, it's an extender. To that end the best option in the setup to use it for that purpose is what they call 'FastLane Technology' and here's how it's described:

Basic - Connect devices on both 2.4 and 5Ghz bands at the same time. Extends both WiFi bands at the same time (2.4 and 5Ghz), but reduces WiFi performance.
FastLane Technology - Offers maximum performance but limits connection to one band (2.4 or 5GHz).
Router-to-Extender in 5GHz only and Extender-to-Device in 2.4GHz only (Router must support 5GHz band).

I of course took the middle option and I use the 5GHz band between AP and extender and 2.4GHz for devices. So you see there's no free lunch to extend both bands at max performance but again, for what this is and at this price, it works well and will definitely improve the signal for problem areas in your home.

title: Worked for 3 weeks. Horrible experience.
text:
There should be a 0 star for garbage products like this. It worked for roughly about 3 weeks and then I could not connect to its 5Ghz band. Tried resetting the device multiple time but nothing worked. Went through their lengthy process of trying to contact them. They don't list a support number on their website, at least I couldn't find it. It's almost as if they NEVER want you to call as it's not easy to find. First, you have to create a case online and then you are given a number to call. What world are these guys living in? If you really want to help your customer post your support number on the first page that comes up when hit "Support"! Moving on...called the tech support and got connected to some guy in India. He had no customer service attitude. Very short in his answers and rude. He asked me to allow him to connect to my laptop so he can trouble shoot. Great! Don't really like that but I let him do it. Half the time I didn't see him do anything, the screen was not moving at all. Maybe he was reading up on what to do on his end. The tech kept doing the same rebooting process over and over again for an hour! I got frustrated with this nonsense and I told him to forget about this, I'm sending this product back. He goes on to tell me that this product has a lot of issues and recommends me another product, a little higher on the performance side from this extender which doesn't seem to give any issues, according to him. OK great! so why are you selling this product with known issues still?
Overall, horrible product, that only lasted 3 weeks. I have had no luck with Netgear products and the last one I had was a router that got disconnected from my modem every week which I finally gave up on about 3 years back. Replaced with an Asus router and problem solved. I hoped that Netgear has improved in their quality but they just don't work for me. In my opinion I think the whole issue is in its firm ware. It just seems to get hung up in a brick state if it gets disconnected from your router. Stay away from anything Netgear.

title: Great product; bad instructions
text:
I'm not in the habit of writing reviews for products but felt compelled to write for this one. I have a normal suburban 2-story house. For some unknown reason the bedroom was the dead zone. The extender I had configured downstairs near my router just wouldn't penetrate and give coverage in the bedroom. That's frustrating when you're trying to use an IPAD or tablet and can't get coverage. When I plugged this in and configured it I have 100% coverage now.

That's the good news. The bad news is that the instructions are poorly written and lead you to an online website where you have to either call a number or work with an online rep. I chose to do neither. I plugged the device in, waited for the lights to stabilize and then looked for the new URL that showed up in my WiFi list of resources. I then connected my IPAD to that device and the online screen popped up that allowed me to configure the device. Five minutes later it was up and running and I've perfect coverage since then.

text: I have a mac mini placed inside a wood/glass cabinet working as a "cord cutting" media computer.  However, it was getting a very poor reception from the WiFi router.  I think I was getting something like 15db N/S ratio, with a link speed of 54 mbps.  (the max link speed of a mac mini is 300mbps).  Even though 54 mbps is fast enough to stream HD, the noise was killing Netflix HD which had to keep on pausing to buffer.  The range extender now gives the mac mini a 32db N/S ratio with a link speed of 300mbps.  Doing a network speed test, I am getting about 100mbps download speed.

title: Amazing improvement in wifi
text:
I live in an old cheese factory which has been converted to a single family home. In a word, it is huge. Two stories, 1450 square feet on the main (upper) floor, more than that in the lower floor, which is where the factory was. Much of it was built in the 1890's, with more added on later. There are concrete walls, tree trunks as support beams and a long steel I-beam that was built in a more "modern" phase of additions.

Needless to say, the wifi on its own isn't great. The router is centrally located, but still only does well in the kitchen, living room, and dining room, which are all pretty open to one another. There is a TV in the room on the other side of the wall where the router is and I can't watch Hulu on the TV, as it is always buffering. Forget trying to stream anything in the family room on the lower level.

I placed the Wifi range extender in my basement with line of sight to the TV in the family room and now have excellent reception in both rooms. I'm overjoyed.

Setting it up was so simple, too. Just plug in the range extender in the room where the router is and wait for it to boot up, then press the WPS button on the extender, then the router and wait for them to "talk". Then plug it in near where you need better reception. I have mine about equally distant from the two rooms where I needed improved reception. I don't think I could be any happier unless it came with another 20 gigs of Internet!

text:
Had issues with getting wifi access in my basement, living room, and upstairs guest room and decided to give this a try. I was not disappointed.

CONS
nothing to write home about, but each device add a "_2GEXT" or "_5GEXT" to the SSID it is extending. I have 2 in play, so I have a network that's labeled SSID_2GEXT_2GEXT.

They all work but would be nice if a user could edit the name to differentiate them - so I'd have something like SSID_BasementEXT.

title: What good is it when it jams your existing Wifi signal?

After some testing, I found out that when this extender is plugged in, our existing Wifi network goes from about 150Mbps down to less than 2Mbps which often was less than 1Mbps. After removing and replacing the extender several times to confirm that was indeed interfering, and finding that changing the extender's channel (which was actually disabled for the 2ghz network, which was the important one) did not help, we decided to return it. Extending a wifi signal is pointless if you jam the primary signal

title: Hard to setup, not a reliable connection
text:
Out of the box, it wouldn't work.
(1) My PC couldn't see the EX6120 NETGEAR wireless SSID. I found an iPhone and connected to it.
(2) The NETGEAR genie admin interface is tedious and clunky on the iPhone and in the end, just when you have the configuration almost complete, it auto connects to the new network and terminates the genie, while the configuration is incomplete.
(3) Dug up a CAT5 cable and connected the PC to the EX6120, allowing the PC to connect to the NETGEAR SSID and complete the extender's configuration.

The new extended wireless connection is good where it was needed, but at odd times, inexplicably the EX6120 drops the device connection for a minute and restarts it while it is being used. SHM. Makes no sense.

title: Way to slow - speed was less than main router
text: This product did not work. I have a 4 floor house and wanted to enhance the speed of my wifi on the top two levels, because the main high speed (1Gig) router is located in the basement (due to the complexity of our network and stereo system - I can't move the router). So, I bought this extender. After completing the installation, I took it to our 3rd floor, plugged it in and waited for it to connect. Once connected, a few feet away from the extender, I signed onto the signal and ran a speed test. My results were a download speed or 33.27 Mbps and an upload speed of 34.97 Mbps. From the same location, I then signed on to my main router and I got a faster connection - 58.17 download and 44.64 upload. I tested this a few times in different locations on both my 3rd and 4th level. Each time the main router in the basement outperformed (i.e. had a higher speed) than the extender. This extender is does not live up to its promise.
