title: Mine simply doesn't work properly.
text:
I see a lot of good reviews, so I assume they just don't always work. Got it connected pretty easily and it worked well for a few seconds, then the signal faded. Did this over and over then finally called NETGEAR support. They took me through the entire process and did in fact have me go through one more step once I told them the way they were taking me was exactly the same as I had been doing it. The thing took off perfectly and then faded again in just a few minutes.

Then and before, it wouldn't reconnect to my device or vice versa once it faded. Got a lemon, ticks me off.

title: You lose a lot of bandwidth on 1G internet, but probably ok for users with 100meg internet
text: Easy to connect, but needed to use the -ext to connect devices to.  Other extender I have (Netgear AC1900) were able to use the same wireless as the main router and did not need to use -ext to hook up to.  See the list of wireless networks to see what I mean.  That said, the speed into the house is over 800meg with ethernet cable to computer, speed from the Netgear AC1750 wireless router with Netgear AC1900 extender is over 200meg, but drops down to under 50meg with the Netgeat AC1200.  Still plenty fast enough to support all the devices I have hooked to this extender.  For the price, 50meg is adequate for I would guess 90% of the population.  For anyone with 100meg interne this extender should be fine since it can handle 50meg (see picture).  Should be able to run printers, Alexa, wireless speakers and probably TV with video streaming.  I'm not a gamer, so I defer to someone else to answer if 50meg is enough for gaming.  The only negative I can find is I couldn't hook it up to one network as I did with my Netgear AC1900, but had to set up an -ext to hook specific devices to individually.  Maybe the capability is there the same as it is for the Netgear AC1900, but I haven't figured it out yet.  I had to plug it upside down due to bottom plug style, but it works just fine upside down.  Just needed to point that out to all the OCD folks out there like me.

title: Slow speeds
text: My biggest gripe about this is that you cannot extend your wifi with this by running an ethernet cable to it. I want to connect this to my router via an ethernet connection to make the extender emit a wifi signal comparable to the main router. I've tried multiple times, but unfortunately I believe the ethernet port on this device only works one way as an output. Working only off of a wifi connection to the main router, the signal that comes from this is fairly strong and consistent, but extremely slow. We get a 200mb speed wifi connection from our main router, but only 30-35mb speeds from this... And that's 83% slower. This thing can only perform at 17% the speed of the original router... Which is why I wanted to connect via ethernet. It may be okay for one or maybe 2 devices streaming something at 720p or maybe 1080p, but I'm downloading very large files and I need a much faster connect then 30mb/second.

title: Happiness is a nice, strong signal.

title: Get In My Basement
text: Very few things seem to want to go down into my basement. It could be the musty smell and the mildew that softly coats everything. Or maybe it's the poor lighting and exposed wires. Some might say its the metal door and the 5 deadbolts. Whatever it is, my basement seems to be a no-go zone, and that's including my wifi. Well, today I rejoice for I finally have company. Geez, set up was easy, push WPS on extender, then on router, and BAM; I'm connecting with other lonely basement dwellers. Before the extender I was 3mbps up/3 down. Now I'm 45/40. This is more than enough to live stream grainy video in black/white and, if I so choose, show the fine details of my stitch work on my masks. The extender seems to be a good idea as opposed to letting some "electrician" try to drop line and then getting "spooked" in the basement due to the cameras and cages and calling the cops. Geez Lyle, I explained I'm an "artist" and for the nth time, I apologize.. Also I still have a couple of your tools and you're free to stop by anytime to get them. I'll be here, but this time with friends!

text: Purchased this yesterday due to several online review sites listing this as one of 2019's top two wifi extenders for under $100. Got it same day delivery. LOVE AMAZON PRIME! Received it late in the day, so at about 11pm  started hooking this up as a repeater for my 3 Camera Arlo system. Old generic repeater suddenly stopped working after a power surge. So after messing around with this Netgear extender for an hour, never getting the 5G side to provide internet, I called Netgear tech support. Two hours on the phone trying to troubleshoot with tech support. We never did get the 5G side working. Was told I'd have to contact my Router Manufacturer and have them switch my router channel. WHAT?!!! So put the 5G thing on the back burner, and just rely on the 2.4G for the Arlo, so I'd at least have cameras running for the night. Hooked the Arlo Smart Hub up to the Ethernet Port, and low and behold, NO INTERNET to the Arlo hub. Called Netgear tech support back, another hour on the phone until we came to the conclusion that the Ethernet Port on this extender must be faulty, so I'd need to exchange it. To be honest, I think that was just the quickest way to get rid of me because the tech was at a loss. Mind you, this is all taking place between 11pm and 3am. That's how many hours I've been messing with this thing. Called Amazon, and being the awesome customer service they are, shipping me out a replacement this morning, which I should have later today. But NOW I start reading the Amazon customer reviews. Now I'm thinking maybe I should have just opted for a refund and purchased a second router. I guess we'll see how it goes, and if we get it all working as it should, and I'm not dropping connections ever other day, like a lot of others are complaining about, then I'll keep it. But if it so much as even looks at my funny within the 30 day window, it's going back, and will look into just purchasing a good second router to use as a repeater.

title: Great addition to my WiFi network
text: I'm in a second floor condo unit, and I needed a WiFi signal in my garage to take full advantage of some of the features of a new garage door opener.  Unfortunately, my Arris Surfboard router located on one end of the condo couldn't get a reliable signal through the cinderblock walls of the garage below on the other end.  The Netgear WiFi extender solved this problem for me.  By locating the extender in a room immediately over the garage, I was able to get a reliable WiFi link to the garage door opener, and I'm now able to add a video camera to the garage as well.  The Netgear extender paired up easily with the Arris router, and if the connection is ever lost (like a router reboot or power outage), it syncs back up again automatically.  Good product!

title: Useless for travel; can't set up with web browser as advertised
text:
I got this unit, powered it on, and went to install. You have to either press the WPS button on your router (not available when you're traveling, obviously, as you are using a router that may be in a hotel or campground office, etc.) or set it up via web browser. When you enter the address as instructed, you see that you can only set up certain Netgear models using the browser, and this wasn't one of them. How handy - NOT. If you try to connect using your computer's wireless find-and-join program, it might ask for a Network Security Key, also not provided in the instructions or on the unit itself.

UPDATE: I eventually got it to work, but not by following the instructions in the skimpy manual. I did a web search and found alternate instructions (involving an IP address to be used for the extender). I still have problems with connectivity, where it will say "connected but no internet connection" for a long time then all of a sudden come on. Once it does finally connect to the internet, it seems to stay reliably connected with multiple devices. You may be using the factory reset more than once, as well.

UPDATE #2: Ended up returning it after struggling for hours with a "no Internet connection" message on every device, even after unplugging it and then plugging it back in. If you have to fight this much to get it to work...well, there are better options out there.

title: I could not connect to the device (2 different devices)
text:
I have tried 2 of these devices now and I have had nothing but problems.

The first device was only partially defective. I was able to get through the setup after a few "factory resets". The issue with this one was that my devices could not resolve a good IP address on the 5G network. I was able to connect to and use the 2.5G network but since it is dual band, and I want to extend both existing networks, this was not acceptable. After attempting to reset the device again and get through the setup, I was not able to even connect to the 2.5G network and later, I could not connect to the device at all. It had slowly died....

I returned the device to Amazon and they had the replacement on the way the same day (nice work Amazon).

Received the device last night and tried to set up the new one this morning. I could not even get through the initial setup. I was able to connect 2 different computers to the default network (NETGEAR_EXT) but when I tried to navigate to the "mywifiext.net" site, I kept getting a message that says the site was not secure and I could not connect. The "details" said the site was using an unsupported protocol and none of the browsers I use would connect. In full disclosure, I did get to the site during first attempt (switched browsers) and got as far as selecting the networks that I wanted to extend but then the connection was lost and I could not get back to the site. I attempted to reset the device as well as the computers but no access to the website could be established, and I got the unsecure/unsupported protocol message.

I have a different style network extender from Netgear that has worked flawlessly for over 3 years now, so I do not have an issue with the brand or other products they make. I cannot recommend this particular product however.

It does seem others have had good luck with these but I'm 0 for 2 on them and I'm moving on to something else. Your results may be different.

Instructions said to go to "mywifiext.net" where there is supposed to be a screen button to setup a new device.
There was no setup button.
Unable to proceed I accepted the offered chat with NetGear tech support that popped up on the screen.
Tech support guy said problem was my network wasn't secure and that there were 17 devices currently tapped into my wifi (when there should only be 7, i.e., 2 roku sticks, 2 printers, 2 iphones, laptop).

Bottom line is it took 2 hours to get the device up and running and I ended up paying $299 to someone called 'Computer Services USA' for "3 years of support and securities".

Update: 11/24
Computer Services USA has called me several times. I never pickup because they caller ID indicates "RESTRICTED", but they left a message. Indian voice saying my network is being hacked and I need to call them right away.
Since talking with them last I have had spectrum replace my router so I know Computer Services USA can't peek into the network anymore so they are lying when they say they can and can see hacking activity.

title: Easy setup, but a little slower than working directly through my router
text: This sets up easily and works, but at a somewhat slower data rate than working directly through my router and a little slower than I was hoping for. I probably should have bought a higher speed version.  I now have two of these. My router is on the 2nd floor center of the house and one of these is near each end of the house and located on the 1st floor. Simple to set up - Just plug it in near your router and press the button on this and the back of your router. Expect it to take some time (like maybe 5 minutes). To identify the router and the green light to go steady on the extender. Then you can just unplug and move it to the desired location. Think of the range for these as circles and your router and this extender must have overlapping circles to work. The circle diameter is about 50' radius, but it will vary if walls, etc. are in between. Metal and stone/brick walls do not conduct signals well. My home is about 100' long and this is working for me. I did not need tech support, so a medium 3 stars for that.

title: WORKS GREAT - FOLLOW INSTRUCTIONS TO THE LETTER
text: I purchased two of these for Arlo wireless base stations. One works great and was easy to install. The other one is being returned for replacement because 2.4 GHz is flaky, probably due to a loose antenna on the right side. A couple of important notes. First, during initial set up, place the unit very close to your main WiFi device (same room or closer). If not, you are begging for problems. I used a tablet to connect to the extenders, one at a time and unplugged the first extender immediately after configuration so it does not interfere with the second one being configured. Once the extender is set up, you lose Internet connectivity because it is now operating on your new SSID and its password. You need to reconnect your tablet (or other device) to the new SSID and password before proceeding with final set-up. This connection takes a few minutes with several automatic re-tries, but eventually connects. Because I am using two of these extenders on the same WiFi system, I add an A at the end of the SSID on one and a B at the end of the other (Ralph_EX6120_2G-extA & Ralph_EX6120_5G-extA and Ralph_EX6120-2G-extB & Ralph_EX6120-5G-extB). I turned off the 5G radio and disabled its SSID broadcast because I did not need 5G extended. Since I am only using them as an Ethernet connections to the Arlo Base stations, I might turn off 2G and turn on 5G so as not to have so many devises operating on 2.4G where the cameras operate, but 2.4G works great now with clear camera resolution.

text:
I purchased this first and foremost because my router is in the basement affixed to one of the floor joists in the basement because I didn't want to see it. Unfortunately, the signal was not good on the first floor (ranch) because of the duct work and foil wrapping on the floor joists. This device fixed that problem.

My "smart" home thermostat cannot handle a wi-fi router that is dual band capable. So, I was told to call by thermostat guy to call my ISP and have them tell me how to turn off that capability, connect my home thermostat, then reenable dual band. Yeah! Right. I realized that this device has the ability to run in dual band mode or single. I set it up for single and connected my thermostat to it. Killing two birds with one stone. The signal throughout the house is now 5 bars at every location!

This is very easy to install and get up and running AND it's plugged in where it cannot be seen. No wires hanging off it. This was a great solution to my two technical issues.

text: This is a pretty good device but has significant to small flaws. It is unable to detect my router's 5Ghz wifi signal. I wanted to extend my router's 5Ghz range but the device did not see it, other people also had this problem so I chalked it up to my lazy research. Although, the device does everything else fine. It was able to connect to my router's 2.4Ghz signal and extend it through both 2.4 and 5Ghz antenna's but that defeats the purpose because of the bottleneck of 2.4Ghz. I decided to use it as an access point by wiring it to the router from another room in the house and have another 2.4 and 5Ghz access point. The only other small flaw is that the ethernet port on the device maxes at 100mbs.

I wanted to throw a signal into my backyard since my rig is in the front of the house. Now it’s basically useless. It doesn’t work anymore and it only throws a signal about 5 feet them cuts out. I only wanted to use it to get podcast while cutting the grass in the backyard and in my garage shop about 25 feet from my house. It doesn’t work at all in The garage anymore as well.

title: Junk cash grab.
text: I have had and still do own many Netgear products. As an avid experienced user in network structuring, this product is for those owning a 10yr or older a/b 54Mbps router on their network. I am using the Netgear X4S Nighthawk in our home and our pool is about 150ft away from our home. I bought this for guest to use at the pool during a party. It couldn't even pick up a signal with the wind blowing in it's face. Speaking of face, it sure feels like a slap in it. At the pool, remind you 150ft away, my ZTE Zmax2 was connected 3-5 bars without it, my iPhone captured 3 and 4 bars of our X4S and to my ISP was a rock solid 120Mbps out of 150Mbps service with 180Mbps burst. This product only worked when within 50ft of router; why would I need and extender at 50ft? Why would anyone need a signal extender inside of 50ft with today's router's signal technologies. The description of the product leads you to believe you can go to the edge of the range of your routers and extend it; that a load of BS because it cannot pick up the extra 250ft beyond the initial 50ft to extend the range. The powerline series are a cash grab as well.

title: It seems to work
text:
I am not thrilled that it basically creates 2 extended networks one for 2.4 Ghz and one for 5 Ghz. it uses your current named network and adds _2GEXT and _5GEXT
That means you need to log into it if you want to use it. I was hoping it would have the same name and seamlessly "transfer" you as you move into the zone of the extender. As is, in my dead spot, which is the kitchen, I need to log in into the _2GEXT network to get the benefits of the better Wi-Fi connection... so when i am in the middle of texting a picture while in the kitchen and the picture transfer is stalled - only then i would realize that i am on the "main" network which is very weak in the kitchen - and switch networks to the _2GEXT and miracle of miracles - Wi-Fi is good.... i think it would be better for a constant connection to the particular _2GEXT and not for a moving about the apt/ house mobile usage - but still - it does work.

title: Doesn't work as advertised nor setup program provides for.
text: Another NETGEAR product that isn't ready for prime time yet.  It should work, but if you read around, the unit will either do 2.4 or 5 GHZ but not both at the same time.  I was able to do a specific (not published by NETGEAR) sequence to get it going on both, but upgrading to the current firmware ended that.  All I can do is have the extender work in both input bands but only through one transmit band to the router at a time.  Bottom line, it doesn't work as advertised nor what the installation program will have you believe.  Like another poster, I put it up high in my detached shop.  Other than the inability to work as advertised, the unit does have a fairly sensitive receiver and transmits fine.  I went from 2 bar to 5 bar coverage and improved performance.  You can adjust the power output to fit your needs.  It isn't a big deal for something that does an iPad in the shop, I haven't learned my lesson.  I buy something NETGEAR every 3 years and find it has the same type of non functionality issue.

title: Worked but not as expected
text: The three stars are mostly from the tech support of Netgear. I ordered this product hoping to get a better signal in my upstairs loft. I have an Netgear ac1900 R700 router that works perfect. The signal is strong enough to reach the loft (router is in the basement) and I can stream on my appleTV and surf the net with no issues most of the time. 1st issue I encountered was that the extender would connect to the router but would not connect to the internet. I had to call customer support and after they determined that they needed to change a setting for my router they said they would change it for me for free if I purchased a 6 month warranty for my router. If I did not purchase the warranty then they would charge me $50. The tech kept telling me it was free, but only if I payed an additional $100+ dollars.  I have had the router for 3 years and it is great, I have never had an issue adding any device to this router until I tried adding the extender. The tech was really pushing for me to purchase additional warranties throughout the process. He finally did the adjustment for free after I told him it would just be better/cheaper if I returned the extender.  Now that it works it is a separate network from my original router and that was not what I wanted.  If you are looking for a wifi mesh solution then this is not the product you are looking for. I did return this and will purchase a wifi mesh system that will work with my existing router as an access point.

title: AC1200 - a Winner for Me!
text: I wasn't getting enough bandwidth to watch Amazon Prime video in my bedroom with the Netgear WN3000RP that  was off my AT&T Uverse router.  I tried the Netgear Nighthawk that was really too powerful for the internet speed I had and that I could not get to work.  I then purchased this AC1200 and it works beautifully. I am able to stream Amazon Prime video, Netflix and HBOGO to my bedroom with ease.  This is a winner for me.  Even though I have a lower speed 2.4gz internet with Uverse, this range extender works great to give me the power I need throughout my house...even through a tiled bathroom and several walls.  I also got a $10 coupon on this deal.  I am so glad I purchased this item.  As for installation, I do it on the computer rather than through the WPS button.  However, after you get the Netgear AC1200 to show up on your wifi, you have to give it time to connect further before clicking on continue.  I found it was not an instant thing.  As a matter of fact, I thought it wasn't working because it kept saying it had not connected.  I got side tracked with something and when I came back, it had connected!  My best advice is after you make sure it is on your network, don't give up and give it some time to connect.  I hope this my review will help others who need a range extender with Uverse.

title: Extends WiFi, Not Network
text:
Unfortunately, this was not what I expected. I needed something to extend the range of my WiFi network for use by smart devices. Rather than extend my current network, this created another network on my signal. The problem is that all my devices must be on the same network.

If you need a network to connect your PC or phone to that is out of your router's range, then this would be a great device for you. If you want to connect multiple devices to an existing network that is out of range, and it must be the same network, then this device would be useless.

Another consideration is that the instructions that come with this device are basically non-existent. A few short sentences, and if you're not technically experienced...good luck.

In short, if you need your wifi signal range extended, if it doesn't need to be the same network as elsewhere in your house, and if you know what you're doing...buy this device. If you need to extend your primary network, not just the signal, but the name, don't buy it.

The biggest positive was that Amazon took it back without any problem. They even provided pick up and a prepaid label. The refund only took a couple of days. Way to go Amazon!

title: It does help, but....
text: For some reason it caps at 100mbps when the title says 1200 and I cannot figure out why. That said, my main issue was my wifi, which generally hovered between 300-500 Mbps (AT&T Fiber), would randomly cut out for a minute or so, even though the router is in the room next to mine maybe 20 ft away...so I was looking for something to strengthen it and help keep it steady. Now, instead of getting them once every hour or two, I don't think I've had a single crash when connected to this device. Maybe one? Which I'm loving. The upload stays at a pretty solid 100 compared to the 10-20 before which is impressive. 100 down is still enough to do what I want to do, though the difference is noticeable with certain things. But I purposely paid for this one because it said 1200 Mbps, this internet isn't cheap and I want to get what I pay for. 5 stars because I do have a steady connection now, 4 stars because it caps at 100, and 3 stars because it's advertised for 1200 and the online "help" pages are extremely vague.

title: You might as well just buy some cat6 and another access point
text:
Read the negative reviews.
This thing has all sorts of problems. I haven't decided whether all extenders have the same problem.

1. To use as an extender, you must set up additional SSIDs, one for 2.4Ghz and an additional one for 5Ghz. I can live with this, but it's annoying.

2. The network that it extends has to be a 2.4Ghz network. The Netgear genie looks like it lets you pick one, but it doesn't work that way. It always chooses the 2.4Ghz option when given a choice and won't work consistently if you try to force it to use a 5Ghz network.

3. Performance is terrible. I get 300+ Mbps down on the 2.4Ghz network. With this extender, I get more like 30-40 Mbps. Unforgivable. I wish I could send this back but the packaging is all gone.

title: BOOM!
text:
After attempting to set-up a ridiculously complicated TP-Link AC1200 Range Extender, only to have it fail (no boost in range) and then stop operating all together after 41 days, I went searching for other options.

Purchased the Netgear AC1200 at half the price of the TP-Link, and was stunned by how quickly I was up and running. Literally, took less than 10 mins. using manual set up option.
1. take unit out of the box, plug into an outlet near your router, wait for amber light to turn green.
2. use your iPad/phone/PC to connect to it (I have AirPort Extreme so no WPS button), check for green indicator light, follow simple instructions on webpage to assign name/password.
3. move unit to outlet close to area that needs stronger connection, check for green indicator light. Done.

Purchased this specifically to improve the connection quality for my Skybell HD doorbell. Instantly went from ‘poor’ to ‘good’ connection. I’m happy!

title: Not as happy as I had hoped to be.
text:
I bought this to extend my WiFi coverage into my garage. My garage is at the upper limit of my home router and I have a weak signal with diminished speed while in my garage. This is important because my cell coverage is very weak and I have to rely on WiFi calling in my area. Unfortunately my home router signal isn't strong enough in the garage for consistent WiFi calling. Hence the reason for purchasing this extender.
On initial setup and use it works fine. My biggest complaint is it has it's own unique SSID and I have to remember to manually login to it when I'm working in my garage. My phone will not automatically switch to the extender. My phone tends to hang on to my home router even though it's a much lower signal. If I forget to manually login to it, my calls will be dropped. The same happens when I return to the house. The extender stays connected and my phone does not automatically switch back to my stronger home signal.
I have tried installing apps that will switch wifi connections based on signal strength but I haven't found one that consistently works.
I would have returned this unit but time ran out trying to make it work seamlessly.
BOTTOM LINE: this extender works as advertised if you are willing to manually switch between it and your home router.

You can only login to this device through the extended network and your router through the original network, so keep that in mind. title: Excellent Range, But Does Not Autoreset
text:
This product has exceptional Wi-Fi repeat range provided that it doesn't reset on you when the host modem 'flickers.

I purchased this item to connect my wemo lights and Arlo cameras. I've had the item for 5 weeks. I have noticed that when my internet modem loses signal this rerepeater does not come back on line automatically. I found this out when I went out of town and lost access to my wifi cameras. Good news? Unplugging the item will reset the 5GHz so I have connected the item to a Wi-Fi plug so I can remotely turn the power off and on to reset. Bad news? My Wemo lights and Arlo cameras operate on 2GHz and the repeater will not engage the 2GHz unless you physically press the WPS button twice [even though the repeaterhas the password stored]. The requirement just seems to be the design.

Once I move the extender more than 20 feet away from the router, devices start losing connectivity. I have better connectivity directly to the router, which is pretty weak. title: This Works Well as an AP
text:
Set up as an access point on second floor of house. Fantastic improvement in speeds. Areas of the house on second floor that were as low as 10-15 Mbps are now running 55-79 Mbps. Dead spots on first floor improved from 30 Mbps to 68 Mbps. Excellent improvement...able to stream movies and videos far better than before.

Set up was straightforward. Followed the set up instructions, but at first no internet. I had to reset my cable modem and router to get everything synched up. Once that was completed, it has been smooth sailing so far...and very fast wireless surfing. Will update if I have any issues, but for now this is a 5 star purchase and I am very pleased with the results.

title: A snap set up and good, strong signal.
text:
Netgear AC 1200, where've you been all my life? Seriously, it is a very good WiFi extender.

I've tried several base stations and extenders over the last decade of wifi streaming. (The Apple Airport Express is still a good extender, btw, just not the umph we need upstairs). The TP Link is okay but is a nightmare to set up and needs resetting often. This Netgear 1200 is basically plug 'n' play set up and adds that extra kick we needed for wifi coverage to our upstairs in a not so large home but one with a lot of devices, including a cellular security system...and neighbors that keep upgrading their wifi networks for a stronger signal. Boom! Done. We are gliding on air again. I suspect some of the issues other reviewer have had is that they are not working with the AC 1200 and that they are trying to set up their extender within their existing SSID, which reduces its capability. Let it be a separate SSID and it is both @ a 2-minurte set up and you'll get a stronger signal.

title: Thoughtfully designed handy Wifi extender.
text:
In replacing a TPLink Wifi extender product, I was not too optimistic about the performance of the Netgear going in.

The TPLink product would loose it's network connectivity atleast once a week and would have to be unplugged and plugged back in to reconnect. Verified that there was a pretty strong Wifi signal even when it disconnected.

On replacing with this unit, the setup was intuitive and I have not had a problem since setup for more than a month since I've had it.I am mainly using this a wired port for a solar monitoring system. Since this unit has been commissioned, I've been able to monitor the solar system output without any interruption.

For good measure, I've been able to connect the laptop as a means of testing with very high signal strength. In fact the signal strength was pretty good and I had to turn it down to 25% to make sure that I was not contributing to signal noise in the neighborhood.

Overall, a very good buy and while there are cheaper units, this is a good reliable product that I would have no hesitation in picking up again.[[ASIN:B014YN7LVE NETGEAR AC1200 WiFi Range Extender - Essentials Edition (EX6120-100NAS)]]

title: It does work great and I really highly recommend it, but...
text: It does work great and I really highly recommend it , but I caution you from buying on Amazon, because of what our housed endured setting it up, and I will tell you about it. Our modem is downstairs and my roommate living upstairs complained about connection problems. These problems included 1) Unable to stream, constant buffering  2) Unable to download files, files timed out. It is easy to setup, but the device we bought on Amazon completely destroyed our home network. It changed the name of our network, even though it's not supposed to do this, and the network had a password that differed from the one our network, which it also not supposed to do.Everyone in our house (7 people) were up in arms because they couldn't get online. I got really frustrated and tried a lot of passwords which included the ones on the back of our modem. Nothing worked. I ended up having to call our internet provider and they changed our network back to the way it was before. I was aghast. The next day while everyone was out of the house I tried again, but this time I restore the device back to factory settings. This time everything worked the way it was supposed to in the directions. The reason I give this one star is because the only thing that explains what happened is that someone owned this product before us. But they sold it as a new product. So basically, it is very possible you will get a used one, and if you do its going to knock down your network, unless you are smart enough to hit the reset button using a paper clip before you connect it to your network, but the directions don't ask or tell you to do this. They assume that your product is brand new.

text:

This thing is connecting to a NetGear R7000 so Netgear has no excuses for compatibility. And... The thing is patched to highest firmware... And... It's a wall light with no WIFI.. You'll get an IP address.. and you can ping the extender... The extender says everything is good... Can't ping the Router on the other side (which is also the Default Gateway)... JUNK ACHIEVEMENT UNLOCKED

To NetGear: I'm sure you want to make your products easy to use, but you also have to give us the capability to troubleshoot link problems. When all the normal troubleshooting elements are included in the product, you cause folks like me to hate the product.

title: Horrible product. Hijacks your browser while failing to connect.
text: It seemed to work at first and setup seemed easy. After about a month, I was unable to log onto the Internet either through the extender's address or the primary router's address. This occurred both with my laptop and smartphone. It'd try, but it was as if the password wasn't working; it couldn't complete the login. My wife was still able to log on using an iPad. I tried again some days later, and it asked me to go through the setup again. But when I tried, it wouldn't complete the setup. When I tried to make my phone "forget" the extender's address, it wouldn't. It refused to let me log on using my primary router. It's like it's hijacked my phone's browser, though I ran a virus check and nothing was detected. This is worse than a product that doesn't work. This product is destructive.

I am returning this product because "LACK OF SUPPORT."

title: I do not write reviews.... ever ...
text: I do not write reviews....ever. But I felt a definite need to write one for this product. We have always had issues with wifi in our home of nine years. We've tried numerous routers, etc. I decided to give this a try and it works amazingly! We can stream to multiple tablets and gaming systems from places in our home that has never even thought about seeing wifi.

title: Greater Than 90% Reduction in Speeds
text:
Went through the installation process after resetting the extender. Had to use the IP address (192.168.1.250) instead of the link (mywifiext.net) suggested because my browser kept saying it couldn't connect because I didn't have internet even though you're supposed to connect through the link. Installation went very well.

Immediately noticed they I lost a "band" on the little wifi icon when connected to 5G even though the device is less than 10 feet from my desktop computer. I completed a speedtest when connected to my router and the extender. Router performed very well when connected to 2.4 and 5 getting scores of 60Mbps and 200+Mbps. When connected to the 2.4 and 5 on the extender the scores were consistently around 10Mbps. Don't bother buying unless you plan to just browse the web for articles in the basement. It'd probably be better to just buy an ethernet cable extender for the outlet instead.

title: Decent unit after difficult installation
text:
I found the unit less than easy to set up. First, the instructions give you the option of setting up under WPS or a web based scheme that is supposedly more protective of your network. But, there is no explanation in the instructions concerning the protectiveness of these different set up options, much less whether each is available under the customer's router and computer set up. Second, at least in my case, there was a problem in the router ID that prevented the thing from working. I do not fully understand this discrepancy, and don't understand how installation could be achieved without more technical aide.

Happily, Netgear offers technical support by phone which was sufficient to resolve my problem, though it took two different technicians, after I was cut off from the conversation with the first. The second technician was a hero in getting this thing working after about 2.5-3 hours on the phone with each. Perhaps my problem was fairly unique given many other reviews reporting an easy installation.

The unit extends the WiFi substantially, resolving my needs.

title: Great for my RV traveling or motels.
text: I have used two NetGear extenders.  My wife and I were full time traveling in our RV for two years and stayed in over 250 different RV parks.  We discovered many parks say they have WiFi, but we discovered that we couldn’t get reception inside of out pretty RV.  But if I put my extender outside it would increase the signal enough to reach inside.  Sometimes I would have to plug it in halfway between my RV and their router.  I did use my cell phone to walk around to see where I had a good signal that I could extend.  I have two cautions.  First it does take some time each time you move to a new RV park to set it up with their password and the second item is some RV parks don’t just have a password to sign in but have a website to sign in on and I usually couldn’t sign in with that system, but that was usually rare.  I have also used it when I use my timeshare or motel.  I  also forgot but my next door neighbor needed a wifi about twice a year and the extender reached her house if I put it in my bedroom.  It is a great device to repeat your signal.

title: Decent to fill Wi-Fi gaps but that's all
text:
I purchased this for several reasons - like you I needed to extended my WiFi signal thru my home.

Setup was super easy and both bands worked with no problem. For the review, I set it up using WPS and via Ethernet cable.
I place the router not more than 50 feet and initially had issues with signal so I found a different spot - boom took care of it. The lights on the front are easy to see at all times and it gives you signal strength status. Antennas are maneuverable so you should be able to find a good signal. I didn't care that it didn't have a is port though some might. My usage didn't require it though my next purchase will. The Netgear_EXT Wi-Fi network on the extender is unprotected so understand that. You can use this as a access point as well. I loved analytics app because I could see every device connected to it. I hv android so I was in good shape.

Now for the not so good. I had 8 devices hooked up to it - all 2.4g band and got poor throughput. Shuddering with excellent signals, freezes and to fix it I had to restart the device and those connected to it only for it to happen again. I measured only 21mbps thru-put And the specs say GbE gigabit. It doesn't use beam-forming or MU-MIMO technologies for solid connection for a lot of devices. I only had 8 and it had issues. I took it down to 4 and then 2 and I just can't take it anymore.

I contacted them about this and their nightgown R7000P that drops so much it's hard to get lot of production done but they didn't answer not one of my emails even with the 90 day 24/7 tech help. But the community was a help but didn't fix anything. I just found that other buyers of the product had similar issues.

As we spask I'm looking for a much better unit. I can't blame netgear for my oversight on the MIMO - but this extenders technology is outdated. So if you want to cheaply fill in a gap in single ok buy it. But if you need more then this is not the unit.
My biggest disappointment was that they never responded so I didn't get the tech service they offered and i had issues with the router and still do. But the router I'll deal with for the time being.

I'd pass on this device and get one with MIMO or beam forming plus us port. Save your money.

title: Review of Netgear AC1200 WiFi Extender
text: This is a great extender.  I have bought many extenders and this one was the easiest to set up.  The front lights on the extender make it easy to figure out if a location is a good one to pick up the main wifi.

title: It is pretty easy to install.
text: It is pretty easy to install, but does it truly expand the wifi range? Well, sort of. I wanted something that would take my existing signal and extend it to the garage. in order to do any sort of success story the extender needs to be physically outside. I am trying to think of ways to hook it up to an ethernet cord from the router, to the extender and place the extender in the garage rather than in the elements. My garage is detached and maybe 75 feet from the router in the basement of my house. Without the extender, if I leave my garage service door open, and am near the entrance to that door I have about 50% signal regularily. If I shut the door, it basically is running on Data. With the extender, The only real success I had was to plug it in outside of the house on the wall, and that was physically only about 20 feet from the router from inside to outside. and that I think will work, just need to protect it from the elements if I were to keep it out there. I think the extender graphic on the box is a bit exaggerated if you ask me.

I placed it in a hallway outlet in about the middle of my home, about 30 ft. away from my wi-fi router, and the same distance from my TV, which I stream to. Before installing this, streaming would be interrupted to buffer whatever we were watching. Now after installation, this has not been a problem at all. We have also noticed increased signal strength in other wireless devices, but from what other reviews said, I really expected a much stronger signal. This may have to do with interference from structures within my home. Increased signal strength outside my home is better also. Overall we're pleased and I would recommend this unit.

title: It just works! - UPDATE - it sure did, for a while
text:
UPDATE 5/13: Starting experiencing an intermittent issue where the 5G network would be unavailable, then both networks would drop entirely. Sometimes this would remedy itself within 5mins, sometimes this would require a reset, and a few times, the network info just disappeared altogether, requiring me to set up everything again. After troubleshooting my network setup, I have determined this to be due to the extender (as much as I would love to pin this on the notoriously garbage signal reliability from my internet provider that rhymes with Rectum). This is a shame, as Netgear was a brand I could trust. Maybe this model is just too old (2016?), maybe it's the fact that it was acquired used (though not likely), I dunno. Either way, I'll be shelling out the cash for a nicer unit from TP-Link that has Wave 2 MU-MIMO support, along with some other goodies.

Turns my 2 bars of 5ghz into 5, a huge improvement. Router is downstairs, on the opposite end of the house. Speeds are identical to the full signal wifi I get directly from the router! Since I'm working from home, signal reliability is paramount. I have experienced no drops whatsoever. I bought a used unit that was cosmetically perfect, however the previous owner left their network info in there. Oops. At least the setup process was a breeze, other than having to hunt for a paperclip to reset the unit. A solid product, for sure.

title: In short, I STILL don't have reliable WiFi...
text:
I bought this to help boost the range of a Netgear wireless router in a roughly 3,500 sqft house. The router sits at the very end of the house, downstairs, and my work machine on the second floor at the OTHER end of the house gets 1 "bar" of 5g signal. I configured this unit using WPS as per the instructions and plugged it in towards the middle of the house, and would see 2-3 bars of 5G with it using the afore-mentioned computer... ...for about 4 months. Now I either get 1 bar on occasion, or more-often-than-not I can't see the signal at all. When I connect to the signal with a closer device, it'll usually quickly kick me down to the 2G signal from the router itself. I'm not SURE if this is a problem with the router or the extender, frankly. However, just today I noticed that the work computer can see the 2G signal from the router at 4 bars while the 2G-EXT signal from the extender showed 2.
Bottom line: I'm buying an ASUS Mesh system and will likely never purchase Netgear equipment again.

title: Be careful out there and do be talked into paying for issues caused by installing a product. A good company would not do this.
text: First and last Netgear for me. Attempted to install as an extender exactly as with enclosed instructions. The unit had some bad effects where I could no longer get on the internet via my router/switch but only via the unit wirelessly with an ethernet cable hooked up to computer and unit. I contacted support which sounded like India with someone reading from different scripts. I obviously new more than this and another person. I have multiple engineering degrees and programming. I uneasily allowed him to connect to my computer where he pointed to a "Network Access Protection" issue and they could fix for just $150. I of course said no thanks and disconnected. My computer began to running files unnecessarily and shutdown on its' own and start in safe mode. Well, likely OK, but to be safe I knew what to do, stopped the start, shutdown my router, started by loading files manually while inspecting. I had some issues and also knew how to fix protection they/unit installation messed. My son a software engineer/coder and I got on together remotely and fixed everything in just minutes - no $150. To be fair to Netgear I do not know if these support/script readers just have limited ability or if India support people are attempting  to make a few bucks for themselves on the side. I've now installed a less expensive travel router I travel with in the area I had an issue - all good. I'll grab another one of these for traveling. Be very careful out there!!!

title: Couldn't be much easier
text:
I needed to extend the reach of my WiFi network out to the end of a new addition, about 70 feet from the router. It took about 5 minutes to set up the Netgear extender after it powered up. I tested the speed and found that my original network was giving me 70 Mb/s download speed in the same room as the router. With the extender on the 2.4 GHz band, I got 26 Mb/s, as I would expect somewhat lower due to the fact that each packet uses twice the bandwidth it would without a repeater. What was very interesting is that when I accessed the extender on the 5 GHz band, I got the same 70 Mb/s download speed since the repeater was switching data from one band to the other and there was no conflict.

One thing that I really like about this device, which I haven't tested yet, is the ability to remote an Ethernet connection. I have am Ethernet VoIP adapter I want to add to a section of the house where I have no Ethernet wiring. This will allow me to convert it to a wireless VoIP adapter.

Overall, this device seems to do the job it is intended to do. If you read and follow the instructions, it couldn't be easier to set up.

title: Good WiFi extender.

title: Overheats and gums up constantly
text:
I've bought 2 of these one for me and another for my mother in law. They work for the most part however after having them for quite a few months some fatal problems have become apparent with these units. Firstly these units run quite warm in fact I'd say they get a bit hot. They have passive cooling and it barely gets the job done in fact it probably has a lot to do with the rest of the problems that I have with this unit. they are constantly slowing down, gumming up or flat out locking up entirely leaving me to reset them constantly. Adding an external fan to the outside helps a bit to the point where I only need to reset mine every 1.5 - 2 weeks whereas with the unit at my mother in law's has no fan modification has to be reset nearly every 2 days.
I can not recommend this particular model to anyone.

title: Check compatibility with YOUR router model before ordering!!
text: Not compatible with all routers!  I have an ASUS RT-68U router. (current model, top-rated almost everywhere)  The Netgear AC1200 connects and works well on the 2.4 ghz band.  The 5.0 ghz band will connect to devices, but will not extend internet connectivity.  I verified that the ASUS router works fine on the 5.0 ghz band, and spent about an hour on the phone with Netgear support before they finally decided that the 6120 is apparently not compatible with the ASUS RT-68U.  Netgear wanted me to buy one of two other  bulkier and more expensive models that they were "almost certain" would work. Yeah, right...  Instead I'm ordering a TP-Link AC1750.  (Amazon customer support was kind enough to make an exception and allow me to return the Netgear extender after the return period had expired.  5 stars for Amazon, only 2 stars for Netgear)

title: Can't use both 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz signal from router simultaneously
text:
One thing to know about these sorts of extenders--they don't work seamlessly, you have to connect to a different SSID than your main router in order to use the extended range. For instance, if you normally connect to a network named "MyRouter", you won't be using the extended range unless you connect to a new network named something like "MyRouterExtender", which is the network being broadcast by your new Netgear range extender. I was hoping this thing would work as a signal repeater, but it does not.

But that's not why I'm rating this device as two-stars. The other thing to know is that this doesn't work as advertised--you can't extend both your 2.4Ghz and your 5Ghz signals simultaneously. When I did that, I was only able to connect to my extender's 2.4Ghz network. If I tried to connect to the extender's 5Ghz network, it wouldn't connect. The workaround for this is to only extend either your 2.4Ghz network OR your 5Ghz network. You can still have the extender broadcast a 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz signal, but they'll both be backhauled to your router over whichever network you chose to set up.

I had to search the internet to find this answer, and it seems to be either a bug in the way it's implemented, or the device is advertised with features it doesn't actually have.

So, buyer beware.

title: BE WARY--LOTS OF FRAUD AROUND THIS
text:
The written set-up instructions were neither accurate nor clear. They contained no indication of available support. Fortunately, this was written on the box. HERE'S THE WARNING:

Netgear's failure to provide accurate instructions, and its failure to police its domain, means that the same site they would send you to (ending in .net) is actually a fraudulent site if you use the significantly more common .com. The .com site is also right at the top of a search result using the site that Netgear directs you to if you follow their printed instructions.

The .com site has a handy call in number for failed connections (Which, of course, are likely common given that the printed instructions are not accurate). The person at the end kindly attempts to get you to allow him to enter your computer to help you fix the setup. Fortunately, I became suspicious and did not do this. I worry for all of Netgear's customers who permit this.

So my caution is, use this product only with great caution!

title: Better Luck Using Powerline Adapters
text: I've had good luck with NETGEAR products in the past, but not so with the NETGEAR AC1200.  I purchased this in November, 2018.  It was super easy to install and indeed effectively  extended WiFi range to an upstairs office.  However, the device failed in February, literally one week after the warranty expired.  Contacting technical support was a complete non-starter because NETGEAR's "extended warranty" support fee was more than the cost of purchasing another device.  I rebooted the device to factory default settings and initially that didn't work.  However, for whatever reason it did start working again after several days so I continued using it until it finally bit the dust about a month later.  In my experience, using ethernet over Powerline adapters has been a more reliable and effective solution than WiFi extenders. Recommend the TP-Link AV1000 Powerline Ethernet Adapter.

title: Better than expected...
text:
I bought this item to use as a wireless access point for our TV / gaming station where I had unreliable WiFi signal, but an unused Ethernet jack.

I had it hooked to an older Linksys router with 100 Mbps ports and it was getting +\- 97 Mbps upload and download speeds. I was pretty happy with that because I’m an X-ennial and didn’t really understand what this thing was capable of.

We recently upgraded to ATT fiber and I bought a $60 TP-link router with gig ports. I have the ATT gateway in pass-thru mode and this little netgear AP is plugged into the TP-link’s gig port via old cat5 cable.

The 5ghz band now downloads between 600 and 750 Mbps and the 2.4 ghz band is about 275 Mbps...

This item is currently selling for significantly more than what I paid, but I didn’t have any clue that I would be getting this sort of performance out of it.

title: Works but doesn't solve slow data transfer problems
text: Range ext are always troublesome bc they must be in range of your router to work and if they are so is your wireless device. This means your device has to decide to switch over from the router to the ext. most of the time it doesn't switch and if it does the data rate is slower bc the extender adds extra hops to the router and still has the same diminished signal for its connection to the router. If it's closer to the router then your device may switch to when it doesn't need to again slowing your data transfer. Although these worked I experienced these issues as in the past with other ext's. Ended up buy more powerful router and locating it better in the home. If you use this Ext for computers that are stationary and stay in a fixed area then this device may be the solution that works well bc you can put it closer to the router for a stronger signal and give it a different Sid so all devices in a fixed location will only connect to the Ext.

Do not get this NETGEAR EX6120 (AC1200). I had just upgraded to ATT fiber 300. I'm able get +300Mbps from the router. Any devices that connects to this WiFi extender does under 100Mbps on 5GHz. Which suppose to be up to 867 Mbps for a true (AC1200) device. Tested this even couple of feet & inches from the extender. I had tried configuring this extender as an Hotspot and as access point using CAT6 cables with the same low performance results. The results as if its a NETGEAR EX2700(N300).

Unfortunately, I got bought this extender 4 months ago and can't return it. From this experience, I'll never buy anything from NETGEAR again.

So wondering these products really do work as advertised ? - they do work - but I didn't find the signal quality any better than my original signal quality (In fact this one drops more often) - so returned this one too.

One question - those whose review is really positive - and seems to be working really - Did you hard wire this extender from your WIFE provided router? Is that the key here ? Should I get this hard wired between my Verizon router to this extender ?

I am really looking for a solution that works.

title: Nice little Wifi extender!
text:
I purchased this unit to get internet to a detached garage that is about 100 feet away from the house. In simple terms, this works very well for my needs which includes everything except heavy duty streaming of movies. I followed the instructions using WiFi Protected Setup (WPS) on the extender and my router and was completed within a few minutes. I then took the extender to the remote location and plugged it in. Two minutes later, I was online using the extended WiFi (uses different SSID than the main router). When the unit was running a 5G link between the extender and the house, I was able to get 70Mbps download speeds on my phone and laptop. When running a more stable 2Ghz link to the house and 5G on the extended WiFi, I was able to get 40Mbps. In the house I have 300Mbps service that usually yields around 280-290 Mbps service. This is provided to show that you will always sacrifice some speed using an extender!

More Detailed Setup: In my case, I did my best to get the source router as close as possible to the edge of the house so as to provide the best signal possible to the extender. I have it setup running a 2.4Ghz (locked down) link from the house to the extender and then a CAT5 cable from the extender into my office which is about 40 feet away. I am not using the extended wifi although I am using another Linksys Wifi router as an access point in the office. I currently have two laptops, a desktop, and a hardwired network printer running though the extender and it works great. Keep in mind that 2.4Ghz has much better range than 5ghz but the throughput is less. I regularly get 40-50Mbps throughput on all my devices. I have been using this about three weeks and it works great. I will post back later if anything negative happens.

title: This is not the same as WiFi mesh.
text:
I knew going in to keep my expectations modest. This device is being used to expand WiFi coverage in an apartment setting. There was a "dead" corner in the far bedroom. This device provides coverage in that dead corner. It works as described, and does more or less what I expected. Setup was pretty easy if you are technically inclined, but could be difficult if you are not. If you don't know what's happening, or how WiFi works at some level, I would not recommend using this.

I set it up to use Fast Lane. This talks to the router on 2.4G, and provides WiFi locally on a new 5G network. This setup is more efficient because a packet is only in the air once on each frequency, as opposed to twice in normal mode. It is set up to use the same password as the main router. In this mode, the device creates a new WiFi SSID for devices to attach to.

The downside is that your device (iPhone, for example) decides when to leave and join networks. It doesn't necessarily switch seamlessly between available networks. So, if you are near the router, and enable Wifi, your phone will join the router WiFi. If you then walk to the other room, it may eventually switch over to the extender WiFi, but usually not without a disruption in internet. So, you find yourself manually choosing the WiFi sometimes.

I suppose that mesh system would have a better user experience. But, those are a lot more expensive. So, for now, going to stick with the extender.

text:
I used this extender to address "low wifi signal" warnings in two of my Nest cams. Unlike another brand I tried, this one does the job! I just placed this about halfway between my main WiFi AP and the cameras, changed their SSIDs to use the extender and everything works great!

No more signal quality warnings from Nest and steady video and audio streams.

Note that you need to reconfigure the WiFi SSID in the Nest cameras to use the new AP and this is more painful than it should be (need to re-scan QR code or re-enter camera ID number), but that's an issue with Nest, not this extender.

Also, I like how the extender has status LEDs to show both it is connected to your main WiFi hub and also that device(s) are paired with it and working. Nice double-check when there is an inevitable WiFi issue in the house.

After a few weeks of continuous streaming, no problems at all.

title: This product is marketed incorrectly and mislabeled by the manufacturer
text:
Let's be perfectly clear.... a WiFi range extender should not create an entirely NEW wireless network. It should extend and repeat an EXISTING wireless network. This device does the former and not the latter.

While that may be perfectly suitable for devices that are stationary, it is simply not the case for those that move around a house regularly. Most wireless devices want to connect to and HOLD a connection regardless of how weak the signal is. So, with this device creating two new networks that link back to the existing wireless network(s), your devices are somehow supposed to divine when it's best to connect to one versus the other. That simply won't happen, because it belies the nature of WiFi. Your roaming devices will sit there and spin while trying to pull data from a weak connection before they'll drop that connection and join the stronger network, unless you've implemented some sort of intelligence that knows to do just that. But the default will be to try to maintain a connection no matter what for most operating systems.

Beyond that, since new networks are being created, any device that acts as a host will likely not route connections across the networks. In other words, if you have an AirPrint printer on one network, your iPad won't see it if it's connected to the other network.

Netgear should pull this product off the market as-is, then rebrand it for exactly what it does... it's a wireless access point that is capable of using WiFi as its internet connection. Again, that might be fine in situations where a device never moves, but I suspect in 2021, that's probably a rare circumstance.

title: Does almost nothing.
text:
This is possibly the worst device created by man. It was able to extend my existing network by about four feet. After that, the signal was just as bad as using the main router. Sometimes I got a stronger signal from the main router than when I was standing right next to this thing. Then when it was working, it seemed like it struggled to actually provide the internet connection. It said it was connected, but specified “no internet connection”

If your goal is to get your WiFi into the backyard or the other side of your house, this probably isn’t the device.

title: Works ok, but may require additional support from NETGEAR and your network provider
text:
Initially, the product did not identify the 5G network in the network scan. No easy way to contact support from the company (NETGEAR). I was not able to find a phone number to get support. The only way to contact the company is by opening a ticket on their website platform. While the technicians offer instructions and suggestions, the online platform is the least effective way to diagnose a network issue. After two tickets, I received a hotline support phone number. Once I got on the phone with a technician, they were able to diagnose my problem quickly (I needed to have my network provider change the channel of my network), and the issue was resolved.
So, the product now is working as expected, and I have a very good signal in the area of my house where signal was poor.

title: Honest review
text:
Honest review:
As someone that never listens to 5star ratings cause I usually think they’re fake or from idiots I’m going to be an idiot myself & leave a 5star rating.

Range: my route is inside the main house on the top floor. I put this extender into my outside garage that is 75 feet away & built out of cement blocks. Now my WiFi hook up remains consistently fast. I tested it out by streaming HD movies & playing Smash Ultimate on Switch. Did a speed test & it matches what I get inside the house. 5 Stars.

Installation: I see a lot of people hating the installation &/or saying you have to go to some website on your phone. I did. One of that. I took it out of the box, plugged it into a wall outlet next to my router, waited 1 minute for it to boot up, pressed WPS button on extender, then pressed WPS button on my router, waited 1 minute & it connected (If that fails unplug extender & retry process). I then unplugged the extender, walked out to my garage & plugged it into an outlet inside my garage next to a window (idk if thenwindow matters) and boom I’m getting great connection & speeds. 4 Stars only due to the instruction booklet being a complete mess but it was quite simple for me. Took 5 minutes.

I’ll have to post an update in a few months since I see people complaining about it failing in 6 months. I kept the box in case that happens & I bought it off of Amazon so I can pretty much return anything I want for free. If you want to know more feel free to contact me on Twitter @Drewsefer89

title: Great... Until It Stops Working
text:
Set up on the unit is pretty easy. You just need to plug it in near your current router, then press the WPS button on both this unit and your router and wait. It takes about 5 minutes, but after that, you just unplug it and plug it in wherever you want to extend your wifi coverage to.
However, about 6 months into use when I was using a device connected to the extender, a 'login' screen, like the type you get at hotels, came up. Also, in conjunction with the login screen, the unit had completely disconnected from the router and the internet. The wifi connections were still listed, but there was no internet connection. I tried resetting it and setting it up again, and that seemed to work... for about a month. After that, despite doing constant firmware updates (to fix all the security leaks this device seems to have), the unit started resetting itself pretty much daily.
I would not buy this unit again, nor would I recommend anyone else to buy it. Frankly, I hoped Netgear would be able to make a wifi extender that actually worked (since I've had horrible luck with the little pos devices no matter what make I buy), but I was wrong.
This definitely undermines any positive experience I may have had with Netgear, and I'm not sure I would buy anything else they make again. At any rate, I don't think I can not recommend this device strongly enough. Don't waste your money.

title: Perfect Remedy for Aluminum Siding and Cinder Block Barriers
text:
I live in a home that is covered with aluminum siding (i.e., WiFi shielding), and I could not receive any WiFi signal in my detached garage behind my house. Further, the garage has cinder block walls, which are not known for their WiFi friendliness, either. Fortunately, the roof of the garage is wood, and my house has a second floor, and this Netgear unit allowed to exploit them both.

I followed the easy instructions, quickly matched up the Range Extender with my Netgear router, and then put it on the windowsill of a second floor window that faces my garage. Deal done. The extended 5G signal still doesn't do well in the garage, but the 2G signal is strong and steady out there now. Just what I wanted!

Pros:
- Easy to set up.
- Does exactly what I needed.
- Not particularly expensive.

Cons:
- None identified at this time.

title: Poor customer service.
text:
I received the item on time. I tried to install it so it was secured requiring a password. I was unsuccessful. I tried an on line chat with an alleged Netgear assistant. I was told they would have a technician call me. They did.

I was told they could help me get it installed but they had to take over my computer screen which I allowed. About a half hour or so later I was told my computer was infected and they could fix it for $99 for one year, $199 for two years and $299 for a lifetime membership. I expressed my opinion very lividly and hung up.

I called back told them I wanted someone who spoke English that I could understand. They got my a supervisor. He said they would take care of it by an on line chat. Again Netgear’s customer service is outsourced. The online chat started ok until it came time to take over the computer. I let the person do it for the second time. After 45 she proceeded to tell me it was going to take a lot of time. I asked her if it was free. No answer other than it was going to take some time. At this point I wrote how I felt and terminated the on line chat.

I then contacted Amazon to return the product..

I will not purchase another product from Netgear as their customer service is a gimmick to sell some other service to who knows what. I know my Mac is not infected as I have no problems with it and I am the only one who uses it. Besides I normally use my iPhone and iPad to check mail etc. it usually sits in the computer bag turn off.

Ps. I never did get the product properly installed.

title: Unobtrusive, small sized and portable!
text: I bought two of these on Prime day at bargain prices because of their small size and portability. I gave one to my daughter to cover a dead spot at her house. Since the unit doesn't require cords and wall mounting, it could be plugged unobtrusively into a hallway outlet. So far it seems to be working well for her. The second one I purchased as an extra. I have excellent coverage in and around my house but it comes in handy when I  need to boost WiFi signal to detached buildings. It is easy to set up with dual band routers in wireless bridge mode so that it combines both networks and extends them to create a single extended "fast lane". It is advertised as being capable of operating in bridge mode to extend each band separately but I found this problematic therefore, the four stars. That wouldn't seem a "best choice" method for me anyway so it really didn't matter. I do like that it has an input RJ45 port as it can also be used to set up a wired access point. Overall, it appears to be a good & useful device especially considering it's Amazon Prime Day sales price.

title: Quit working in < 2 months
text:
Update Jul-21-2018: Worked like a charm for about 7 weeks. For whatever reason the 2GEXT and the 5GEXT, while showing a good connection to the internet, generally don't actually transmit data. Trial and error suggests that if I clear the settings and re-set it up again it will work for a day or two, but no longer.
Received it yesterday, very easy to set up and run. My router has a WPS button, which makes everything easier. Except for the following bizarre problem: while the ipad worked fine with it, my Macbook didn't seem to realize that the WPS setup had worked and wanted me to use the setup software instead, so I went through those motions. Then it wanted me to login to the software before giving me access - the same kind of message you get in some hotels, asking for your name and room number before letting you proceed. Stupid, I thought, but I typed in my Just Previously Set Up email address and password, which it did not recognize. I clicked on the password help and it revealed to me back the exact email/password it refused to recognize. Frustrated after 1/2 a dozen attempts, I decided to send it back. But today it works fine, no login prompt, just a strong connection to the router. No troubles with bandwidth, for me at least.

title: Be patient, read the instructions
text: I got this to extend my wifi signal up to an apartment over the garage. I learned by doing the startup process that a little patience is required at each step. Wait for the lights to come on when the buttons are pushed. They may take 2-3 minutes. Don't start pushing buttons and getting red in the face. The instructions should stress this but they don't. Once I figured this out, the WPS function hooked me up and I was running in 15 minutes. This product works as advertised. One more note, the Device LED will turn red if nobody is connected to it. This does not indicate a fault, just the absence of a client user. Once any client is connected the device LED will turn green again. Knowing this will save you from chasing a nonexistent fault.

title: Very easy to set up. Did exactly what I wanted it to do by giving me a strong signal on my patio.
text: It was very easy to set up. It took less than 5 minutes. I used the WPS method. I plugged in the extender close to my router. I pressed the WPS button on the extender, then the WPS button on my router. Did that 2 times to set it up for 2.4 Ghz and 5 Ghz.  Then I plugged it in about 50 feet from my router. Now my wife and I can use our iPads on our outside patio, which we could not do before. We get a very strong signal. On our iPads we can select either the 2.5 Ghz or 5 Ghz network. You use the same password as you use for the router.

title: TERRIBLE DEVICE-NOT WORTH THE MONEY
text:
If I could provide less than 1 star review I would. I ordered this in the hopes that it would solve my wifi issue in my house. I work from home and require fast internet, but my current office location is just out side of my wifi range, so it has been spotty and keeps dropping. I plugged the device in and followed the directions and hoped that it was easy to use, but when it continuously refused to connect, I called the 800 help number. I was connected with customer service provider named "Don Rider" who proceeded to tell me I had to let him log into my computer and 'see' the issue. I did on a very old device that isn't used any more (and now I'm wondering what junk he uploaded) and he told me that I had all sorts of issues, but for the one time low price of $299 he could fix it and get the device connected forever or for a low yearly price of $149 he would get the device connected.
What a SCAM! I refused the service and hung up, then I removed all traces of program that he used to log in and promptly returned this. I am now the proud owner of a Linksys wifi extender that was so easy to use! Just plugged it in and it connected immediately. No issues. I would NOT recommend this for anyone looking for something safe, reliable, and easy to use.

As a result I missed the return period by one day... my mistake. I had no problem getting it configured and no issues with connecting to both the 2G and 5G connections. It also appeared to have decent signal strength and I had no issues with my few initial quick tests streaming video to a smart TV in a bedroom that was a bit too far for the wireless router in the basement to reach. However, and here's where I made my mistake, this Netgear extender failed miserably when actually trying to watch a movie and stream music. It kept up with the signal for the first few minutes or so, which is all I initially tested, but then had constant dropouts when actually sitting down to watch a movie and listen to music. Oh well... learned my lesson. Do NOT take what looks like a good connection and a quick test for success!

title: Does what it needs to. I use it for my PS4.
text:
My OG PS4 (capacitive touch buttons) is probably the only device in the house that only supports the 2.4 GHz band. For some reason, the connection sucks on the 2.4 band these days, and while the 5 GHz band has amazing speeds, those speeds don't reach my PS4 in my house, let alone support it. So I used this extender to capture that 5 GHz band and have my PS4 connected to it through the ethernet port. That way I can get the better speed on my PS4.

It is true extenders only give you about half of the speed of the original source. I have 350 down and only get around 150 through the extender. The speed on my PS4 maxes to about 80 Mbps though, for anyone wondering.

Still works fine after almost of year of use. Needs to be powered cycled at least once a week or the speeds can drop from my experience.

title: Set up - Very easy out of the box
text:
First off, I did receive this Model: EX6120 directly from Netgear to test and review, but my review will be completely non-bias.

Set up - Very easy out of the box. I tested both the WPS method as well as going through the web browser. Both were a breeze, but the WPS is much faster. If you have that capability on your current wireless router. I recommend it just for the ease of setting it up. However, if you want to custom name the extender, then you have to go through the web setup.

Features - 802.11ac, Dual Band, Gigabit, Wall-plug, External Antennas. The nice thing about this extender, is that it does work with both old and newer type of wireless routers. I tried it on both an older ASUS router as well as my newer Netgear Nighthawk. Both worked seamlessly with setup, but there was a difference in the range. More on that below.

Performance - This was a little tricky because I have a pretty large 2 story house at 3400 sqft and my office with the wireless modem is located on the bottom floor corner of the house. So placement was a tricky for getting a good signal to the upstairs master bedroom on the complete opposite side of the house. I first tried placing the extender in the middle of the upstairs hallway, which is about dead middle between the wireless modem in my office and my master bedroom. The signal from my devices to the extender was great, but the extender would not keep a good solid connection to the wireless router downstairs, so I had to move the extender into the guest bedroom down the hallway, which is right above wireless router. That seemed to work much better and the extender keeps a good connection with the router while still giving me a good connection to my devices in the master bedroom.
There was a difference in speed in trying both the ASUS router and the Netgear Nighthawk.I tested both one right after the other and found the new Nighthawk edged out the ASUS by about 15 Mbps faster. Which if your doing normal browsing may not make a big difference, but for video, it certainly can effect the playback and can be quite frustrating if your video keeps buffering or freezing up.

I think for the cost, this does a pretty dang good job and would recommend it for smaller homes than mine. However, I think for a larger home, stepping up to the EX6200 or even the EX7000 would be much better. If your wireless modem is located in middle of your home, that can male a big difference as well.

Another note; if you have a slow internet connection coming into the house, such as an old crappy DSL service, no extender will help speed things up. I happen to have Comcast Cable and it's screaming fast (100+ Mbps), which certainly helps. Especially if you connect multiple devices at once. The extender only works as good as the signal getting to it. The more speed, the better it works!

Hope this helps!
