title: Does exactly what it says at a great price
text: The wifi extension part of this is pretty bad, but that has nothing to do with the product and 100% to do with the underlying technology that wifi extension in general has.  Given my 200Mbps internet from fios was giving me 20Mbps with a super high latency on repeater mode, I decided to run a lan cable from my router into this one to use in access point mode.  Boy does that work great.  However, I was wondering why it seemed to max out at 100Mbps on all of my speed tests.  I turns out that the lan port on this thing is 10/100, and not gigabit.  Still, I can get strong 5Ghz in the upstairs of my house.  100Mbps will do 4 concurrent 4K streams, so I think I will live :).  Also, I found out that my wifi printer (on the router's 2.4G network) is found by a laptop upstairs on the 5G network using this device.  Very nice!

title: WARNING - Your WiFi password will be sent to Netgear WITHOUT your consent during setup!
text:
What a horror. What we discovered with this extender calls for a class action.
We wanted to set up our extender and were already pretty shocked that one of the 2 set up procedures requires to create an account on the Netgear WEB site! So we decided to use WPS. This procedure took over 30 min trial and error but finally succeeded.
Then the next shock: Our IPAD immediately reported a WEAK Security, even though our router has WPA2/AES, the extender only uses the WPA2 but with the over 10 years outdated and very insecure TKIP - That was 1990 standard, not 2021!
We tried to set up our extender once more, this time via WEB site and what we discovered then made us speechless: All and every data INCLUDING our WiFi password had been transferred via internet to Netgear and all WITHOUT OUR CONSENT! This is highly illegal.
Unbelievable - For us definitely the very last Netgear product we ever purchased. We will never trust this company again.

text: Set this up in my garage to get extra boost out there, the device couldn't establish a decent (even "yellow") connection to the router in the house. Moved it to my bedroom on the second floor, directly across from the router on the opposite end of the house, yellow-to-red connection. Moved it into the bathroom, other side of the wall from where it was in my bedroom, everything green (thing I wanted boost for is located in garage). It is so temperamental it is not even worth the price tag. Also, have had to reboot it twice now within 4 hours of installation because the extended network cuts out. I'm sure having it in the bathroom will cut the lifespan short, but considering its pretty much trash, don't really care. Gave it two stars because at least the setup is super easy, but that's where the praise ends. Have had it too long on a shelf to return, but wont be getting another Netgear network anything regardless.

text: Just got this in. First off, instructions are sort of a gray area. I tried to follow them to no avail. So.....I went to the website,and guess what?...the instructions there are slightly different. Still no luck. So I register the device so that I can get free support, but support isn't available until the following day. Frustrated I read back through the Amazon reviews and the first one I read has the key word I'm looking for. Ah! You have to access it wirelessly (like a laptop) to set it up. All this time I had tried to do it with my desktop which has a LAN connection to my router. That's why I wasn't accessing it, but of course the factory instructions really don't cover that. So anyway, got it all set up and working. Moved it to the mid-point in my house to where it 'should' help extend the coverage and it helps by maybe 1 bar. GRRRR. I've also found that after it sits for a while, it loses contact with my router. DOUBLE-GRRRR! Lastly, it doesn't really work like I thought it would. What it does, is establish ANOTHER address for your equipment to use. So, for instance, if your network is named 'MyNetwork', then when you have this device attach itself to your network you end up with 'another' network named 'MyNetwork_2EXT' (or 5EXT). That is your network extension for your devices to attach to when your regular network isn't reaching. So that means you have to put your password in your devices for this new network as well. Anyway, I think it has fallen short of my expectations and I'll be looking for something else to fill in the gaps. I'll probably be shipping it back ASAP.

title: Super easy to set up even without WPS. Even with apple airport extreme router that is notoriously third party incompatible
text:
Super easy setup. I was worried that i wouldn't be able to set it up because of the preferred WPS setup. NOPE, super easy to set up!
I plugged it into the outlet in my room which is close enough to the router that i can use that routers own signal, but i wanted a boost and be able to have my own network partition for my room. So once i plug it in, i go to my computer ( any mobile device with wifi will work), and search for wifi networks, it will show a network along the lines of NETGEAR_EXT. So you connect then open a web browser and it will direct you to the page to setup the extender, allowing you to select which networks and what types of ffrequencies to allow. Super satisfied. 750 and 1200 both look the same and both support 2.4 and 5 ghz with a feature that converts it into one fast network its awesome. Setup is pretty much that easy and thats if you dont have a WPS router, if you have one i assume setup is just press the WPS button on the extender while plugged into an outlet near the router, while also doing the same on the router.
They should automatically sync, and then you can take the extender and plug it in somewhere in the house where you need it, it just needs to be roughly halfway between the device and the router signal that you are trying to extend.
So glad i purchased.

He asked for access to my computer to check my modem, and I foolishly allowed it.  He began to sent all kinds of files to my computer and really bore down on trying to sell me an expensive program that would protect me in the future as my modem was corrupted.  After he was so adamant, my radar began beeping and I realized this was a scam.  I told him to get out of my computer and  then immediately unplugged my modem and turned off my computer.  When I later went back to bring my computer up,, I could not get in.  It cost me $99  paid to Dell to get my system straightened out.  I will never consider buying anything from Net Gear again.

title: Kept dropping the connection
text:
What a waste of money. I had high hopes for this thing, and was completely disappointed.

I have an older no name JCG JWA-N8002 300M repeater which I was using for 4years which used only 2.4GHz. Since I have had 5GHz for a while now, I thought to upgrade it as I kept get interference on the 2.4GHz from the microwave oven of all things on the old repeater.

Well I got this Netgear and the first issue was the setup. It was straightforward and since I'm tech professional I could easily set it up.
The limitation of the fast speed setup others had mentioned was there. You can only use one band for either up or down stream when setting up for fast speed configuration.
i.e For the Fast speed. So 2.4ghz for Repeater to Router, 5Ghz for Repeater to devices or vice versa. No problem.

I tried that setting and didn't see much improvement beyond how it was working. For me the distance from router to unit is literally 15Ft. Yes the router is in the next room so I wasn't bothered by fast speed or regular, I just needed it to work and not be disturbed by my microwave oven.

All I really used it for was to bridge the wifi to Lan and use the lan connection on the repeater.

It worked quite fine and then I noticed the main issue which earned it this 1 star review.

IT KEPT DROPPING THE CONNECTION. NO JOKE!

It would work for a while (30MINS) and then would drop the connection for less than 10 seconds and then continue.
This would seem fine at first until you start streaming or moving files then it becomes a real pain.

I tried to change configurations, I changed the upstream/downsteam. I switched it to use only 2.4 or only 5Ghz. Same thing. I switch channels on Router and tried the fast speed. Nope. Same behavior. Dropped connections regularly.
I tried so many different things instead of just sending it back for refund during that refund window. It still dropped connections.

So in the end, I went back to my old repeater and bought a new microwave which no longer interferes with the 2.4Ghz connection. I have had no dropped connections on my old repeater since then. I don't understand how a cheap brand can be so much easier and functional than a NETGEAR product.
Very very disappointed.

title: Setup is a breeze if you read the reviews here on Amazon
text:
Included instruction is horrible. All the related searches for support on Netgear's website essentially came back with similar "instruction." I had to come back to Amazon and searched for setup tips and tricks from other reviewers. Who'd guessed that Amazon has better customer service and support on this product than Netgear?

Some tips I found:
1. Setup using a mobile device, such as cellphone or tablet, is much easier than a laptop.
2. If you don't want to broadcast your SSID, don't use this product. The "hide SSID" feature of this product becomes unstable after a while. My tablet would default back to its original wifi connection as if this range extender didn't exist. Once I broadcast my SSID, than everything worked fine.

title: Power loss resets the extender's MAC address
text: We've a Netgear AC1700 wi-fi router in the basement & a workspace on the 2nd floor.  The wi-fi signal strength is OK but wanted to provide a boost. I configured the extender a couple of ways to check best reception and finally settled on its default mode of simple 4g/5g support.  During the process of these configuration changes, the extender's virtual MAC addresses changed on each power reset. It took me quite a while to figure out what happened  at the first change, it's not mentioned in any documentation. The consequence of this was the router would deny internet access until the new MAC values were approved in the router's configuration. A complete PITA! The extender is now plugged into the UPS in the upstairs workspace.

title: NO Connection to Network (at all). Troubleshooting didn't help. Review based off of not working at all...
text: I give only one star since I can't give a real review since I could not get the extender to link to my network at all. Since I had to manually setup I did so as the instructions told me to (setup in the room that the wireless router is in). After no success connecting manually with [...] (it would pull up the website and tell me that my extender was not connected to the network) I followed the troubleshooting instructions (online since the actual manual didn't have anything useful in troubleshooting, thankfully this wasn't a router ;-) just an extender). I tried factory resetting the range extender 3 times (no luck). I tried the hard wire (via three different cables, a CAT5E and two CAT6 cables just in case there was a cable issue) and I could never get the router light green connectivity (only a steady blinking orange meaning it can see it but that's it) and therefore still the same issue of the mywifiext.net telling me the extender is not connected to the network. Thinking possibly it could be the router needs to reset all hardwired addresses I reset my router twice and still the same issues. I tried restarting my main computer then I tried two other computers all with the same outcome. I even tried different web browsers (chrome, MS Edge) and cleared the cache and again had the same results. I tried the connect to the extenders IP address (provided by troubleshooting online) and couldn't access it either. NOTHING in the troubleshooting worked (including my extra PC skills in troubleshooting networks). I don't recommend this unit based off of not working at all for me. I'm returning it for a refund and will go with a different extender (one that has mostly positive reviews, I shouldnt have jumped at the Amazon Prime day deals, it wasnt...)

title: Shocked that it worked so well! Highly recommended.
text: For some reason, I've always doubted or was skeptical of these types of "gadgets". However, a friend of mine bought one and at the time I was piggy backing (with permission) my neighbor's wifi from the apartment below mine. The signal was low to medium strength. I initially bought a different model that had a higher signal strength rating and coverage area. It wasn't easy to set up, because I didn't have access to the router. I returned it and bought this one. The setup took me less than 5min and I was absolutely shocked by the strong signal strength in all corners of my apt with all devices. I bought a second one for my house in the country and now have signal strength far out in the fields. I highly recommend this product if you have low-medium signal strength in any part of your house or if you need stronger coverage outside of your house.

title: Hard to configure, goes offline within minutes
text:
I have been working with networked devices since the early 1980s. I am a software developer, not a network engineer, but I have a lot of experience with network configuration due to some of the projects I have completed.

The AC750 EX3700 is a nightmare. It claims to be dual-band, but the only way I could get the 5G client band to work was to disable the 2.4 router band. That problem took a while to track down as there was no indication in the status page that there was anything wrong. I updated the firmware hoping the problem was fixed, but nope... same situation.

After struggling with that for a few hours, and trying different permutations to try and make it work, I gave up and chose to use only the 5G bands on both sides (router, client). That seems to work, but not really. It will work for a few minutes, but then it stops working: I can connect to the extender, but iOS devices report "No internet access" and other devices get timeouts when trying to access remote servers. I've exhausted my patience with this device so I will be returning it as soon as I stop typing this review. I don't know what I will get to replace it, but I assume there is a reasonably-priced range extender available that doesn't require an EE degree to install, and also works reliably.

title: Cheap Fix for Big Old House ...
text: I used this product to extend my wifi network in my house.  The DSL modem placement is at one end of the first floor of the house.  The master bedroom is upstairs at the other end, smart TV on the farthest wall.  Before this device, no signal.  Couldn't use my kindle in the bedroom either - intermittent Wifi.  I spent the extra $20 to get the strongest model and am glad I did.  The smart TV utilizes the 5G band, my old Roku and kindle use the 2G band, but both are streaming smoothly.  My husband can even get wifi in his shop in the garage (farther away yet).  Also notable, the device can pick up the wifi signal at a much greater distance than I anticipated.  I experimented with moving it farther and farther from the modem to see what the effect would be.  It was pretty easy to install; most of what's required is patience and ability to focus on the instructions which is sometimes pretty difficult for me!

title: Be patient and call Amazon
text: I went through the proverbial ringer with this wifi range extender AC1200.  I had an old Netgear extender and an old router from my internet service provider.  The old router was replaced.  The old extender didn't communicate with the new router.  I tried and tried and failed.  Somehow I got through on the phone with the Netgear tech support - that is a feat in itself.  Round and round we went, trying all kinds of options, and failed to reconfigure the old extender to the new router.  Threw up my hands in frustration and selected a new moderately priced Netgear - the AC1200.  Well, configuring IT was a nightmare too.  I tried for a solid hour before I went through all kinds of machinations and FINALLY got a tech support on the line.  When he couldn't get it configured, he suggested shadowing my computer to make it work.  I was hesitant, but after I shied away from that suggestion on the Old extender tech call, I thought okay - come access my computer and let's get this configured.  Well, after I asked him if he was going to actually be doing things on my computer or would he be directing me, he sounded like he was threatening me to jump ship, abandon the call and leave me to my own devices (no pun).  No no, I said, please help me.  After 45 minutes on the phone with him, he began to tell me about some system configuration he was going to have to do and called up some text edit program which I didn't understand and then started upselling me to a major job that I was just not comfortable with.  I told him I'd have to sleep on it and he was really kind of rude, chastening me that I was the one that called THEM for help.  But, you know when you're talking overseas to someone, it does get a little nerve wracking to think that I'm being asked to lay bare my computer before a complete stranger.  I said no thank you.  I just planned to return it to Amazon.  I started that process and made the choice to have an Amazon representative call me.  Christine was patient and kind.  She asked for some basic information and then directed me step by itty bitty step until LO AND BEHOLD! my wife extender is now configured, up and running.  I don't know where she's from or anything about her at all except this:  SHE was helpful and a breath of fresh air compared to dealing with the NETGEAR tech.  So, if you have ANY difficulty installing your extender - don't waste time with the NETGEAR support - just call Amazon support on the page where you're choosing to return the item - it's one of the choices you can use there and they call you right away - even at 9:30 pm. I'm sure the extender is going to work top notch like the other one did - but NETGEAR Support is the main reason I won't give it a 5 rating.

title: The initial installation was not very smooth but was not too bad. Auto setup didn't work
text:
I had unsatisfied experience with this product, not only because of its performance, but also because of Netgear's customer service. The initial installation was not very smooth but was not too bad. Auto setup didn't work, so I had to do web-browser setup, extra steps, but was okay. After setup, I moved the extender to 2nd floor, and got very strong signal on my smart TV, very happy! But my thrill only lasted for a day. I started to notice interruption with my router signal, occasionally. But the most frustrating thing was that the extender frequently lost connection to the smart TV, and the "DEVICE" indicator stayed in solid red. I had the turn the power off and back on to reconnect, very frustrating. I called the customer service (by the way, I had to register first, then was given 1-408-638-4327. The area code was California, but the service center was in India). First rep directed me to update the software. It didn't solve the problem. Called again, second rep said, "no, no, you don't need to update software. You need to reset the extender." That didn't solve the problem either. Then she said my extender was too far to the router. I knew it was not the issue since the "ROUTER" indicator stayed solid green. But I followed her instruction anyway. It was not helpful, then she asked me to reset again. Enough was enough!!! I hanged up the phone, and was upset because I felt that my time was wasted and I couldn't get real help from knowledgeable service rep. I decide to return the product.
I later did research online, and learned that such issue was fairly common for the wireless Wi-Fi extenders (no matter which brand) because "radio signal is very sensitive to interruptions". I hope this review is helpful for the people who are thinking to buy Wi-Fi extender, especially dual band one. The technology seems not very reliable. I gave a low rating, partially because of the poor customer service. Those reps were poorly trained, not knowledgeable, but over-confident and misleading, wasting customers' time.

title: So far, disappointed - product not performing as advertised
text: Generally, I'm not one to leave a review unless it is necessary and it will benefit potential buyers of this product.  I'm pretty computer literate, but setting this thing up was very challenging.  I could easily re-write the set-up instructions, making it much easier to connect.  But after waiting 90 minutes on hold with tech support, we got the unit up and running only to be very disappointed in its performance.  We measured our Wi-Fi signal strength in the backyard before installing this product, and it gave us about 75% signal everywhere in the backyard.  However, after installing and connecting cell phones to this unit less than half way between the router and the backyard, our Wi-Fi signal dropped to about 20%.  I even connected an extension cord to it and propped it up against the window which faces the back yard.  Even with the signal a straight shot to the backyard through the window glass, we never got our signal above 20%.  I am still experimenting with it, but I'm afraid to say that this item is going to end up as a paperweight.  We get a much stronger Wi-Fi signal without using this over-rated item.

I found mine (Townhouse complex, many networks!), put-in the password (both channels), and BINGO, it's worked perfectly since that moment.  No issues, range problem solved, one week, it's still rock solid.  I bought another one for the garage!

title: Useless (Very SLOW) Access Point - Buy Something Else
text:
I'm a NetGear fan, and have purchased dozens of NetGear products over the past twenty years. This is the one that disappointed me enough to make me switch brands.

As an access point the WiFi download speed from my fiber-optic internet connection is 0.83Mbs. WiFi from the R8000 router on the network is 450Mbps+. This appears to be long outstanding engineering problem with multiple NetGear products (R8000 when configured as an access point, EX6120 Range Extender when configured as an access point, FVS318N when configured as an access point all share the near-identical unusable download speeds). Upload speeds are unaffected.

This issue exists in at least three firmware versions. (I gave up after going back about two years, and not finding a version where it used to work properly.)

Just buy something else.

title: VERY EASY TO SETUP!!!!!
text: Did a lot of research and read a lot of reviews and this device is labeled as "The Best Bang For Your Buck!" Reasonably priced. Very easy to setup. Don't need to understand how any of the "techy" stuff works, just need to know how to follow directions.  We have an Arris NVG443B router with 2G and 5G broadbands. No issues connecting the extender to the router. I followed the "Connect with Web Browser Setup" in the quick start guide using my IPhone 7. Took a total of 5 minutes or so to setup.  VERY EASY!!! I'm using the extender to have wifi access on our TV in our master bedroom. The extender is about 40 feet from our router and 30 feet from our TV. Speed for streaming live TV is working great. I would definitely recommend this device. If you need tech support, the guide says "you must register your product before you can use NETGEAR telephone support".  So, if I would've had problems where I needed telephone support, I would've given this product a lower rating because I think that is frustrating that you have to register the device first.

title: Can't connect to standard AT&T Router
text:
After all the reviews, I expected a much easier process. After one hour, I still cannot get the device to connect securely to my router. The best I can get is WPS, and that took three tries. Once connected to WPS, it indicates both router and device connections, and the signal is strong, but it doesn't actually deliver any internet traffic! I have an AT&T standard home router, the one they have been using at least two years. There must be millions of these out there. The firmware is up to date on the router as well.

The setup routine is a nightmare to follow on your phone as well. Clearly no one ever tested this thing in real life, i.e. a router that is installed on the wall of a closet that you are trying to connect to while setting up and registering your device. This is 2019, spend a few dollars on a usability study before you ship a product.

I'm willing to invest another hour in trying to get this thing to work, after that it is going back to Netgear.

Btw, I have an electrical engineering degree, this is not my first rodeo.

Update: 1 month later.

This device is crap. I've spent a month trying to stay connected, trying to get some consistency, trying to figure out why my devices keep telling me "no internet connection available" when I am on the extender. Today I decided to do a full factory reset, download the firmware updates, and try again. The firmware updates contained an improved registration process, but seemed to have broken the ability to connect to the 5G network altogether. They also no longer are able to check for additional updates, so apparently they broke their own update process with the fixes. I suppose any future updates I will need to do manually. Hopefully we can limp along with the 2G network using the new firmware.

title: 1200Mbps wifi, but only 100Mbps fast ethernet
text:
I connected this to the ethernet port of my aging Linux system for wireless access. The Linux wifi drivers are crashy, freezing the whole system, and this provided enough speed over the Linux system's existing wifi that I didn't have to buy a new system. I upgraded the firmware, turned off the AP broadcast feature, and told it to use the 5Ghz band only. Been running for 2 months without a hitch.

The only downside is that the ethernet port on the netgear is 100Mbps, which is significantly slower than the wifi portion of the device is capable of. I also bought the EX6150-100NAS which has a 1Gbps ethernet port.

title: Device Stopped Working After 90+ Days
text:
Update Jan 15, 2020
Nighthawk X6S AC3000 (EX8000) Tri-band WiFi Mesh Extender. Unstable and Unreliable. I've had multiple support tickets opened for the product. Result is always the same. It works for a while and then can no longer connect to router.

The extender loses internet and restores itself to factory settings and requires a complete set up to make it work again. Hardware support from NetGear is lacking the ability to resolve this problem. Worst product from NetGear I've had.

Update Dec 6, 2019

Again this review is for the Nighthawk X6S AC3000 (EX8000) Tri-band WiFi Mesh Extender. I received a replacement extender. It worked for about 5-6 weeks then it stopped working. I had to go through the entire setup procedure again for it to work. Now, seven DAYS later and it stopped working again.

Whatever you do, don't buy the RAX120 (previously reviewed) or the EX8000. These are expensive and unstable. If you get 90 days out of them without a problem consider yourself lucky. Once you pass the 90 day mark NetGear won't provide phone support. These products are the worst home WiFi equipment I have ever owned.

---------- Previous Update ----------
This review is for the Nighthawk X6S AC3000 (EX8000) Tri-band WiFi Mesh Extender even though Amazon is unable to distinguish this review from a previous review for a different Netgear product (EX6120). That product performed so poorly: weak signal, unable to connect to main router, that I returned it.

This particular product, the EX8000 worked great for the first 90 days and then it stopped working. Only one light would come on. Power cycling the device did not help. Pressing the factory reset button did not help either.

It is now beyond the 90 day support window and too late to return it to Amazon. The product warranty is good for one year. Currently, trying to get Netgear support to replace the defective product.

As a note, this is not the first Netgear product I have trouble with. Quality of Netgear support is only marginally better than their products.

title: AC1200 compared to N300
text:
This product is simply amazing. I got this extender for less than half of the normal price and I would be willing to pay for price for this device. The range on the extender is good and can get coverage across my entire house, with must of my house having concrete board. I also have connection 300 - 400 feet away from the house. I recently got a gig up and down internet with my 2.5 and 5 GHZ band, to my surprise the AC1200 handles the speed and is the same exact speed as my router.

I first ordered the cheapest one, the [[ASIN:B00L0YLRUW NETGEAR N300 WiFi Range Extender (EX2700)]] , and was disappointing to say the least. Having gig up and down internet, the N300 would only get speeds up to 50 MBPS, nothing close to the 300 it can handle. The coverage is not as far as I hoped, barley covering half the house.

In conclusion, ff any of you are thinking about getting one, go for the AC1200 no matter the speed of your internet, it is worth it. The coverage is amazing, the speed is amazing, and for the price I think that is is the best out there.

title: Look for a better extender or get a 2nd router.
text: I bought this extender to get a wired connection rather than wireless wifi. It arrived and was working reasonable. My game said I had 40 - 50 ping but it felt more responsive than that. After a couple weeks if I accidentally unplugged it it would have me go through the whole setup process again. fast forward 3 months it keeps saying "the password is incorrect or I need to move closer to my router to connect." I move my extender 2 feet from my router and I still kept getting this error so I just kept trying to connect it. Eventually after about 30 attempts of factory resetting and painfully long, irritating setups it started working again. I joined my game and had the same ping but I was now rubber banding everywhere, so I factory reset the extender to see if that would fix my issue. Another 20 factory resets and setups I got it to work. Issue was fixed right? WRONG! I spent 45 minutes last night doing factory resets and setups and now it will randomly disconnect. Netgear can have my 50$ but the product is getting smashed and burned. I'm just gonna get a second router from my service provider and if you're looking for a wired connection i reccomend you do that too. Another router is far better and reliable than this literal garbage exscuse of a "wifi extender."

title: Easy setup, Astonishing results
text:
I've been having issues with my wifi range for many years now. I finally got around to buying an extender during Amazon day at a discounted rate, and picked this one on a whim. The item arrived on time, and I immediately set it up. The initial setup was very easy and the instructions were very clear. Plug the extender into a socket near the router, and access the extender via its own wifi signal, and follow the wizard. Within a few minutes, it was all setup and I unplugged it from that room and moved it to the area of the house with the weaker signal.
Consider me thoroughly impressed.
In an area that had barely usable wifi, I could now connect to a separate wifi network that extended much further than I had expected. While the separate network is somewhat annoying (because my iphone and other devices won't switch between the two networks automatically), I'm pretty sure all wifi extenders do exactly the same.
Overall, I'm very pleased with this product.

title: Great value for a great price.

Tried to contact Amazon, and got an extremely pleasant woman, but she was unable to do anything beyond 30 days.  I went to the NETGEAR site (where I have a router and this extender registered), and I am unable to phone, live chat, or even send an email because I am past 90 days.  So, I had an item functional for a mere five months, and no one is able to discuss a replacement.  I do not recommend you purchase this item at all (or anything else from NETGEAR given their terrible customer service).

Just don't buy this junk.

title: Nice device for 802.11ac wifi to Ethernet.  Streams HD content without problems.
text: I'm using the Netgear wifi extender to stream HD content over my internal network, and this device does the job.  For many years I used a Netgear WNCE2001 802.11n wifi to Ethernet device, and I cannot say enough about the old Netgear.  Honestly I configured the old device exactly *one* time, and there was never a problem over ~10 year use!  So, now I need faster wifi (802.11ac) to Ethernet, and the EX6120 has the right specs.  Setup was a bit troublesome, but the device seems to be working pretty.  Over the past two weeks I needed to power-cycle the device one time.  Definitely not rock-solid like the old Netgear device, but pretty good.  Negatives: No log file that I could find, which would help when debugging network problems.  The factory reset button doesn't seem to reset the device completely; I think this is considered a "feature", but I would prefer a real factory reset.  The biggest challenge was diagnosing the dreaded "The DFS channel is not allowed to use because the Radar was detected before"; Netgear could do better with describing the problem *and* please give me a log file showing what happened and when it happened.  In the end I changed my home router (AT&T Pace 5268AC) to a non-DFS channel, and now the Netgear seems satisfied.  I recommend this product to anyone that is comfortable with debugging router/network issues.  Be prepared to learn about DFS Radar.

text: I received  the extender which had a small scratch on the face. I could overlook this as long as the product worked. The claim was an easy installation process . I tried to connect with the Step 1 easy connect several times and that failed. The second method,  using my computer access to the wifi also failed. None of my other wifi devices , and  I have many, gave me a problem with connection to my wifi services. I contacted the help line associated with Netgear online and was connected with a representative who called me back on my phone. I gave  "Frank" access to my computer screen  so he could help me. He determined that my computer was "infected" and wanted to have permission to install a firewall for $145 dollars for 3 years. This is when I became alarmed and told him so. Remember, he called me when I gave my telephone number to the online help service so I really didn't know if I was still dealing with Netgear. I asked him how I could be sure I was giving permission  for a firewall installation  to a reputable source and said I would just like to return the merchandise . He said my money would not be returned because it wasn't the device .They would send another and the problem would be the same . I let him know I suspected the device I received was already returned once because of the scratch on the front. He said yes, yes ,yes and then hung up!I reported this to Amazon and was assured my money would be refunded after the device was returned. I have never had this type of experience with any other electronic company and most times give a 3-5 star rating in my reviews of products and service . Be careful.

title: Great product but be careful about websites.....
text: This was really strange,  I bought a used item and ultimately it worked great.  However, when I was trying to figure out how to set it up I Googled the product and arrived at a web page that seemed to describe installation instructions.  However, the instructions didn't work.  Then, the chat bot on the page asked if I needed assistance, which I did, and then asked for my phone number.  I gave my phone number and received a call.  The person walked me through the installation instructions but when the lights didn't come on they asked to remote into my computer because there was a network problem.  I didn't allow them to remote into my computer, but instead kept asking questions about the alleged network problem.  The person then hung up on me!  Shortly after I realized I needed to push the button on my router in addition to the button on the extender....boom it worked.  However, the person on the phone never mentioned that step and neither did the website.  Later, I found another website that was probably more legit.  So, I'm convinced this was an elaborate scam.  The product works fine but be very very careful about potential scam probably from a 3rd party.

title: Great upgrade for my network.
text:
This replaced my N300 and is great upgrade. I used the 5 GHz to communicate between the router and this extender and then use the 2.4 GHz to connect to the devices. Better penetration through walls even though there is some degradation in speed. Not having any problems with streaming and have picked up 10-15Mbs in areas that were marginal and that has made streaming possible.

The router is located at one end of the house in the office and the extender almost at the other end in the hallway. Probably 60ft plus and several walls to penetrate through. I have a smart TV in a theater room in the bonus room above the garage and am now able to use the wireless connection to it. Couldn't get enough signal without. I do believe the switch to dual band and the particular setup I used is the main reason for the improvements but I still like Netgear products. Good product and a lot smaller form factor than the N300.

Very simple to set all of this up and add my devices back to the system. Highly recommended.

My main router only has 2 available so I had to extend the 5 network from another extender I have in the house.  So it is not much use to me.

title: So far so good, working as expected
text:
So far so good. This is working like a charm. I am using this in my townhouse. The signal was pretty weak in the basement as well as 2nd floor. After setting this up the signal had improved dramatically

And to add to this, the setup process was easy to follow. I used the WPS based setup as described in the manual and it worked perfectly.

A few of points to note
. Two new SSIDs will become available for use at two different bands. For devices that you use in locations where signal is bad, you should use one of these SSIDs
. Please use the Netgear app from Android or Apple app store to check the connection strength before and after the installation. That would give a measure of how good the device is performing
. Watch out for the lights to be all green, even if they are amber, it would work but you can get them to be green by changing the location of the device

So far no negative points to write about

title: Ethernet port improved connection stability
text: Bought this to see if the Ethernet port connection would be more stable than connecting my work laptop (at home) directly to my home Wi-Fi. I know that makes no sense because it still connects to the same Wi-Fi, but the connection is actually much more stable! In fact, in a month of using it, I haven’t had a single mysterious connection drop (when I used to face them daily). I can only figure that the hardware in this product is better than the built-in wireless adaptor of my work laptop. Because of this benefit, I would definitely recommend to anyone who spends a lot of time on a computer that’s not in the same room of the house as your modem/router.

title: AC1200 - EX6120 Fixed 5G WiFi Signals
text: I use Axis WiFi security cameras that need a strong steady WiFi signal. Installed cameras on 5G because of many local 2.4G WiFi signals. The 5G wifi signal fades in and out on the cameras. Read the included instructions and within 10 minutes had the cameras on the new extended SSID. Now a solid consistent 5G signal to the cameras.  What is not obvious is that once you find the IP address of the Extender on your network and after creating a user profile you can log into the device and reconfigure the device.  First, I upgraded the firmware.  Second, I shut down the 2.4G wifi EXT signal as it only caused more interference on the crowded 2.4G band. There are many other options for configuring this extender to your environment. I could not be more pleased at how well this device worked out of the box.

title: Needs patience and persistence to setup!
text: I give this only 3 stars because of the lack of ease in installation. I procrastinated even installing it for a weeks after It's delivery after reading the instructions through several times before attempting it. My thought was, OMG there are so many steps? Why is this not just plug and follow screen instructions. Well, today was the day I decided to tackle it. Followed instructions to the letter and all I got was problems with Netgear's web page, time outs, error issues. Followed all the troubleshooting guidelines and still the same issues. It was my persistence in getting it to work that prevented me from putting it back in the box and sending it back for a refund. Each time I got to the next step their web page would time out, or just hang where I had to refresh it and then start the configuration over again! Frustrating. If you are looking for something with ease of installation, this is not the product for you. Now that's its configured to to my wifi, we will see if it was worth my trouble to extend my wifi signal. If not, off it goes for a refund.

title: Don't waste your money
text:
We have spent an inordinate amount of time trying to get this extender to work properly. Unless you are very technically savvy, it is impossible to follow the directions.

When we initially purchased the extender, it was necessary to have Customer Support walk us through the set-up process. The person who helped us was rather snippy and impatient with me, and told me that next time that I needed help, to just access their website.

Today, we received an Update Software notice, and tried to follow the directions without success. I wasted several hours trying to do this, but neither our cell phones nor our two mainframes would recognize the extender. The extender did not work at all.

We then went back to the original directions for set-up, and tried several times to get the extender to work again (without the software update). It now works with our cell phones, but not on our mainframe computers.

We do not recommend this product.

title: Easy setup with a variety of features
text:
This product can operate in several mutually exclusive modes, but I got it to function as a wifi extender, or repeater, if you like, to extend coverage to places my main wifi router/access point don't reach. In this mode, it creates another wifi network whose default SSID or name is based on the main name, but slightly different. So my laptop, tablets and phone can all connect both to my main router and to the extender. Once the password is saved, most devices will connect to the strongest signal, so when I am farthest from the main router, my tablet automatically connects to the extender.

One feature that I found really useful was "FastLane Technology." If your main router supports dual band, you can connect from the main router to the extender on one band (in my case, 5GHz), and it repeats out on the 2.4 GHz band. This provides better performance than having the extender function as a repeater on both bands at the same time.

So far, the extender has been reliable, stays connected, is trouble-free and allows my "TV room" to use a FireTVstick, my TV itself to log onto the internet, and my DirecTV DVR to access On Demand content over the internet, even though my main router's signal there was just too weak to work.

title: Works Great -- Big Increase in Wifi Coverage
text:
We "cut-the-cord" a year ago and only watch shows via our Roku and Apple TV. Also, our Xbox is down there. Our wifi access point is in our office/den and there is concrete and several walls between it and our main family room / entertainment center. So, the signal was very bad ... blurry shows, etc. This product looked promising, so we got it. It took less than 10 mins to set it up as wifi extender and to find an ideal place for it.

I tested the signal before and after setting it up. The signal at our entertainment center increased 8 times faster with the wifi extender. Now all our shows look great in HD. We are very happy with this and would recommend it to anyone experiencing wifi signal problems. As a side note: the signal also increased significantly in our bedroom, giving us better signal particularly when downloading shows onto the iPad overnight.

title: Extends 2.4ghz range, but was looking for something that performed better extending the 5ghz network.
text:
This device extends network coverage at the cost of throughput (network speed). If you are simply looking for a way to extend your network to parts of the house that do not have coverage and do not care if the speed is incredibly fast for those devices, then this is perfect for you. Using the device to extend my 2.4ghz network on my dual-band TP-Link TL-WDR3600, I was able to reach networks speeds with a solid connection at around 270mbps anywhere in the house. Normally, I get around 300mbps when connected with a good signal to my router, so that's pretty good. (It's always a trade-off between range and speed when extending the range wirelessly through a wirelessly-connected device). The 5ghz range, however, is pretty bad. Unless I have the extender plugged into the same room as the router, I cannot even access the Internet (and am barely able to access the network) on the 5ghz extended network. What's even stranger: I can connect to the 5ghz network on my router and browse at reduced speeds. So the extender actually is performing worse than the router. I will experiment with checking the channels of my devices (wireless TVs and the Dish Hopper 3) and making sure they do not interfere with the selected channels on my range extender, but I find that unlikely to be the case being I've tested this with those devices powered off and get the same results.

In closing, if you need network coverage over the 2.4ghz network and don't mind a hit to your connection speed, get this device. Do not get this thinking it will improve your speed or that you'll magically have 5ghz blazing-fast speeds on the opposite end of a large 3000sq.ft. house going through walls. Not gonna happen! ;)

title: Netgear Service Tech Attempted To Scam Me
text:
I had extreme difficulty installing the unit and I called customer support who sent me to tech support.
The tech after a half hour of not being able to help me, told me that my system was corrupted and the ONLY malware protection I could purchase was from Netgear. I asked how much this would be and I was shown a price sheet that indicated $150 a month or $400 for three months. I found this to be outrageous and terminated the call. I spoke to my IT guy and he had me run the malware program that I already had installed and it turned up 0 bugs.
I felt and feel abused and have arranged to return the unit. Based on this, I shall never consider Netgear products in the future.
On the recommendation of my IT guy I've purchased the TP-Link AV600 Powerline WiFi Extender instead and await its arrival.

title: As far as I can tell, range extenders are completely useless.
text:
I'm not an expert but this is my experience:

-The results were exactly the same with this unit (AC1200) on the 5GHz network and an older unit (WN3000) on the 2.4GHz network.

1. I did get 5 bars on the extended network in rooms where the original network only gives me two or three. But when I ran a speed test, the extended network was slower by half with the 5 bars than my original network (with 3). More bars, less speed. Same computer, same spot.

2. The same experience right in the room with the router, with 5 bars on my network, 5 bars on the extended network. Extended network slower by half.

3. I then tested it set up as an access point, plugged in directly to my router, which gave me 5 bars. Still got the same slow speeds.

I haven't tried any other brands, but from what I've researched, I suspect the results would be similar because of the way these devices negotiate bandwidth.

title: My recommendation is don't waste your time or money with this extender if you require dual band and/or reliability.
text:
I had purchased this extender with plans to expand my 2g and 5g networks currently running on a Netgear Wifi router to the back of the house and I use WPA2. I am computer literate and have worked in IT for the last 28 years. What I found was the extender would see both of my dual band networks and would authenticate but the 5g Network would indicate it didn't have internet access and devices would not connect to it. I had tried down-reving the firmware to see if it was related to that. I was working on it about 2 feet from my current wifi router. I tried moving my current channels around which made no differnce. I tried using WPS and let it configure itself. All of those attempts produced the same results. What I did discover is: I could do a reset and start over and disable all 2g and only configure the 5g and it seemed to work ok for 5g only now. I then tried manually configuring/adding back in the 2g and now it wouldn't connect or work over 2g. I put it where I wanted to extend my access and I left it overnight and it had an error and wasnt connected without a reboot the next day.

I had read reviews about how bad Netgear support was but that I had 90 days of it. So I thought I would give them the benefit of the doubt and try submitting a ticket with them. I indicated my issue and went over the above in the comments about what I had tried to do. They basically came back and asked me all the information I had just provided them. Questions like is 5g turned on, the router distance, have I tried a hard reset, what channels I was using etc. To which I went back and retold them those answers. I then was asked to move the router closer and check again and now they wanted to know what my router IP address was. As this point I could see I was going to go nowhere with them and started my Amazon Return process... (Thank you Amazon!!!). I just received a third email today from another tech asking me to try changing my wifi channels and try downgrading my firmware and how to perform a hard reset.

I don't think Netgear support reads your emails/comments I think they just sound out some canned responses and probably wait until you give up running in circles or until 90 days passes. My recommendation is don't waste your time with this extender and now I am jaded about even recommending Netgear even though I have had an older dual band R6300 for a few years that has been good to me.

title: Rated poorly for customer service and tech support
text:
A fairly standard extender. When the initial set-up wasn't going well, we contacted tech support for advice. He remotely-accessed our computer and gained access to a "log-in review" where there was a whole bunch of "warning" and "error" messages which he told us were "infections" which didn't allow for the extender to connect.

He then gave us the hard-sell telling us that we would have to buy new firewall software to eliminate all of "those infections" and after that, our extender would operate properly, AND that he could refer us to software sellers who could solve our problem. I then asked specifically whether or not we were going to have to buy a new software product to allow our new extender to work? He said yes. NO THANKS!

Being that we are fairly well protected with McAfee software, I called their tech support to verify that what he was telling me wasn't true, and show them the review page listings that the Netgear person said were "infections" and was told by McAfee that all of those items were caused by normal operating occurrences, and there were no infections. They then ran a complete scan to verify this.

So, in the end, all the Netgear customer support accomplished was un-successfully trying to scam us into buying some software I didn't need, and the helpful tech support I needed and was able to use on my new Netgear product actually came from McAfee and Arris (the maker of our Modem/Router)

The Netgear extender works ok, but I will never buy anything from this company again because of the scam artists in their contracted-out tech support.

title: simple setup (relatively), small plug footprint, great connection.
text: I have been using this very happily for a couple moths now in my tiny-home-in-a-truck, and couldn't be happier. Setup was a pretty easy, just needed to use the ethernet connection instead of trying the built-in wireless setup network, which neither my mac nor windows laptop would detect. In addition to the fantastic connection (I am getting great 5G extension where was impossible before, had to use 3g because of multiple walls/etc.), I really like how small it is. I was able to plug it directly into a plug on my inverter instead of my extension cable, which I had to do with my previous extender.

title: Caused issues with some websites
text: When using the extender, I specifically had an issue activating TurboTax software.  They seem to use certain ports to communicate between the PC software product and their back-end servers.  If I connect my PC through the Extender, the activation fails.  If I bypass the extender and connect directly to the router, the activation is fine.  Except, the next time I use TurboTax, and connect via the Extender again, TurboTax wants to re-Activate the software.  It's as though the Extender is making my PC look like a different machine each time, and TurboTax thinks it's being installed on a new PC, thus asking for re-Activation.

title: Happiest WiFi person ever!
text:
Don’t let other reviewers scare you off from buying this product. I did my research and decided on this extender rather than a booster and am thankful I followed what was recommended. I took this extender out of the bos this morning and plugged it in. After two try’s of not seeing the lights indicating that my router and the extender were connected I logged onto my computer and went to the website recommended for set up. I looked into my WiFi list and saw my router with the -ext ending on my 5G (I went through the setup twice as written if you gave 5G) then typed in my WiFi password and I was connected!
I plugged it into my kitchen which is halfway and after maybe 3 minutes both lights were lit green as you can see from my picture! I then took my cell phone to my bedroom (last room as far from my router as I could be) found the WiFi in my phone settings under WiFi clicked on the one with 5G-ext at end, typed in my password and voila!!! I am able to search quickly where I did not have any WiFi before!! Within 10 minutes of opening the package my day has begun and I’m a much happier person this morning. Thank you Netgear for making such a wonderful product!!!

title: Failed after 6 months! Netgear wants $50 for support.
text:
Bought this in Jan 2017. Within 6 months 5G network stopped working. Netgear only offers a 90 days support period for their procducts. After 90 days it costs $50 per support incident. I wont be paying $50 for support on an $84 dollar product that failed in less than 6 months. I now have to find a replacement for this device. IT WON'T BE NETGEAR! Matter of fact, I will be replacing all of the Netgear equipment I have (Cable Modem / Wireless Router / 2 Extenders) with another brand. I will never buy a Netgear product again and do not recommend that you buy their products either.

My Certs:
A++ / Network + / Security + (will provide cert#'s on request)

text:
Initially when I purchased this item, it worked well and better than other wifi extenders that I have purchased. Unfortunately, after a few days the hardware began crashing on a daily basis requiring a reboot every time to even have it work properly. I tried resetting and reinstalling, which took 2 hours because the mywifiext.net site kept crashing while installing through my iPhone and required installing via laptop. Again, the daily issue persists and now I am required to sign up and register via mynetgear to even get help through support, which I am doing now and is another hassle because this site isn't working properly. I am highly disappointed in this product thus far and considering returning this and purchasing a mesh network system.

Update: I ended up returning this product due to the frustration, especially after having a work teleconference dropped. Instead, I invested in a TP mesh system which as been working even better.

title: Doesn't Work So Good
text: The first problem I encountered was getting the Netgear Range Extender to connect with the router.  I put it in the same (small) room as the router, but had to try it numerous times (pulling it out of the wall and plugging it back in, pushing the WTS buttons on the Extender and the router, etc.) before I got the much sought-after green light.  Next, I plugged it into several outlets before getting the green light back.  This was in an area equivalent to a couple of rooms away from the router.  When I tried connecting my cell phone to the extender it took.  Got a solid green light.  But then the green light would go out every so often.  The phone itself showed the signal strength to be fluctuating.  For the amount of grief I had trying to get this to  work, I was underwhelmed by its performance.  And as for the directions, anything beyond the basic initial information was not as clear as it could have been.  I'm sure this item works as advertised for many people, but I'm not one of them.

title: WiFi dropped repeatedly until uploaded older firmware
text:
This review is for the Netgear AC1200/EX6120

I hope this review will help others with issues with dropped WiFi on this extender.

I have 2 Netgear AC750/EX3700 extenders at our home with no issues. They are still running on my home network. I needed an additional extender due to the size of our home and the recent installation of 5 Ring cameras.

I decided to stay consisitent with the others and order an additional Netgear extender and decided on the AC1200/EX6120.

From the onset, the AC1200/EX6120 would connect immediately after set up but would no longer connect after about 12-24 hours. I tried the hard reset and the problem would reoccur. I would unplug and reboot and I could connect but again after several hours, the same problem persisted.

I reviewed several reviews online and decided to upload the older firmware version as suggested.

After several uploads of the different older firmware versions, version V1.0.0.40_1.0.25 did the trick.

I no longer have issues with the wifi dropping and have consistent coverage with the extender without dropping.

While the newest firmware should have solved the problem, it has not. I hope this helps at least one person out there. Happy surfing!

title: Dosn't do what it is supposed to do and often has a worse signal than the one it supposed to boost.
text:
I don't think I've ever been more disappointed in a product than this one. We have a perfect application in our home where this product should shine. The router is on one level and a TV on an upper level. We installed the 'extender' in a perfect spot, 1/2 way between the router and the device on the next floor.

The installation was clumsy, but worked the first time, then disconnected and the second attempt was extremely frustrating; Wi-fi didn't recognize the device and I needed many attempts to get it work again. I did get it configured, and was able to connect devices to the '2GEXT' version of the signal, but no improvement at all, and often times worse than the original signal. At best, it seems to be a 'pass through' signal. We don't see any 'boost' at all.

Netgear historically has been a solid company. This product does nothing for us. Netgear was smart enough to price it low enough to make it a bigger pain to return it, than simply learn a lesson. Shame on you for selling a product like this. I'd rather pay twice as much if I knew it actually works.
